IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Motor disorders cause debilitating impacts on movement across adolescence and adulthood. Understanding genetic mechanisms that shape the development and maintenance of neural networks for body movements is crucial for identifying effective therapies for the treatment of motor disorders. Research in this proposal uses advanced genetic, imaging, and behavioral tools available in animal model systems, providing me with a strong foundation to become an independent scientist investigating motor regulation and dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Cells must control when and how much of a protein is made; dysregulation leads to human disease. The start of translation, which defines the protein to be synthesized, is the rate-limiting step and therefore is targeted by regulatory complexes that tune protein production up or down. Here, I apply biochemical, biophysical, and structural approaches to illuminate molecular mechanisms that underlie translation initiation and its control – a pillar of human cellular function.

ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: Project Narrative Interventions that increase plasticity and regeneration after spinal cord injury (SCI) are improving, but little is known about the spinal cord neural systems that would be most effective to target such interventions. This project both identifies the spinal cord neural cell types and synaptic mechanisms that would be most effective to target such interventions and establishes an artificial intelligence (AI)-based platform for fast, reliable and unbiased quantification of motor recovery in rodents. Our experimental scrutiny at both the neural and behavioral levels establishes a critical foundation for developing a prominent research program and securing independent award funding studying the spinal cord circuits important for sensorimotor function and recovery following SCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hazardous drinking and anxiety co-occurrence among Latinx persons in the United States poses a major public health concern. The proposed research aims to study the potential for microaggressions (MAs) – brief, subtle forms of everyday discrimination due to racial/ethnic status – as a culturally-specific antecedent to maintained and exacerbated alcohol use motivation, hazardous drinking, and anxiety experiences among Latinx hazardous drinkers and explore mediational processes and moderators in the MA-hazardous drinking and anxiety experiences relations that will inform future intervention and prevention efforts for this neglected health disparities group. Moreover, we seek to elucidate if MAs are distinct from, and more impactful than, non- discriminatory daily stressors and overt racism on the proposed outcomes.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The public health significance in this study lies in its potential to develop an improved understanding of how to efficiently improve depressive symptoms among adolescent and young adult cancer survivors (AYACS). The findings from this study could result in a scalable and low-cost intervention that enhances self-management of depressive symptoms in this population. Ultimately, this could lead to improved quality of life, increased adherence to medical recommendations, and reductions in healthcare costs associated with cancer recurrence, comorbidities, and premature death among AYACS.

PHR: Adolescent and young adult (AYA) breast cancer survivors experience substantial symptoms and have unmet concerns in survivorship. In the proposed multi-site RCT, we will test the efficacy of YES, a novel mHealth self-management intervention designed to address the needs of AYA breast cancer survivors vs. usual care. We hope YES will reduce diverse survivors’ symptoms and concerns and improve their quality of life.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trachoma is the leading infectious cause of blindness in the world. This project aims to develop a mobile software application to enhance trachoma monitoring activities by allowing eye photography and integration of visual acuity and refractive error assessment. The mobile application will be field-tested and validated in diverse settings in Peru to ensure broad generalizability.

PHR: Vivo is a novel resistance training exercise technology platform for older adults that offers a technology and programming solution to the limitations of impersonal training programs in the highly popular digital fitness space. Vivo will allow users to monitor and track behavioral, physiological and psychological progress in real time, and access social network functionality to promote immediate and enduring social support to reinforce the progress from strength training. The technology platform will optimize adherence by leveraging naturally occurring social support systems as Vivo users exercise in real time with a live trainer, family members and teammates.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nicotine vaping has risen sharply among U.S. adolescents over the past decade. This pilot/feasibility study will set the stage for a larger efficacy trial of a school-based intervention to reduce nicotine vaping. In this program, high school students work with researchers to develop and deliver the program to middle school students. The program includes narrative videos produced by high school students that convey vaping prevention messages, which are delivered in the context of classroom discussions led by high school students that incorporate known determinants of substance use resistance. The program includes a text message campaign implemented by high school students for middle school students.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In response to NOSI (NOT-MH-21-175) this proposal leverages multiple large datasets and sophisticated machine learning approaches to address how symptoms of mood, anxiety, and stress, collectively characterized as `anxious misery,' relate to the altered integration of functional brain regions (or networks) across adolescence and adulthood and in relation to treatment response. Multimodal neuroimaging and clinical and cognitive data collected from four Connectomes Related to Human Disease (CRHD) projects, the Human Connectome (HCP) Aging and Development Lifespan projects, and the Adolescent Brain Cognitive Development (ABCD) projects, including 2,187 people, will be analyzed in a unified manner with data-driven methods to understand the relationships between symptoms and brain networks across individuals. Project outcomes will provide a more unified understanding of brain dysfunction in people with different types of anxious misery symptoms and are expected to guide future efforts to provide more effective treatments tailored to specific people.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project is a collaborative initiative between US researchers and Lao public health officials to determine the efficacy of a novel mHealth intervention for smoking cessation among Lao patients. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it is expected to advance mHealth applications in tobacco-cessation treatment in low- and middle-income settings and subsequently reduce tobacco-related morbidities and mortality. The mHealth intervention is also affordable and scalable and thus is appropriate for widespread adoption in low- and middle-income countries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Enrolling clinical trials relies on a range of manual processes and requires timely communication with clinicians to avoid losing patients to follow-up. Arkana Laboratories has developed a mobile app, Arkana Connect™ which provides nephrologists with pathology reports, replacing antiquated manual reporting systems like fax machines. The company now proposes a Direct to Phase II SBIR program to develop automated clinical trial enrollment feature on the Arkana Connect App to provide trial sponsors with a more automated, efficient, and timely means of enrolling trials for kidney disease research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Enteroviruses cause a wide spectrum of acute disease, ranging from mild upper respiratory illness to aseptic meningitis, encephalitis, and acute flaccid paralysis. In addition to acute infections, enteroviruses, especially coxsackieviruses of the B group, have also been linked to severe myocarditis and type 1 diabetes mellitus. This study will investigate the mechanisms of entry beginning with receptor recognition by coxsackievirus B3 since these critical first steps set in motion events that promote host entry as well as initiating conserved conformational changes to the virus capsid that are necessary for release of the viral genome.

PHR: NARRATIVE Adoptive transfer of T cells that can recognize tumor and cause tumor cell death is a promising approach and has gained momentum after novel anti-tumor T cells could be engineered by viral transductions of tumor reactive T cell receptor (TCR), or chimeric antigen receptors (CAR). However, many confounding factors as susceptibility to immunosuppression, or T cell’s inability to persist and undergo activation induced cell death due to chronic antigen stimulation in a tumor microenvironment remains. In this application, we propose to generate clinical grade metabolically enhanced Tumor Infiltrating Lymphoytes (meTILs) based on our published methodology in Cell Metabolism. Successful completion of this Phase II application will support this approach where targeting immunometabolism to program TILs could be used in future trials to treat cancer patients.

PHR: Project Narrative Music training can change brain structure and function in non-musician older adults age 60 and over. The goal of our project is to examine whether a music improvisation training intervention for older adults with and without mild cognitive impairment can improve cognition and brain function and facilitate late-life engagement in cognitively challenging activities.

PHR: Project Narrative This research project promises to deliver a number of insights into the evolution of gene expression in the eye and congenital eye disease. By contrasting the genomes of blind and sighted mammal species, it will pinpoint regions of DNA important for vision and which are likely to be involved in human eye diseases. The project will then explicitly test for mutations in these regions in patients with congenital eye disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding the effects of genetic variation on gene regulation is a formidable challenge for interpreting genetic associations with complex traits and diseases. Here, we propose to reveal how genomic variation shapes immune cell and autoimmune disease phenotypes, by developing a generalizable toolkit that leverages cutting- edge gene editing and single-cell profiling technologies to produce high-throughput, genome-wide maps of gene regulatory elements and variants. This open and accessible resource of enhancer and variant effects on molecular, cellular, and organismal phenotypes related to immune function will serve as a crucial knowledgebase for understanding the genetics of autoimmune disorders and therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Plants express small RNAs that accumulate to high levels in reproductive organs harboring the male germline; these small RNAs show interesting parallels to the animal piRNAs, and perturbation of their biogenesis or activities causes sterility. Our proposed study aims to understand the localization, biogenesis, functions, and targets of a specialized class of the small RNAs (the 21-nt phased, small interfering RNAs) that are abundant prior to meiosis, using the maize as the model system. The research outcomes will provide mechanistic insights into the biogenesis and functions of these small RNAs, with the potential to illuminate why plants have evolved this unusual small RNA pathway enriched in or even specific to male reproduction.

PHR: Baltimore CASCADE Study Site (BaCSS Project) Project Narrative  African American Women living with HIV in disadvantaged regions of the US have an increased risk of cervical cancer and require focused prevention interventions using novel and emerging technologies. In the BaCSS Project, we engage the population science and clinical trials expertise and resources of the University of Maryland School of Medicine (UMSOM) to establish a clinical study site for the CASCADE network. The project provides operational leadership and pluripotent infrastructure in support of the implementation science studies and pragmatic clinical trials of evidence-based interventions for the prevention and early diagnosis of cervical cancer and supports the development of concepts and protocols to overcome barriers and reduce failures in cervical cancer prevention in WLWH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Therapeutic glycoproteins (biologics) such as antibodies address critical health care needs, but there are currently no simple methods for analyzing the attached glycans (sugar molecules) during the biologics production. The ability to monitor the glycosylation of biologics during their production would be transformative for biopharmaceutical R&D and would accelerate the creation of new biologics and biosimilars. Our innovative technology enables monitoring of protein glycosylation in near real-time in a robust and convenient manner.

PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to build the first computerized adaptive test based on multidimensional item response theory to more precisely, rapidly, and repeatedly assesses cognitive abilities, compared to existing gold-standard in- person neuropsychological testing. This assessment will be suitable across the adult lifespan (from cognitively normal younger adults to older adults with MCI), thereby advancing early detection of cognitive decline associated with Alzheimer’s disease. It also would be available online, thereby increasing accessibility in underserved populations and providing a new tool for basic and applied research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD) is the most common cause of death from liver disease and accounts for over 20,000 deaths annually, and while ALD morbidity and mortality differs among racial/ethnic minorities, we do not have an adequate understanding of why these disparities exist. We will apply a conceptual framework to identify specific clinicodemographic (e.g., alcohol use patterns), biologic (e.g., genetics), and social determinants of health (e.g., barriers to care) factors that influence racial/ethnic disparities in ALD outcomes. This proposal will yield critical data to inform future interventions to reduce disparities and improve outcomes for patients with ALD.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will inform public health research and practice on developing prevention and intervention programs that will mitigate the effect of adversity on adolescent drug use vulnerability and later drug use and abuse. In addition, our study will help determine the utility of neuromarkers to advance addiction prevention models via earlier and more accurate risk assessments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Despite increased availability of resources for chronic pain, veterans living in rural areas have poor access to these services and must attempt to navigate multiple health systems to receive comprehensive treatment, often resulting in poor clinical outcomes. In this multisite study, we will test the effectiveness of a tele- collaborative care intervention for chronic pain among rural veterans, which is designed to enhance care coordination across settings and lead to clinically significant improvements in pain, function, and quality of life. The trial will include an implementation evaluation and, if the results are significant, will lead to improved care across the VA nationally.

PHR: Project Narrative Recent studies have found that expression of the androgen receptor splice variant 7 in circulating tumor cells can identify resistance to hormone therapies in approximately 10% men with prostate cancer. We have developed a new test that builds upon this assay to identify other patients at risk for resistance to these therapies. This proposal validates this new assay to move us closer to the goal of achieving better precision in treating patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Behavioral interventions are considered a critical category for slowing, or even preventing, cognitive decline and progression of mild cognitive impairment. This study will refine a cognitive training program incorporating the approach of precision medicine, and pilot test the refined training program’s cognitive and neural effects in older adults with mild cognitive impairment. If this program is found to be effective, such a program could be investigated further to assess its promise for preventing or delaying the onset of dementia.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The underlying cognitive mechanisms involved in proportional reasoning have received little investigation and are poorly understood. The current proposal aims to address this issue by using developmental and computational modeling approaches to characterize behavioral signatures of cognitive representations, cognitive processes, and symbolic strategies used to engage in proportional reasoning from infancy to adulthood. The long-term goal of this work is to develop a coherent theory of how people reason about proportion and to leverage this knowledge to support young children’s proportional reasoning and adults’ probabilistic decision making.

ORG_NAME: H. LEE MOFFITT CANCER CTR & RES INST
PHR: NARRATIVE Tumors are not simply collections of mutated cells that grow in isolation; rather, they respond to and modify both the physical microenvironment and a variety of host cells in the organ they are invading. These changes in ecology (“∆-Ecology”) are key to understanding tumor progression and the response to therapy – particularly the development of resistance. We focus on NSCLC, the most common and among the most lethal of human cancers and will define the ecological and evolutionary dynamics that govern disease progression and treatment, with the goal of driving novel therapeutic strategies that exploit this ∆-Ecology.

PHR: Project Narrative This project aims to identify genetic variants that causally influence a range of health, disease, aging, and behavioral phenotypes in diverse populations. Existing evidence from genetic association studies are confounded by environmental factors that may be correlated with genetic variants. Using new data from family- based studies and new statistical tools we are developing, we will be able to identify causal influences, study more diverse populations, and in some cases, increase statistical power.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Polygenic risk scores (PRSs) are set to play a key role in advancing our understanding of the etiology and treatment of disease, but they presently underperform in non-European populations due to limited availability of diverse population datasets and limited PRS methods designed for application to global populations. To overcome this “PRS portability problem”, we develop a suite of PRS computational tools that incorporate sophisticated, high-resolution statistical modeling of structure in terms of: (i) ancestry, (ii) genetic risk, (iii) the genome, and (iv) phenotype. Our modeling will provide a step-change in the accuracy of PRSs computed in diverse populations and allow users to detect G*E interactions, the functional sources of the portability problem, and the determinants of disease heterogeneity among ancestries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pregnancy is a key period to optimize maternal and offspring cardiovascular health. In this project, we will collaborate with the NHLBI and the ENRICH Network to test whether a multi-component intervention delivered in the context of home visiting will improve maternal and child cardiovascular health. This project may have great benefit to society, as interventions delivered in the perinatal period have the potential to influence lifelong cardiovascular health across generations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This community-partnered intervention application will test the implementation and effectiveness of integrating a cardiovascular health (CVH) improvement program into an evidence-based home visiting model, the Family Check-Up (FCU), creating FCU-Heart. Set in the Pittsburgh metropolitan area, this two-phased study will pilot the FCU-Heart intervention and then conduct a multisite randomized clinical trial to assess the impact of FCU-Heart on CVH outcomes of low- income, high-risk postpartum mothers and children up to age 3. FCU-Heart aims to improve CVH and reduce racial disparities in CVH outcomes by assessing maternal CVH, providing direct feedback about each mother’s CVH, then offering skills and resources to promote their own and their infants’ CVH through culturally adapted evidence-based modules with trained FCU-Heart family coaches.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adjoa Manu is a promising public health graduate student with the long-term goal of becoming an independent researcher addressing inequities in reproductive health that affect people with disabilities and other minoritized population groups. The research and training proposed in this diversity supplement will prepare her for the next phase of her research career and support NIH's efforts to diversify the health research workforce. Additionally, findings from the proposed research will provide unique insights into strategies for supporting reproductive decision-making among women with developmental disabilities that affect cognition.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transgender and gender diverse (TGD) individuals are often diagnosed with late-stage cancer and often die from cancer prematurely. These individuals appear to be underscreened for breast cancer at rates and for reasons that are unknown. This K23 application will enable the principal investigator to investigate these rates and reasons; to learn from her 6 senior mentors; to take necessary coursework; and ultimately to emerge as a national leader with the goal of helping TGD individuals acquire equity in cancer screening and cancer care.

PHR: Project Narrative Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is a leading cause of death in the US. Obesity in mothers and children is linked with nearly every major CVD risk factor, including hypertension, elevated glucose, high cholesterol, poor diet, and physical inactivity. This research will test an empirically validated pre- and postnatal lifestyle intervention within an evidence-based home visiting program to improve cardiovascular health in Hispanic and non- Hispanic women and children during pregnancy and postpartum.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative High- and low-level computations for coordination of orofacial motor actions Neuronal circuits in the brainstem control life-sustaining functions, including breathing and other rhythmic orofacial motor actions that underlie both exploration and consumption, and that must be performed without interruption from the moment of birth. Our hypothesis is that high-level rhythmic signals modulate the phase of low-level rhythmic activity on a cycle-wise basis, and high-level broadband signals regulate both set-point and posture to form coordinated and precise rhythmic behaviors. Guided by our hypothesis, we use and advance the tools of modern neuroscience to add informative labels to individual neurons in the brainstem, place these cells within circuits, connect circuits with motor actions, and coordinate different actions into behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This Japan-US workshop entitled “Making Acute Stroke Trials Succeed: Challenges and Potential Solutions” has two goals: 1) To exchange information about the opportunities and barriers to conduct collaborative stroke clinical trials that are innovative in design, patient- centered, and pragmatic; 2) To explore the use of emergency consent procedures, and other innovative methods to facilitate enrollment in acute stroke trials in Japan and the U.S. The workshop can be viewed as an accelerator of patient-centered global collaborative trials and a facilitator of enrollment using emergency consent procedures in Japan.

PHR: Narrative East ethnically RACING assessment barriers, vertical  Carolina University has a longstanding mission to serve rural eastern North Carolina, a racially and  diverse region with significant health disparities and adverse social determinants of health. This AHEAD project will identify gaps in health disparities research capacity through an institutional needs and develop an action plan for improvement. By leveraging existing strengths, reducing identified and building a supportive infrastructure and transdisciplinary community, the action plan will catalyze a growth in extramural biomedical research funding to advance health equity in our region.

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transition age adults (ages 18-25) with opioid use disorders are poorly served by the current treatment system for substance use disorders. This study will examine the variation in quality of treatment for opioid use disorders for this age cohort and examine multilevel factors—individual, community, treatment program—associated with higher quality care. The findings from this study will inform clinical decision making by patients and providers as well as public health responses to the rising tide of young adults seeking treatment for OUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: RELEVANCE Home visiting programs offer a potentially effective and sustainable framework for delivering interventions to improve cardiovascular health (CVH) among women and children. As part of the “Early Intervention to Promote Cardiovascular Health of Mothers and Children” (ENRICH) program, this project proposes to develop, implement, and evaluate a CVH intervention integrated into home visiting programs throughout Alabama, which has some of the highest cardiovascular disease mortality rates in the country. This study will examine the intervention’s health benefits for mothers and their children (aged 0-4 years) as well as factors associated with the implementation of the program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The NJ ACTS K12 Career Development Program, Doctors as Valued Learning Partners (DEVELOP), prepares early career faculty for independent careers in translational sciences. The program provides mentorship, personalized training, educational opportunities, salary, research, and travel support to prepare Scholars for an independent research career. Scholars will engage in research in translational science grounded in preclinical, clinical, epidemiologic, behavioral, or community-based research methods under the mentorship of teams of highly qualified, committed faculty from the four NJ ACTS partner institutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Equitable TRanslational science to Accelerate Impact of New innovations (E-TRAIN) T32 is proposed as a postdoctoral training program for the Northwestern University Clinical and Translational Sciences (NUCATS) Institute. This 2-year program expands domain expertise through mentored research and develops skills in cross-disciplinary team science to accelerate development, demonstration, and dissemination of new health innovations. Inclusive excellence, equitable and anti-racist study design, and trainee wellness will support human-centered design, dissemination, and implementation. Trainees will be prepared to contribute to the goal of the National Center for Advancing Translational Science of “bringing more treatments to all people more quickly” by reducing clinical and translational science (CTS) barriers.

PROJECT_TITLE: NUCATS T32

PHR: Relevance Synaptic plasticity is integral to development and experience-dependent changes in the brain. While there have been attempts to link synaptic plasticity mechanisms discovered in reduced preparations to in-vivo function such as memory formation, important challenges and questions remain. We are now at the point of being able to address these important questions, but the challenge of integrating molecular mechanisms to behavior remains. Global collaboration between molecular and cellular biologists, technology developers and systems neuroscientists is critically important to connect mechanistic level knowledge of synaptic function to in-vivo behavior.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dilation & curettage (D&C) is one of the most common surgical procedures performed on women throughout the World, with resulting intrauterine fibrosis developing in ~40% of women who undergo D&C in the postpartum (6wk period after birth), but is very rare after D&C in nonpregnant women (<1%). While stem/progenitor cells and macrophage immune cells are crucial for endometrial repair, the role of these cells and underlying molecular mechanisms in this susceptibility of the endometrium to fibrosis and abnormal repair are unknown. This work will have an important impact on the reproductive field by revealing mechanisms underlying abnormal uterine repair, and on the medical field at large by providing insights into the body’s physiological anti-fibrotic wound healing mechanisms, leading to a deeper understanding of the pathogenesis of fatal idiopathic fibrotic diseases in other organs.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRITIVE Preterm labor leads to preterm delivery of an underdeveloped fetus in 50% of cases and there are no FDA- approved medications available to prevent preterm delivery. The research planned in this application will employ tissues and cells from pregnant women. Mariani Ramirez is a diversity applicant whom we will mentor to examine the role of endogenous nitric oxide, which relaxes the muscle of the term, but not preterm human uterus, in regulating the formation of gap junctions that couple the tissue electrically and coordinate labor contractions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With 10 million residents, Los Angeles County is the most populous in the US; three-quarters of residents identify as ethnic minorities and more than one-third were born outside the US; and nearly 1.5 million people are below the poverty line. Rates of premature death and disability related to heart disease, diabetes, stroke and violence exceed national averages; the disease burden is magnified by language barriers, cultural beliefs, poverty and disparities in access to care. The goal of the CTSI is to bring biomedical innovations to bear on the greatest health needs of Los Angeles—one of the nation's most ethnically, socially and economically diverse counties.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE - FROM PARENT AWARD Cognitive impairment following stroke is emerging as one of the leading causes of disability in the country. Despite large research efforts, there are currently no approved pharmacotherapies for improving functional outcomes following stroke. This proposal aims to uncover molecular mechanisms underlying stroke-induced synaptic and cognitive deficits to identify potential molecular targets for pharmacologic intervention.

PHR: Self-destructive behaviors such as self-injury, disordered eating, and substance use are common among Veterans with posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and other trauma or stressor-related disorders and are linked to profound distress and impairment. The proposed study would use advanced computational methods to model [the cognitive, emotional, physiological, and behavioral processes] that maintain suicidal ideation and other self-destructive behaviors at both the group and individual levels in gender-balanced samples of Veterans. Knowledge generated by this research could be used to improve existing trauma-focused treatments and develop personalized, real-time assessment and intervention tools for Veterans who engage in self- destructive behaviors in the context of traumatic stress.

PHR: Alcohol and prescription opioid use disorders and comorbid major depressive disorder (MDD) are costly and prevalent in Veterans and associated with poor clinical outcomes, including an elevated risk of mortality. Despite the urgent need to improve treatment and reduce the burden of these co-occurring disorders on Veterans, the shared genetic vulnerability underlying them is poorly understood. Prior studies are limited by inadequate power to detect small effects, a lack of population diversity, and inadequate associated phenotypic information. This CDA-2 application addresses these limitations by using data from the Million Veteran Program, a longitudinal, electronic health record-based biobank, to investigate the genetic architecture of alcohol and prescription opioid use and comorbid MDD. Findings from this CDA-2 will increase our understanding of the etiology, genetic architecture, associated phenotypes, and causal pathways between these comorbidities and inform precision medicine approaches to these disorders in Veterans.

PHR: Rare cancers comprise over 25% of tumors in U.S. adults, but due to low incidence and geographically dispersed patient populations, they are challenging to study, leading to significant unmet clinical needs. This proposal will form a Research Center that will directly engage patients with two such rare cancers – osteosarcoma and leiomyosarcoma – as partners in research in order to generate a large shared database of clinical, genomic, molecular, and patient reported data. We hope that this work can accelerate discoveries that drive novel treatment strategies, new clinical trials, and new standards of care, and also serve as a model for patient- partnered research in other cancer types and patient communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative:  The substrate specificity of E3 ligases determines which proteins in a cell are targeted for degradation. Changes in substrate specificity can lead to disease (in the case of mutations) or enable potential treatments (in the case of pharmacological agents such as molecular glues). Here we propose novel computational approaches to identify endogenous substrates and to identify molecular glues that will target specific disease- causing proteins.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cognitive impairment begins early in Parkinson’s disease (PD) and progresses to dementia in a majority of patients, impairing quality of life and contributing to growing health-related costs. The proposed study is designed to study exercise and a novel aging-regulator, klotho, that may mediate-exercise induced benefits on cognition. This research has the potential to fill a major gap in identifying novel therapeutic strategies to counter cognitive decline in PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will evaluate disparities in domestic mold exposure and asthma morbidity both before and after a large-scale intervention in New York City public housing to reduce mold, by determining their distributions across climatic, neighborhood, building, and individual characteristics. Such analyses directly support the NIEHS’s commitment to uncovering where exposure burdens combine with social determinants to impact health in an era of climate change. Our findings will inform more equitable mold interventions and housing policies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Increasing physical activity improves quality of life and functional capacity in patients with pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH), a rare disease with a median survival of seven years. We recently demonstrated in a randomized pilot trial the feasibility of increasing step counts in patients with PAH using a text-based mobile health intervention. Accordingly, we now propose a larger, longer-term study to test whether increasing step counts through a mobile health intervention will improve quality of life in patients with PAH.

PHR: Narrative Supply chains for more than 50% of medical devices are threatened by current and new ethylene oxide (EtO) regulations because of the limitations of current EtO control technologies. The proposed research will demonstrate an EtO abatement technology to minimize fugitive EtO emissions from sterilization facilities and warehouses beyond what is achievable with current approaches. The proposed technology addresses a void in current abatement strategies, creating the opportunity to dramatically reduce fugitive EtO emissions, ensure an uninterrupted supply chain of medical devices, and protect workers and communities from harmful EtO exposure.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Reduced EtO emissions to safeguard biomedical supply chains

ORG_NAME: GRADUATE SCHOOL OF PUBLIC HEALTH AND HEALTH POLICY
PHR: Narrative Addressing health disparities, especially in the face of COVID-19, requires an integrated multisector equity-focused, community-based approach. Our proposal examines the impact of Harlem Strong Community Mental Health and Economic Empowerment Collaborative, a community-wide multisectoral coalition in which a health insurer works with a network of community-based organizations, medical providers, and behavioral health provider to engage in a network- wide implementation planning process to: (1) problem solve financing, access, and quality of care barriers, (2) support capacity building for mental health task-sharing for community health workers, (3) facilitate coordination and collaboration across mental health / behavioral health, primary care, and a range of social services, including case management, housing supports, employment and financial education, and other community resources to improve linkages to services, and (4) identify a set of common mental health, social risk, and health metrics and strategies to integrate these metrics into data systems across the network for continuous quality improvement of the system. The long-term goal of our study is to develop sustainable model for task-sharing mental health care that will be embedded in a coordinated comprehensive network of services, including primary care, behavioral/mental health, social services, and other community resources.

PHR: Survivors of childhood cancer in their thirties have exercise capacity that mirrors values found among older adults in the general population. This proposal tests the efficacy of an individually prescribed telehealth-based exercise intervention on exercise capacity in this population. This study has potential to move standard of care (encouraging physical activity) for exercise intolerance from its’ current state, where it is ineffective for most survivors, to a clinically actionable, practical, sustainable, and generalizable intervention.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal leverages a very well characterized and deeply phenotyped cohort of mother-offspring pairs to investigate different biological pathways by which the in utero environment may confer risk of obesity-related conditions in offspring during childhood. It will explore the relevance of metabolic subtypes during pregnancy, as a means to identify nuances in metabolism that are related to maternal fuels implicated in fetal programming (e.g., glucose, insulin, lipids) lifestyle intervention targets (e.g., diet, physical activity), placental signaling, and offspring’s metabolic profile. Findings from this study will improve knowledge of in utero risk stratification, maternal and child metabolic pathways involved in early life cardiometabolic risk and could reveal targets for prevention strategies to interrupt the transgenerational cycle of diabetes and obesity.

PHR: Children with substantial African ancestry have long been known to have half or less the rate of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) than do children with other continental ancestries. We will conduct admixture mapping of ALL risk and outcome in African-American patients. The proposed research will potentially answer a long-standing mystery by revealing critical genes or loci that explain the comparative deficit of B-cell ALL in AA compared to EA children, possibly pointing towards prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Relevance – Loss of bladder or bowel control, generally known as urinary or bowel incontinence, respectively, are conditions with many etiologies that are not only debilitating and embarrassing for the millions affected but are also very costly to the healthcare and workforce sectors. Sacral nerve stimulation (SNS) is an effective, minimally invasive treatment for otherwise intractable cases, or those that do not respond to conservative treatments such as pharmacotherapies. However, placement of the leads that innervate the muscles for the bladder or bowel is a complex, highly precise process in which insufficient response from lead stimulation has suspended implantation in up to 76% of cases in some studies. This Phase I project addresses the shortcomings in imaging and visualization of soft tissues behind bone by developing a guidance tool with a photoacoustic ‘eye in the needle’ approach to better place SNS leads with millimeter-level accuracy adjacent to the nerve, resulting in more successful and reliable treatment for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Narrative The All of Us Research Program aims to collect data from a diverse group of participants in the United States with an overrepresentation of traditionally underrepresented groups. However, there are disparities in disease prevalence compared to the broader U.S. population, limiting the ability of researchers to test hypotheses that could apply to the U.S. population. To improve the generalizability of the data and expand their impact, this proposal aims to develop, assess, and refine synthetic sampling weights for the All of Us Research Program data by leveraging external data resources from the U.S. population.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This project will examine the impact of school-based health centers (SBHCs) in California and Oregon on health care utilization, cost, health outcomes, and education outcomes overall and for members of health disparity populations. By using multiple years of health insurance claims data, survey data, education data, and information on students' access to SBHCs, we will estimate the causal impacts of students' access to SBHCs in a difference-in-difference model which leverages variation in the availability of SBHCs over time and across communities. We will also examine the dimensions on which SBHC impacts vary, including location, services offered, size, and the pandemic to inform the operation of current SBHCs and design of future SBHCs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative  How Origin Recognition Complex (ORC) accurately executes its roles during normal cell cycle and in disease, remains long-standing question in the field. The smallest and most enigmatic of ORC subunits, Orc6 protein, is important for DNA replication in all eukaryotes and also has a function in cytokinesis. Our goal is to define the distinct mechanisms of metazoan Orc6 functions using Drosophila as a model system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: NATHAN S. KLINE INSTITUTE FOR PSYCH RES
PHR: Project Narrative: Fetal alcohol spectrum disorder (FASD) is a significant non-genetic neurodevelopmental disability in which affected individuals display cognitive and social abnormalities. The studies herein examine the cell-type-specific cannabinoid receptor-epigenetic mechanism by which postnatal ethanol exposure causes cognitive and social- behavioral defects. The findings will address our knowledge gap in understanding cell-type-specific CB1 mediated epigenetic mechanisms and inform us why the developmental brain is, therefore, vulnerable to alcohol's damaging effects. Moreover, the findings of the proposed studies may be used by health care professionals in counseling women on the potential adverse impacts of alcohol abuse during pregnancy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Inherited mutations in telomere maintenance genes can cause life threatening diseases including bone marrow failure, liver cirrhosis, and pulmonary fibrosis, which have limited therapeutic options. Using human population genetic data and high throughput genetic screening, we identified a novel connection between nucleotide metabolism and human telomere homeostasis. This proposal aims to uncover the mechanisms underlying this connection, with implications for the treatment of telomere biology disorders and potentially other degenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed research is of high significance because it defines the functional mechanism of a major sphingosine-1-phosphate (S1P) transporter Spns2, a bioactive lipid important to regulating the growth, survival and migration of mammalian cells with profound proangiogenic effects. The project is relevant to public health because it will lay the foundation for the development of new therapeutic strategies for diseases associated with S1P signaling and to target Spns2 as a potential immunosuppressant. An innovative aspect of this proposal is the application of a suite of integrated biophysical methods to characterize the transport and regulatory mechanisms of Spns transporters.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer clinical trials require clinician investigators to develop trials and monitor their progress, review safety data, and respond to human subjects concerns. This Research Specialist award application seeks funding for an accomplished clinical trialist at the Medical College of Wisconsin (MCW) to partially support their effort devoted to National Cancer Institute-funded clinical trials research in the Cancer Center. Such support will facilitate further increasing the quality and number of trials at the applicant’s institution by supporting the Clinician Scientist’s contributions to developing national trials, implementing NCI trials at MCW, and performing service to the NCI clinical trials networks.

PHR: Project Narrative Individuals who use alcohol and marijuana simultaneously are at increased risk for developing substance use disorders. The proposed project aims to understand how simultaneous use leads to increased risk for negative outcomes by examining the brain’s response to stress cues, neuroendocrine responses to stress cues, and relationships between stress, craving, and drug use in the real world. By elucidating brain and behavioral mechanisms, it may be possible to identify treatments to prevent or reduce the negative consequences of simultaneous use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Patients who survive an acute critical illness including sepsis, COVID-19, influenza and acute respiratory distress syndrome often develop physical disability that can persist for years after hospital discharge. The planned proposal will determine cellular and clinical parameters responsible for the reduced or inability to recover muscle and physical function after critical illness. The findings of this study will inform the development of future therapeutic interventions that mitigate long-term impairments and stimulate muscle and physical recovery after critical illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative It is estimated that 10-25% of human embryos have the wrong number of chromosomes, resulting in a high incidence of miscarriages and birth defects. Most of these abnormalities are the result of mistakes generated when female reproductive cells (oocytes) divide, yet surprisingly little is known about the mechanisms that underlie the vulnerability of oocytes to these errors. This project seeks to gain insight into this important question, focusing on how a structure called the spindle mediates the alignment and segregation of chromosomes during cell division.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In 2021, it is estimated that there will be approximately 61,000 new cases with 23,660 deaths occurring from leukemia. The goal of this project is to reduce the impact of leukemia by supporting clinician-scientists conducting clinical trials sponsored by the National Cancer Institute at Washington University School of Medicine / Siteman Cancer Center and nationally. These trials will test novel therapies and prioritize a precision medicine approach where molecular testing is used to select patients who may most benefit from treatments targeting specific genetic abnormalities present in their leukemia.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE) Through existing and innovative partnerships and clinical trial networks, this proposal will provide improved access to NCI clinical trials to patients at the Masonic Cancer Center of the University of Minnesota, the Minneapolis/St Paul metropolitan area and, ultimately, to greater Minnesota. In addition, the support of the proposed Research Specialist, Britt Erickson, MD, will lead to enhanced development of national clinical trials specific to endometrial cancer, a leading and rising cause of death from gynecologic malignancies in the US. Knowledge gained from these clinical trials will lessen the burden of cancer and improve existing disparities in cancer treatment outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Obesity is fundamentally a disorder of energy balance that occurs when energy intake exceeds energy expenditure, resulting in increased energy storage in the form of triglyceride within white adipose tissue. This proposal aims to discover the molecular mechanisms by which energy-storing white adipocytes suppress their natural energy-burning potential. Understanding these mechanisms may lead to therapeutic strategies to unlock the energy-burning capacity of adipose tissue to promote weight loss and/or improve nutrient homeostasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Each year, millions of people are harmed or killed by viruses that spill over from wild or domestic animal reservoirs, and in some cases these spillovers result in devastating pandemics. One new avenue for suppressing these animal pathogens is to develop self-disseminating animal vaccines that block the viruses at their source and prevent them from spilling over into the human population. This project uses a combination of mathematical models and laboratory studies to develop a framework for designing self-disseminating vaccines and optimizing their performance.

PHR: We propose to conduct a randomized controlled trial to test two different financial incentive programs (versus control) to promote physical activity among 330 low-active adults. One incentive program will replicate a program currently used by three major health insurance programs in the absence of empirical support: Participants will have the opportunity to earn a refund of $200 for attending at least 50 sessions over 6 months. The other incentive program will have the same incentive schedule, but will use a “loss-frame”, such that participants are told that $200 of their membership fee is being held and will be returned or forfeited depending on whether they use the gym at least 50 times in the next 6 months.

ORG_NAME: VETERANS AFFAIRS MED CTR SAN FRANCISCO
PHR: The clinical and economic costs of mental illness are significant within the VA. For example, ~4% of veterans suffer from schizophrenia, ~8-31% suffer from PTSD, and ~7-18% suffer from a substance use disorder. Currently available treatments for these disorders are insufficiently effective, are often costly, time-consuming, and associated with significant side-effects, and frequently have poor uptake and adherence. Most mental illnesses are associated with social deficits that lead to social isolation and loneliness, which in turn lead to worse mental and physical outcomes including suicide, despair, and early mortality. Using a multidisciplinary and multi-pronged transdiagnostic approach, my lab is focused on understanding and treating the pathological psychological, neural, and behavioral mechanisms of these social deficits. We hope that by targeting these deficits with novel pharmacological and non-pharmacological interventions, we can revolutionize mental illness treatment within the VA, leading to better clinical outcomes and decreased health care costs.

ORG_NAME: VA GREATER LOS ANGELES HEALTHCARE SYSTEM
PHR: Schizophrenia is a severe mental illness with major public health consequences for Veterans. Treatment of Veterans with schizophrenia in the VA health system accounts for a disproportionately large amount of the VA’s total health care budget (16-20%). Schizophrenia is the most expensive per patient psychiatric condition within the VA, with the majority of affected Veterans receiving some level of service connection. Pharmacological advances have helped to alleviate acute psychotic symptoms, such as hallucinations and delusions. However, current interventions are not sufficient to improve recovery and adaptive functioning, particularly in the social domain. The proposed study aims to systematically evaluate components of social motivation and their respective stages of processing to assess their influence on real-world social functioning. This knowledge can inform novel interventions that target the specific aspects of social motivation that are most disrupted in Veterans with schizophrenia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed Research Evaluating Vagal Excitation and Anatomical Linkages (REVEAL) center aims to conduct groundbreaking research on the effect of vagal nerve stimulation (VNS) on four key autonomic systems: the autonomic nervous system, the cardiovascular system, the immune system, and metabolic system. This research will produce a first-in-the-world dataset that will be foundational for the development of VNS-based therapies for several maladies related to autonomic systems.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Race-related traumatic online experiences have become daily stressors in the lives of adolescents of color, yet media literacy programs fail to help young people manage these challenges. We propose to address this need with the design, development, and evaluation of an immersive virtual reality (VR), media literacy, and coping skills intervention. Guided by a media literacy as health promotion and prevention framework and culturally responsive computing theory, the VR intervention will build on Black and Latinx adolescents’ strengths and provide immersive practice to enhance the learning of coping skills and racial coping self-efficacy for dealing with negative race-related digital media.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is directly relevant to public health because it will reveal key developmentally-regulated neural circuit mechanisms that render the maturation of the prefrontal cortex vulnerable to the detrimental impact of cannabis during adolescence. This goal is directly aligned with the NIDA agenda by delineating a developmental framework in which substance use disorders-associated behavioral deficits can be understood, specifically those arising during the adolescent transition to adulthood. This knowledge is expected to fully serve NIH-NIDA mission by devising timing-sensitive intervention strategies to prevent or mitigate the onset of substance use/abuse during critical periods.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The two largest primary risk factors for late onset Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) are aging and APOE4 genotype. This project tests the efficacy of the longevity promoting intervention, 17α-estradiol, on aging- associated APOE4 phenotypes and AD development. This study is crucial to understand how geroscience and longevity-promoting interventions can be used to alleviate APOE4-associated risk for AD progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Computer-based modeling, simulation, and visualization of molecular systems have evolved as indispensable tools for modern science and medicine. Over the past three decades, the NIH Resource at Illinois has provided some of the most advanced and widely used (currently with more than 125,000 users) software packages that make computational tools and algorithms for molecular and cell modeling readily and freely available to the biomedical community. Beyond developing computational technology driven by the needs of its very large user base, the Resource is engaged in training activities supported by an unparalleled number of fully online and heavily used set of tutorials, case studies, workshops, and a heavily visited web site.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of this project is to develop a series of techniques to profile post-translational modification (PTM)- based regulation of protein function. In particular, we intend to measure PTM-mediated alterations in protein higher-order conformation. This is related to human health as the dysregulation of these processes is highly correlated with disease and detailed knowledge of these conformations can inform drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed work seeks to characterize the metabolic footprint of commensal Clostridia and investigate how this contributes to their microbial assembly in the gut. Completion of the proposed work provides fundamental knowledge about prevalent yet under-characterized human gut commensals and their role in human health and disease, all of which advance our ability to manipulate the gut microbiota for our benefit.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Intracortical brain-computer interfaces (iBCIs) have been used to restore movement to humans with spinal cord injury, but users have control only of the motion of the arm and hand, not its stiffness, nor forces applied to grasped objects. We propose to circumvent this fundamental limitation by developing an iBCI for humans that effects movement by predicting patterns of muscle activity, used as inputs to a musculoskeletal model of the hand. We have proposed to develop the system initially in virtual reality, then test it with a robotic limb; it could also be used to reanimate a person's own paralyzed limb through functional electrical stimulation of muscles or nerves.

PHR: Project Narrative  Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common form of dementia diagnosed through the presence of brain amyloid beta (Aβ) plaques, generated from amyloid precursor protein (APP). APP and Aβ localize to mitochondria and mitochondrial associated membranes (MAMs). We will test the hypothesis that the cellular localization of APP at mitochondria and MAMs dictates Aβ production.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Deep proteomic and metabolomic profiling of biological tissues is an overarching goal of modern biological and biomedical research, but it remains a key – and conspicuous – missing component from the spectrum of -omics, specifically genomics and transcriptomics, which capitalize on next-generation sequencing of DNA and RNA. The proposed effort will meet this challenge by advancing revolutionary new methods for label-free single- molecule proteomic and metabolomic profiling, combining them with novel methods for sub-cellular spatial analysis. Its achievement will complete the constellation of single-cell -omics, thereby broadly advancing research worldwide in fields that span from fundamental biology to the frontiers of clinical medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sjögren’s syndrome, an autoimmune disease characterized by uncontrolled inflammation, impairs saliva production and leads to severe and chronic dryness in the oral cavity. We propose to determine the role of tuft cells, a type of cell that has been found to be important for proper immune functioning in other organs, for the proper immune functioning of salivary glands in healthy patients and those with Sjögren’s syndrome. These studies are expected to introduce a new area of investigation to salivary gland research and potentially lead to novel treatment options.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Women who experience gestational diabetes are at high risk of developing type 2 diabetes mellitus in the postpartum period – especially in low- and middle-income countries like India where the burden of diabetes is high and disproportionately affects women – but few receive the World Health Organization-recommended postpartum diabetes screening. We propose a hybrid type II effectiveness-implementation cluster randomized trial, guided by the CFIR Framework, to determine whether community health workers can improve postpartum diabetes screening in the urban slums of Pune, India, through home-based testing or clinic-based referral with regular reminders. The proposed study seeks to provide an acceptable and scalable model to improve postpartum diabetes screening in other low-income settings, thereby improving early detection of diabetes in women and preventing morbidity and mortality in this high-risk population.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly 70% of patients with metastatic bladder cancer die of their disease despite current treatment with chemotherapy or immunotherapy, making the discovery of novel therapeutics an urgent imperative. We showed that mutations in the promoter of TElomerase Reverse Transcriptase (TERT), a protein which maintains telomere length and cellular immortality, occur in nearly 70% of bladder cancers and drive high TERT expression which contributes to tumor growth and poor patient prognosis. Here, we use an innovative platform for High-Throughput Screening (HTS) of small molecules that reduce TERT expression specifically from mutant TERT promoters in bladder cancer cells, with the overall objective of developing novel cancer cell specific therapeutics for bladder and other TERT driven malignancies.

PHR: Kappa opioid receptor (KOR) agonists have analgesic and anti-pruritic effects while KOR antagonists are potentially useful as anti-anxiety and antidepressant agents and for drug abuse treatment. The paraventricular nucleus of the thalamus (PVT), part of the brain anxiety network, expresses a high level of KOR and we propose to characterize these KOR-expressing PVT neurons in terms of afferent and efferent projections and functional significance in KOR- mediated behaviors. The proposed studies will enhance our understanding of KOR functional neuroanatomy and KOR-mediated anxiety, stress responses, aversion and other psychopathology with the hope that the results provide the basis for developing KOR antagonists as anti-anxiety agents.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Almost two-thirds of breast cancers are the hormone-receptor positive subtype which are treated with adjuvant endocrine therapy (AET), yet up to 50% of patients do not take these medications as prescribed resulting with increased rates of breast cancer recurrence and death. Adherence to AET is lower among Black breast cancer survivors and this new mHealth, intervention will address a major barrier to AET adherence, symptoms from AET, in a tailored fashion to Black breast cancer survivors. This intervention has great promise for reducing cancer-related symptoms burden which negatively impact quality of life, reducing disparities in care, and potentially improving cancer outcomes among Black breast cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic pain is a highly prevalent disorder that results in significant disability for both adults and children. Chronic pain remains difficult to diagnose and treat because we do not understand how components of the nervous system work together to build an experience of pain. The fundamental knowledge gained in this project will provide the foundation for better diagnosis and effective treatments for chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: COLLEGE OF MEDICINE, UNIVERSITY OF IBADAN
PHR: NARRATIVE Brain health, which determines brain capital, is central to achieving overall health and all sustainable development goals. However, the current DS-I Africa programs do not have a dedicated training program in brain health research to unravel its determinants, especially sociodemographic and lifestyle factors which play a major role elsewhere. GRASP is aimed at developing a sustainable cohort of African scientists to tackle the brain health burden in Africa by improving the data science skill of selected scholars to unravel its determinants using available large integrated datasets within DSI-A network. 1

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intervention INC: An interactive family-centered mHealth tool to reduce obesity risk in urban minority preadolescents study will test the effectiveness of the adapted tool on child BMI z-score, with a full-scale randomized controlled trial. Critical preliminary data will also be collected on perceptions of the intervention at the organizational and family levels and characteristics of recipients (clinic staff, children, and parents), as well as the contextual factors that influence the tool’s implementation in a health care setting. This study has strong public health relevance as not only does the tool use innovative communication approaches to deliver complex health messages in a simple and meaningful way to engage an often hard to reach population, but the data collected will ultimately inform the more efficient and effective delivery and use of culturally relevant health care resources for a diverse, at-risk population.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Intervention INC: An interactive family-centered mHealth tool to reduce obesity risk in urban minority preadolescents

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: OVERALL We propose the creation of the USC Center for Optimization of Participant Engagement in Cancer Characterization (COPECC) with a focus on optimizing the engagement of Hispanic/Latinos in colorectal cancer (CRC) Genomic Characterization research studies, as part of the NCI U2C Participant Engagement and Cancer Genome Sequencing national network. The overall goal of USC COPECC is to generate results on participant engagement optimization and translational CRC genomic research that will be shared with the broader community to promote best practices for engaging Hispanic/Latino and improving overall outcomes for CRC in this underserved population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lytic cell death is a self-protection mechanism against pathogen infection or even cancer, but its dysregulation also results in various inflammatory diseases and tissue injuries. Plasma membrane rupture is the cataclysmic step in lytic cell death that further propagates the inflammatory responses. NINJ1 is a newly identified protein to be responsible for carrying out plasma membrane rupture, but its working mechanism is not clear. Glycine is a widely used additive in various ex vivo organ preservation solutions during organ transplantation for its cytoprotection effect. Glycine cytoprotection is recently demonstrated to be a result of inhibiting plasma membrane rupture. Our proposed studies aim to understand the structural basis of NINJ1-mediated plasma membrane rupture and its inhibition by glycine treatment. This research will have the potential of identifying novel therapeutic targets for various inflammatory diseases and informing the development of better cell preservation strategies or agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Type IV pili (T4P) are bacterial appendages that are critical for behaviors including DNA uptake during natural transformation, biofilm formation, twitching motility, protein secretion, and virulence. Using several model organisms with emphasis on Acinetobacter species, we will characterize the fundamental mechanisms driving T4P dynamics, regulation, and function. This work will lay the groundwork for developing new methods to control or hinder T4P and the broad behaviors they elicit in diverse bacterial pathogens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In preclinical studies, we demonstrate the efficacy of an IL-23 blocking strategy to improve alcohol-related liver damage. Here, we will clinically translate these findings by first testing the safety and tolerability of guselkumab, an FDA-approved anti-IL-23 antibody, in patients with alcohol-associated liver disease. We will also assess biomarkers for guselkumab target engagement as well as early biomarkers of treatment response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Brain injury directly suppresses the immune system through release of soluble factors that disrupt thymic homeostasis and dampens responses of the peripheral immune system long term. The nervous system is also connected to the thymus though neuronal connections. In this proposal, we will determine the exact mechanisms of immunosuppression during neurological injuries and elucidate the contribution of innervation and soluble factors to the overall immune state with the hope to reverse this immunosuppression and help patients with neurological diseases.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Center for Coordination of Analysis, Science, Enhancement, and Logistics (CASEL) in Tobacco Regulatory Science (TRS), serving as a central hub for the TRS research community, is a critical mechanism for providing the U.S. Food and Drug Administration's Center for Tobacco Products with the timely and targeted information it needs to carry out its regulatory activities. CASEL will contribute to this objective by providing scientific and logistical leadership and coordination; facilitating collaboration; providing expertise in measurement and analytic methods; strengthening the development of TRS careers; and playing a central and key role in dissemination of TRS research findings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic pain is associated with substantial suffering and other co-morbidities such as depression, insomnia, fatigue, lowered mobility, and worse quality-of-life. Most of the care of chronic pain patients occurs during hurried primary care visits with pharmacological treatments (e.g. opioids and medications) despite mixed evidence of efficacy and increased risk of potentially dangerous side effects, including addiction and death. Even when these treatments are effective in reducing pain, they may not improve mental and functional status. The need for easy access to evidence-based non-pharmacological treatment options that include patient information and skill building would be helpful to chronic pain patients. To address this need for non-pharmacological approaches to treating chronic pain, we propose developing the GEMINI platform to facilitate the delivery of online Integrative Medical Group Visits (IMGV) via video conferencing with evidence-based home practice and self-management tools covering such topics as mindfulness, mind-body practices, self-management of chronic pain, stress reduction, sleep, and nutrition. We hypothesize that the use of the GEMINI intervention would result in reduced pain impact, better pain-related patient outcomes, improved self-efficacy in pain management, and reduced pain medication use.

PHR: Project Narrative – Overall Center There continues to be an urgent need for antiparkinsonian treatments that are more effective and have fewer side effects than those currently available. To address this need, the animal and human research of the proposed Center will focus on generating a more detailed understanding of the pathophysiology of Parkinson's disease, especially the poorly understood abnormalities of cortical activity in the parkinsonian state, and on using this knowledge to develop or optimize therapeutic approaches to Parkinson's disease. Apart from conducting highly collaborative and innovative research on Parkinson's disease, the Center will also train young investigators, and educate the public about Parkinson's disease research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Recent advances in biotechnology and computing are unlocking complex model systems including single-cell morphological profiling and large-scale virtual screening for pharmacology discovery. To get the most out of these complex model systems, my group develops machine learning and statistical methods to infer the causal mechanisms. Two projects that embody this work include modeling how spatial factors explain and confound cellular morphology and mapping bioactive chemical space to guide adaptive virtual screening.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Overall) The overall goal of the UMN Udall Center is to define the changes in brain circuitry that underlie motor and cognitive dysfunction in Parkinson’s disease and use this information to improve current and develop new deep brain stimulation therapeutic approaches. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative TBCK-encephaloneuronopathy is a recently described genetic disorder that causes intellectual disability, seizures, and weakness in children across the world. Most of the children affected to date are Puerto Rican and suffer progressive neurodegeneration that leads to premature death. Elucidating how the loss of the TBCK protein leads to neurodegeneration- particularly by examining the novel concept that RNA transport defects preferentially impair axonal mitochondria- may provide insight into the mechanisms underlying neurodegeneration regardless of age, and may help develop new therapies for this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The product of this research will immediately provide new, critical, and fundamental knowledge on the relative importance of mitochondrial fission adapter proteins for synaptic function. Furhter, this project will elucidate the reasons why dysfunction in the mitochondrial fission protein DRP1 is more severe than loss of mitochondrial fission adapters: we posit that DRP1 facilitates synaptic vesicle biogenesis, independent of its function in mitochondrial fission. Pursuit of this knowledge is important, as DRP1 has been identified as a therapeutic target to alleviate core causes of aging and neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s Disease. The motivations for this project are to increase our basic science knowledge of synaptic function in the brain, and also enhance healthspan in populations increasingly subject to age-related neurological diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite opioid use after surgery, many patients still suffer from uncontrolled pain, and postoperative opioid use is associated with short- and long-term harmful outcomes. In this multi-site, 2x2 factorial, double-blind, randomized controlled trial, participants will receive one of four combinations of placebo or cannabidiol (CBD) for one week prior to surgery together with CBD or placebo for 4 weeks following surgery. This study will be the largest and most rigorous trial to assess whether perioperative CBD reduces opioid consumption after surgery, as well as pain, anxiety, sleep disturbance, and inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Asthma among individuals who are overweight or obese tends to be more severe, possibly because of increased inflammation, insulin resistance, and elevated blood sugar. This project is piloting the use of metformin, a well-tolerated oral medication that treats these conditions, among individuals with elevated body mass index and asthma. This will allow us to determine if a major trial investigating the effect of metformin among patients with obesity-associated asthma is feasible and justified, which if successful, would represent a new treatment option to the millions of Americans with asthma and elevated body weight.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The proposed research is aimed to determine whether insufficient energy production caused by an impairment of the Krebs cycle plays a role in methamphetamine use disorder. The project is relevant to the public health because there is no FDA-approved medication for methamphetamine use disorder while illicit use of methamphetamine and deaths from methamphetamine overdose are rising in the United States. Upon successful completion of the project, we will know whether a loss of function by three Krebs cycle enzymes leads to a deficit in neuronal energy in experimental rats with methamphetamine use disorder and whether upregulation of neuroprotective protein parkin can prevent relapse to methamphetamine use.
