IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Long-term cerebrospinal fluid dynamics in patients with shunted hydrocephalus during sleep and while performing activities of daily living (ADL) are clinically and scientifically important to identify and diagnose shunt failure, identify underlying causes, and evaluate the success of surgical revision procedures. However, they remain largely unknown owing to a lack of a direct monitoring technology to noninvasively measure flow through shunts, especially through periods of sleep. In this proposal, Rhaeos will undertake quality-controlled product development (UG3 phase) of the first sensor capable of continuous flow measurements over extended periods (~1 week) in remote monitoring settings, followed by a n = 20 patient NSR-feasibility study (UH3 phase) to evaluate device performance and safety.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This application requests support to establish a new postbaccalaureate training program, the University of Oregon Program to Increase Resilience and Enhance Persistence in Biomedical Sciences (UO PREP Bio), to increase the number of students from underrepresented, underserved, and historically excluded within the biomedical sciences both within UO and nationwide. By offering intentional community building activities, individualized mentorship, engaging research experiences, and academic and professional development, UO PREP Bio aims to prepare students to be 1) competitive applicants for top biomedical PhD programs and 2) to succeed in a rigorous graduate training program, thereby increasing long-term retention and success of these scholars from underrepresented backgrounds. UO PREP Bio will empower students to achieve their academic and professional goals by using a multifaceted, mentored educational framework that allows students to build and develop core competencies in experimental knowledge and inquiry, professional skills, and scientific identity.

PHR: Project Narrative This Liquid Biopsy Research Laboratory (LBRL) partnership team, led by PI Peter Kuhn (academic) and Co-I Rick Wenstrup (industry) of Epic Sciences, is advancing biologically informed liquid biopsy (LBx) technology to fill gaps in current clinical practice of early cancer assessment. The three scenarios addressed by the LBx are 1) peripheral blood LBx as a companion to mammography for the early assessment of breast cancer, 2) enhanced screening and diagnostic workup for pancreatic cancer through multi-omic capabilities to create a multi-modal LBx using peripheral blood and portal vein blood, and 3) a peripheral blood LBx as a substitute to bone marrow aspirate to diagnose myeloma precursor states and detect the transition to multiple myeloma to easily identify candidates for early treatment intervention.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To effectively treat Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) in the future, it will be essential to diagnose it early, before massive loss of brain cells occurs. The retina, as an outgrowth of the brain, shows promise as a site for non- invasive and inexpensive detection of early AD pathological processes, providing a novel screening tool for at- risk populations. This proposal will provide a deep understanding of AD pathogenesis in the retina and the relationship to brain pathology, potentially identifying new therapeutic and diagnostic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative In most rural areas of India, intervention for children with cleft lip and palate ends post-primary surgery and patients and their families accept poor speech outcomes as a consequence of the disorder. This is unfortunate as, many times, these speech problems are correctable via secondary surgery or speech therapy; however, the resources and professionals who provide these interventions are clustered in urban areas and those in rural regions are unaware that additional treatment is possible. We address this gap by developing an AI-based mHealth app to determine if a child with CLP would benefit from additional treatment to improve communication outcomes and to connect them with cleft-care teams in urban areas.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding how the brain processes incoming inflammatory signals during inflammation and arthritis and the degree to which it regulates the onset and progression of tissue damage is expected to guide the development of new types of treatments and diagnostics for inflammation by specifically targeting functional brain networks. Thus, the proposed work is pursuant to the NIH’s mission fostering basic, novel and creative discoveries and innovative research strategies in order to ultimately enhance health. 1

PHR: NARRATIVE Wnts are evolutionarily conserved ligands that signal at short range to regulate morphogenesis, cell fate and stem cell renewal. This application will provide a molecular understanding of the how Wnts are secreted from the endoplasmic reticulum to the cell surface by binding their dedicated transporter protein WLS. We have determined the atomic resolution structure of Wnt in complex with WLS, using cutting-edge single-particle cryo-electron microscopy and we propose to contribute additional structures as well as employ a range of biochemical and cell-based experiments to study how Wnts bind to WLS, are transported, and dissociate from WLS to reach their target cells for signaling.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: UMN CTSI UM1 Project Narrative The University of Minnesota's Clinical and Translational Science Institute, together with its Partners and Collaborators, will find better, faster ways to bring scientific advances to real-world use. To do this, we will reduce research barriers, provide high-quality services for researchers, foster and train a diverse research workforce, broadly share findings, build sustainable relationships with our Minnesota communities, and more. This work, combined with our focus on health equity and impact, ultimately aims to make healthcare better for everyone.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Chronic alcohol exposure leads to changes in RNA splicing process that can alter gene expression and contribute to negative affective states during alcohol withdrawal. The expression of the splicing factor PCBP1 is increased in the hippocampus of rats during withdrawal from chronic alcohol exposure and humans diagnosed with AUD. The proposed studies will focus on PCBP1 to elucidate mechanisms underlying alcohol-induced changes in RNA splicing and its relevance for negative affective states during withdrawal.

PHR: NARRATIVE Carbon-ion radiation therapy (CIRT) has the potential to improve survival of adult patients with radioresistant brain tumors due to its physical dose distributions and its high linear-energy transfer, making it possible to treat brain cancer using less radiation dose than x rays or protons. However, for younger pediatric patients undergoing critical stages of brain development, the question shifts: what are the risks of functional neurotoxic and other late side effects? This critical and unanswered question is addressed by systematically quantifying the 1) RBE for CIRT-mediated normal-tissue toxicity in a rodent model of pediatric brain and 2) efficacy for CIRT in a preclinical rodent model of pediatric glioma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epidemiological evidence shows that women are more prone to developing posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and have more detrimental health complications from using alcohol compared to men. While many studies have sought to understand alterations in threat neurocircuitry that define PTSD, few studies have examined the human reward neurocircuitry that underlies the development of these co-occurring disorders in women. In this proposal, utilizing ecological momentary assessment and functional neuroimaging techniques, I will determine the differences in the underlying reward neurocircuitry that promote alcohol use in trauma-exposed women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because of the enormous burden of disease resulting from traumatic brain injury (TBI) with over 2 million individuals suffering from TBI each year. TBI is a leading cause of death and disability, and currently, there are no specific therapies. Determining the mechanisms by which type I interferon activated microglial impact TBI may identify a novel therapeutic target for this devastating disease.

PHR: Project Narrative Innovative and socially scalable approaches are urgently needed to prevent Early Childhood Caries (ECC). We seek to develop a first-of-its-kind interactive mobile dental app that will provide age appropriate oral health related anticipatory guidance to parents/caregivers by sending out motivational alerts tailored to infant's age and stage of development addressing specific changes in oral health. The proposed approach is prevention focused and thereby highly rewarding and cost-effective compared to the traditional invasive strategies that target the burden of ECC in low- and middle- income countries.

PHR: B. PROJECT NARRATIVE This project studies the cancer genetics of human acute myelogenous leukemia. The overarching goal of this proposal is to delineate genetic and genomic contributors that are currently missing in clinical risk stratification tools and in the growing landscape of potential druggable and disease-modifying targets. Our results will inform the needed complexity of clinical genetic testing panels, inclusive genetic risk assessment tools and identify exemplars of thus-far unrecognized leukemic drivers.

PHR: Young people with HIV in Zambia often have difficulty taking medication as prescribed, miss medical appointments, and drink excessive alcohol and use other drugs. This project will develop and implement a multi-component, mHealth intervention designed to improve HIV self-management and reduce substance use. If successful, this intervention can improve the health of those affected by HIV/AIDS and reduce future rates of HIV infection in Zambia.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Early attention and behavior problems predict a wide range of psychological disorders yet little is known about how these problems emerge very early in development. We will study prenatal and early developmental origins of sleep problems to predict emergence of attention and behavior problems in the first year of life. This will provide valuable clinical information about how to intervene to prevent the emergence of early attention and behavior disorders and improve infant and caregiver sleep.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative This project would provide the first nationally representative estimates of Americans’ experiences with and concerns about diagnostic safety in outpatient settings. Deploying a set of innovative survey methods, data about patient experiences will be collected from 3,300 households to generate a more inclusive, complete and balanced portrait of the contemporary state of diagnostic safety in American healthcare. Using this data, the project team will then assess the impact of health system fragmentation on the prevalence and consequences of diagnostic mishaps, leveraging these results to predict potential benefits from addressing three aspects of fragmentation to improve diagnostic safety and equity in the future.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Patient-Reported Diagnostic Safety Events in Ambulatory Care Settings: A National Survey of Systemic Influences, Disparities and Persisting Consequences

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because 1) we will identify clinically relevant biomarkers that are involved in JNK’s immunological regulation of the tumor microenvironment (TME) in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) and that reflect the immunosuppressive status of the TNBC TME, and 2) we will develop an optimal effective JNK inhibitor-based immunotherapy for patients with TNBC. The long-term goal of the proposed project is to improve the survival of TNBC patients by developing a novel combination of immunochemotherapy with a JNK inhibitor that induces a TME favorable for enhancing the antitumor efficacy of immunochemotherapy. Therefore, this work is relevant to the NCI’s mission “to support cancer research across the nation to advance scientific knowledge and help all people live longer, healthier lives.”

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE  Patients with alcohol-associated liver disease (ALD) can develop severe alcoholic hepatitis (AH), carrying a very poor prognosis. Hepatic lymphatics are thought to reduce the inflammatory response by discharging excess fluids and inflammatory mediators from the liver to lymph nodes, and thus may help to ameliorate AH. The goal of this proposed study is to explore the potential of enhancing liver lymphatic drainage as a novel therapeutic strategy for AH.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People with opioid use disorder are trapped in a deadly cycle wherein opioid use leads to social isolation, and social isolation leads to increased risk of continued opioid use and overdose. Disclosure can reduce social isolation and help people (re-)establish social connection as they enter and engage in treatment; however, many people in recovery from opioid use disorder struggle with disclosure decisions and processes. We propose to test whether a disclosure intervention designed to help people receiving treatment for opioid use disorder make disclosure decisions and build disclosure skills leads to improved treatment- and recovery-related outcomes.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Understanding the molecular processes by which the cervix undergoes a remarkable remodeling through pregnancy from closed and rigid to compliant for safe delivery is critical for defining causes of premature remodeling in preterm birth and for the identification of biomarkers to assess risk of prematurity as well as therapies for prevention. The purpose of this study is to understand how synthesis, assembly, and degradation of cervical collagen and elastic fibers is altered during pregnancy to impact mechanical function and regulated by steroid hormones in clinically relevant animal models. The knowledge gained from these studies has the potential to (1) identify clinically-relevant pathways that can be targeted for prevention of preterm birth and (2) identify new mechanical parameters to diagnose cervical dysfunction associated with preterm birth.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative This project proposes a framework for mitigating the emergency department (ED) overcrowding problem. The project is relevant to public health as it improves patient flow in EDs and consequently reduces waiting times and ED boarding time and increases bed utilization and ED throughput. Improving such outcomes should reduce the likelihood of medical errors, enhance patient safety, and increase patient satisfaction.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Building and Implementing a predictive decision support system based on a proactive full capacity protocol to mitigate emergency overcrowding problem

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE The Southwest Transformative Educational Advancement and Mentoring network brings together four Minority Serving Institutions across the US Southwest: University of New Mexico, New Mexico State University, Northern Arizona University, and Burrell College of Osteopathic Medicine to train the next generation of scientists in cancer and cancer health disparities. This network aims to foster the development of underrepresented and diverse scientists and investigators and strengthen the career pipeline for pre- and post-doctoral trainees and Early Stage Investigators. This proposed network will enhance the capacity of the scientific workforce to address cancer and cancer health disparities experienced by diverse populations in the Southwest United States.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose a paradigm shift in cancer therapy: ChemoFilter, an endovascular catheter-based medical device that will be inserted under image guidance into the veins of the body to directly filter specific chemotherapy drugs out of the blood stream after these drugs have had their effect on a tumor but before they have caused systemic toxic effects. ChemoFilter would help patients fight cancer by minimizing drug toxicity, allowing for high-dose therapy to better treat their disease and improve survival. Patients suffering from primary and oligometastatic liver cancers are the first targets for this device.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The threat posed by Gram-negative bacteria is significant and growing due to the spread of antibiotic resistance. Infection by these pathogens is often mediated by virulence factors known as autotransporter proteins. This project will determine the atomic-level details of autotransporter folding and expression, thus providing a basis for novel antibacterial interventions.

PHR: NARRATIVE: OVERALL: Mapping the Cancer Complex System from Clinical MR Imaging of GBM The aim of our Mayo/Columbia CSBC Mathematical Oncology Systems Analysis Imaging Center (MOSAIC) is to build a conceptual framework to understand sex-specific glioma tissue state transitions and dynamics and the ways to interpret MRI relative to those changes MOSAIC leverages a large and growing core unique resource of radiographically-localized biopsies in glioma patients. In two projects, we will employ quantitative systems biology to quantify the dynamic glioma tissue state ecosystem and connections to routine clinical imaging. This will allow us to better understand glioma tissue states, their cellular cross-talk and how individual patients’ tissue state landscape will respond to therapy to ultimately drive new clinical trials that improve patient outcomes.

PHR: NARRATIVE: ADMINISTRATIVE CORE The Administrative Core will be the primary touchpoint of the center, facilitating interactions between the two projects and three additional cores. The Administrative Core will also actively cultivate collaborations throughout the consortium with assistance from the Outreach Core, particularly through administering Intra-Center and Cross-Consortium Pilot Projects, hosting workshops and symposiums, and facilitating visiting faculty all while enhancing diverse perspectives on this critical topic. Co-PDs Swanson and Canoll will provide the central leadership in the Administrative Core, while the Center Program Administrator will provide day-to-day business, administrative and scientific management of Center activities.

PHR: NARRATIVE: PROJECT 1: TARGETING GLIOMA TISSUE STATES Glioblastoma (GBM) biopsies are composed of not only molecularly aberrant malignant glioma cells but also a sizeable abundance of non-malignant cells (including immune, astrocytes, oligodendrocytes, etc.). The goal of this project is to find targetable cross-talk relationships between these cell compositional networks. Specifically, we will quantify different cellular compositions in pre- and post- treatment tumors, investigate cross-talk between the glioma cells and the microenvironmental other cell subpopulations, and, lastly, determine the impact of targeting this crosstalk to shift the cell community composition into a more favorable/treatable state.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Sexual minority women disproportionately consume alcohol, suffer from alcohol-related problems, and experience depression and anxiety. Although clinical programs are being developed for sexual minority women seeking treatment, culturally tailored preventive interventions able reduce alcohol consumption and increase psychological well-being in the larger at-risk population not motivated to seek treatment have been slow to emerge. This project narrows the disparity in alcohol intervention research and practice by advancing a highly scalable, culturally adapted, gamified personalized normative feedback alcohol intervention able to engage non-treatment seeking sexual minority women and reduce their alcohol and mental health risks.

PHR: NARRATIVE: PROJECT 2: IMAGING THE DYNAMIC TISSUE STATE IN PATIENTS IN VIVO Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) measures many different physical properties of the tissue which may be correlated with the specific tumor behavior (e.g., proliferation, inflammation, angiogenesis) found in the limited biopsies available per patient. This project will fuse readily available MRI to spatially localized biopsies to build predictive models of cellular composition across the unsampled tumor (and brain) to track and validate cell composition changes to standard and immune therapies. Connecting these imaging changes to patient survival will allow identification of clinically beneficial shifts in cellular cohabitation.

PHR: NARRATIVE: OUTREACH CORE Getting computational results into the clinic requires a broader understanding of the methods and general principles by scientists, clinicians, and patients alike. Thus, the primary goal of the Outreach Core is to disseminate knowledge of the iterative dialogue between mathematical oncology, cancer systems biology and experimental and clinical oncology to students, colleagues, and the general public. To accomplish our goal, we will train new cross-disciplinary scientists, inform the research community, engage with the general public, and assess our outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Patients suffering from urologic chronic pelvic pain syndrome (UCPPS) in the form of interstitial cystitis/bladder pain syndrome (IC/BPS) or chronic prostatitis/chronic pelvic pain syndrome (CP/CPPS) have an extremely poor quality of life due, in part, to the cognitive and emotional problems that accompany their pelvic pain and a lack of effective treatments. To learn more about the brain’s role in bladder pain in the hopes of finding new therapeutic targets, we focus on the amygdala, a brain area involved in both pain and emotion. These proposed studies will investigate the role of the left versus right amygdala in contributing to and altering bladder pain in mice.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The increasing morbidity and mortality of the opioid epidemic has necessitated a reevaluation of current addiction treatment paradigms: medications for opioid use disorder, such as buprenorphine and methadone, are effective in decreasing one’s risk of death and disability from opioid use but are underutilized and often difficult to access. The 5000 Emergency Departments (EDs) in the US are potential additional locales for medication initiation, but currently only a small minority of ED patients with opioid use disorder are started on medications. This R34 will refine and pilot an intervention called Talk About It which aims to foster patient-centered care, ‘meet patients where they are’ for addiction treatment, and increase treatment initiation and adherence via facilitating Shared Decision-Making in the ED around these potentially life-saving options.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Breast cancer response to treatments strongly depends on the composition of the local tumor microenvironment. This project will determine if targeting the epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) in inflammatory breast cancer can shift the tumor microenvironment from immunosuppressive to immunoreactive. Results of our study will have broad implications for tumors that have thus far been insensitive to immune checkpoint inhibitors.

PHR: Narrative Cancer immunotherapies have led to major treatment breakthroughs for a number of different cancers, but the majority of head and neck cancer patients do not respond to immunotherapies, and clinical responses are often not durable. We have demonstrated that targeting tumors with stereotactic radiation in combination with immunotherapy while sparing draining lymphatics enhances anticancer immunity, resulting in significantly improved response profiles. The research outlined in this proposal will leverage targeted tumor radiation and a combination of anti-CD47 and anti-PD-1 therapy to improve the response to PD-1 inhibitor immunotherapy in human papilloma virus related cancers of the throat.

PHR: NARRATIVE Electronic cigarettes (e-cigarettes) are one of the most widely used tobacco products and a growing number of people report wanting to quit using them, yet little is known about e-cigarette withdrawal and there are no proven interventions for promoting e-cigarette cessation. The goal of this project is to rigorously evaluate the nature of e-cigarette withdrawal in exclusive e-cigarette users during a monitored abstinence period and the role of nicotine in the expression of this withdrawal syndrome. The proposed project will provide essential information to the FDA and public health organizations about the clinical significance of behavioral and biological withdrawal outcomes and inform mechanisms for e-cigarette cessation.

PHR: Project Narrative The use of gene sequencing technologies to detect genetic changes in cancer has improved patient care by offering novel therapies that specifically target these genes. New approaches to detect genetic changes from blood samples offer a non-invasive approach to diagnose patients with cancer in need of new therapies. In this proposal, we will develop a blood test for FGFR genes that is focused, cost-effective, accurate, and practical for real-time use to enable rapid diagnosis, therapy monitoring, resistance detection.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Clinicians currently operate in a clinical and policy environment with no high-quality evidence supporting optimal guidelines on the perioperative care for patients on OUD who undergo surgical procedures. Using state-of-the-art national databases and rigorous methods, we will generate the most comprehensive data analyses to date on the landscape of perioperative management of buprenorphine and other MOUD as well as its consequences on opioid overdose risk and other health outcomes in privately insured, Medicaid, and Medicare patients aged 15 years and above. Findings from this proposal will inform efforts to optimize the perioperative management of buprenorphine and other MOUD, thus informing optimized perioperative efforts to reduce opioid-related morbidity and mortality for patients with OUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol use temporally increases risk for college students’ intimate partner violence (IPV) perpetration, but real-time alcohol-related IPV interventions delivered proximally to drinking episodes remain underdeveloped. As a first step toward our long-term goal of expanding just-in- time alcohol-related IPV interventions, this application will examine the feasibility and utility of objectively monitoring alcohol intoxication in relation to IPV perpetration using portable breathalyzers paired with a smartphone-based ecological momentary assessment application. This objective assessment of alcohol use in heavy drinking college students’ natural environments is a novel shift from collecting self-reported alcohol use data in relation to IPV and will inform the expansion of remotely-delivered alcohol and IPV reduction strategies in real time.

ORG_NAME: AFRICA INSTITUTE OF MENTAL AND BRAIN HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project seeks to develop, pilot, and test the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of a smartphone- delivered climate adaptation safety and harm reduction intervention for women experiencing intimate partner violence (IPV) in informal settlements in Kenya using ecological momentary approaches. The project will: (1) develop, test, and modify a smartphone-based EMA application designed to collect information on female residents’ IPV experiences, emotional stress, IPV self-efficacy, receipt of IPV-related social support and services, safety, climate-related comfort, social and environmental context, and current behaviors in informal settlements (R21: Phase 1); (2) pilot test the EMA application among 320 women living in two large informal settlements in Nairobi, Kenya and use the data collected to explore important, but understudied associations between climate and IPV in informal settlements (R21: Phase 2); (3) adapt an evidence-based Wings of hope (WINGS) intervention for integration into the smartphone-based EMA application developed in the R21 phase (R33: Phase 1); and (4) test the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of the adapted WINGS-based ecological momentary intervention (EMI) through a randomized control trial (RCT) (R33: Phase 2). The goals of this study are: to provide women with a low-cost, accessible, smartphone-based tool that empowers them to develop, utilize, and revise personal safety and harm reduction strategies that are specifically responsive to climate- related IPV and, in doing so, to provide survivors with interventions in real-time.

PHR: Project Narrative Developmental retinal blood vessel formation is a complex and highly regulated process, and pathologies associated with aberrant formation or proliferation of retinal blood vessels are among the leading causes of blindness. A thorough understanding of retinal vascular development is necessary to better understand retinal vascular diseases. The proposed studies aim to understand the role of innate immunity in the regulation of retinal blood vessel development and elevate our understanding of how abnormal neovasculature arises.

PHR: Narrative Stimulant use and abuse continue to be on the rise, yet we know little about the initial molecular changes that occur in the brain with repeated drug use. In this project, we will employ whole-brain multimodal imaging to investigate how repeated exposure to two classes of stimulant drugs alters excitatory and inhibitory dopamine receptor signaling and trafficking over time. The results from this study will provide insight into the timeline of receptors adaptations due to drug exposure and shed a light on the mechanisms that may lead to addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol use and disorders are prevalent and associated with significant personal, interpersonal, and societal costs. Relevant to NIH's public health mission, the proposed study investigates genetic influences on the progression and trajectories of alcohol use from late childhood to adolescence, examines the role of childhood precursors (impulsivity, externalizing, and internalizing symptoms) in the pathways of genetic risk to alcohol use, and identifies cultural-contextual risk and protective factors that moderate genetic risk among racially- ethnically diverse youth. Findings have strong potential to inform culturally-tailored and personalized early prevention programs aimed at reducing alcohol problems and related health disparities.

ORG_NAME: CENTRE OF EXCELLENCE IN HEALTH MONITORING AND EVALUATION
PHR: NARRATIVE Tailored implementation strategies are urgently needed to increase the uptake of highly effective HIV prevention such as pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) and HIV self-testing (HIVST) among adolescent girls and young women (AGYW) in sub-Saharan Africa. In this study, we will scale several pharmacy-based models for PrEP and HIVST delivery in five areas of Lake Zone, Tanzania and will evaluate implementation and effectiveness outcomes among pharmacies and AGYW. Trainees completing a Certificate in Implementation Science will enhance the research, which will provide guidance about whether pharmacy-based distribution of PrEP and HIVST is an effective strategy for decreasing the incidence of HIV among AGYW.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research aims to fill an unmet clinical need in treating aggressive cancers such as colon, pancreatic, and breast. We found that Integrin Alpha V (ITGAV) is necessary for the survival of these cancers and that a novel pocket on its structure can be targeted with a drug. Additionally, we will investigate the complex signaling controlled by ITGAV to propose combinational therapies and create new therapeutic strategies to treat these cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to harness the power of music and singing to enhance walking ability in people with Parkinson disease. We think that mental (i.e. imagined) singing while walking will help people walk faster with more stable gait while walking to music will help people walk faster but will less stability. Our studies will help us understand the best ways to use singing and music to help people walk more effectively and maintain their mobility and independence, and we will learn how use of these methods influences the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: RELEVANCE (See instructions): Tobacco and mentholated e-cigarette flavors are widely available and using these products are considered  safer than traditional cigarette use. Toxicity and health effects of these flavors and what agents cause  those health effects are not known. This R00 proposes to perform short term and long-term effects of  exposure to menthol, mint, and tobacco flavored e-cigarettes on lungs and how the exposure affect pre-existing lung conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative. The Colorado Clinical and Translational Sciences Institute’s T32 Post-Doctoral Program aligns with and supports the goals of NCATS to ensure that a diverse pool of highly trained scientists is available in adequate numbers to carry out the nation’s clinical and translational science research agenda. Our program is novel in that it expands the translational spectrum by recognizing the importance of shared, naturally occurring models of disease among animals and humans to push discovery. As such to meet these needs, we will prepare diverse interdisciplinary translational scientists involving both doctorally prepared clinicians (physicians (MD), pharmacists (PharmD), physical therapists (DPT), nurses (DPN) at the University of Colorado who will complete the Masters of Clinical Science degree and veterinarians completing a PhD from Colorado State University, our partnering university, that are team-oriented and have developed competencies necessary for successful translational science and research careers.
PROJECT_TERMS: Colorado;Postdoctoral Fellow;Universities
PROJECT_TITLE: CTSA Postdoctoral T32 at University of Colorado Denver

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE Climatic and non-climatic extreme events, or shocks, are dramatically impacting human health. This research uses novel mobility data derived from mobile phones, georeferenced environmental and contextual data (e.g., weather extremes, natural disasters, and armed conflict), and population-representative health data to assess the impact of these shocks and shock-induced changes in mobility patterns on women’s risk of intimate partner violence in Kenya. This work will inform policy and interventions to prevent intimate partner violence and other health threats for women in the face of ongoing and increasing climate shocks and other extreme events.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have demonstrated that biofluids in close proximity to cancers are significantly enriched for levels of released tumor DNA, which permits for greater sensitivity and potentially specificity. In this proposal we will utilize a multi-analyte approach including mutations, aneuploidy, fragmentomics and methylation to develop liquid biopsy approaches for pre-neoplastic and neoplastic conditions involving the brain and head and neck by analyzing cerebrospinal fluid and saliva respectively. We will work closely with our industrial partners, Belay Diagnostics, to validate the performance of our assays and develop CLIA certified tests ready for clinical implementation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cytoplasmic compartmentalization mechanisms have the potential to influence broad cellular processes and pathways, including how, when, and where mRNAs are translated, silenced, or degraded. The research outlined in this proposal will elucidate the molecular and functional role of a new cytoplasmic niche between membrane- bound organelles and membrane-less RNA-protein organelles. We expect the results from these studies will yield fundamental insights into how cells under duress rapidly switch from bulk mRNA translation to sequestration, as well as, how cells prevent membrane-less organelles from developing into toxic RNA-protein aggregates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This project will advance basic neuroscience research tools by developing a novel implantable octrode probe, to be the first on the market for real-time, simultaneous direct measurement of the critical neurotransmitters, gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) and glutamate. The multiplexing and in vivo capabilities of the probe will allow researchers to develop more effective animal models and therapeutics for brain diseases and mental disorders, which affect millions of Americans such as Alzheimer’s Disease (15M), Epilepsy (4M), and Parkinson’s disease (1.5M), and costs over $1.5 trillion in healthcare spending annually.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The human facial skeleton originates from groups of cells in specific positions with unique identities, each instructing the formation of a different skeletal structure. We hypothesize that in human genetic diseases, like frontonasal dysplasia, the ability to establish these identities is disrupted. In this proposal we use zebrafish disease models to investigate a hypothetical identity ‘code’ instructing positional cellular identity, thus informing the etiology of these devastating birth defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to apply a novel method of modeling dual trajectories of alcohol use and binge drinking in a longitudinal cohort from age 15 to 40. Using the social-ecological framework, we will then investigate the role of familial and environmental factors in adolescence on alcohol use trajectories. A better understanding of alcohol use patterns across the life course and key influences during adolescence may help inform harm reduction interventions.

PHR: Despite strong links between maternal infections experienced during pregnancy and risk for offspring neurodevelopmental disorders, little is known about the underlying neurobiological mechanisms that lead to alterations in the trajectory of brain development. The proposed studies will utilize a translationally relevant preclinical model to evaluate cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying aberrant neurodevelopment. If successful, our results will identify causal pathways in specific neural circuits vulnerable to prenatal immune challenge, which is an essential next step in efforts to develop novel therapeutic interventions and preventative strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In two-thirds of lysosomal storage disorders (LSD), patients suffer neurologic symptoms that are not corrected by most therapies, including gene replacement, especially if treatment is given after symptom onset. We recently identified pathologic changes in hippocampal network dynamics that arise early in CLN3 disease, a representative LSD, and the most common cause of pediatric dementia. The goal of this project is to understand if early, progressive changes in network physiology in CLN3 disease will establish a point beyond which gene therapy cannot restore function to a diseased neuronal circuit and to explore if modulating network activity can modify the efficacy of gene replacement.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative To improve health outcomes for people with disabilities, an overlooked health disparities population, this proposed study will use complementary datasets from the National Survey on Drug Use and Health, and commercial (MarketScan) and public (Medicaid) health care claims, to investigate differences in alcohol use, alcohol-related morbidity, and alcohol use disorder by disability status. Uniquely, this study will determine if disparities exist for people with disabilities regarding access, quality, and outcomes of treatment for alcohol use disorder. Knowledge gained will inform improvements in the health and wellbeing for people with disabilities by identifying where policy and practice changes are most needed to reduce future alcohol-related morbidity and consequences.

PHR: Narrative Clonal hematopoiesis is the phenomenon of age-related outgrowth of somatic clones in the blood. It can be detected from the discovery of somatic CNVs in blood samples. We will discover and analyze somatic CNVs in the blood of individuals enrolled in the All of Us initiative. Completing this project will result in a resource of somatic CNVs that can be leveraged by various studies utilizing data in the All of Us project. Results will also provide a new insight into the etiology of somatic CNVs in the blood. 2

PHR: NARRATIVE: To develop and commercialize [18F]fluorthanatrace ([18F]FTT), a PET tracer that measures PARP-1 expression and PARP inhibitor target engagement, Trevarx Biomedical Inc. and the University of Pennsylvania are proposing a Phase II STTR project to develop an efficient method for synthesizing [18F]FTT for widespread distribution, one that maximizes product consistency and production yield. The proposed project will result in a standardized procedure that will support larger multi-center trials that can be easily adapted by commercial radiopharmacies to provide a widescale supply of [18F]FTT following FDA approval, thereby providing a valuable imaging biomarker that will enable better guidance of PARPi treatment for many cancer patients. This project is innovative since it will establish a new roadmap for the rapid commercialization of PET radiopharmaceuticals to efficiently bring novel PET tracers to market.

PHR: Project Narrative: Therapeutic agents targeting checkpoint inhibitors have transformed cancer treatment by enhancing anti-tumor immune responses but can also cause a breakdown in self-tolerance resulting in autoimmune complications affecting most organs. We showed that changes in immune cells and their inflammatory mediators modify pancreatic β cells and cause diabetes following checkpoint inhibitor immunotherapy. The proposed studies, using checkpoint inhibitor-induced diabetes as a model, will enhance our understanding of immune-target cell interactions and the impact of tumor on development of immune related adverse events, which could potentially lead to identification of biomarkers and therapeutic targets of these events that do not impact tumor responses.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We proposed to develop brief, accurate, survey-based screening tools for identifying substance-naïve youth at prospective risk of early, high-risk drinking and drug use during adolescence. By creating low-burden and generalizable measures for use in real-world settings, we will enable a more precise targeting of preventive interventions and clinical services toward the youth at greatest risk of negative long-term outcomes (e.g., chronic substance use disorder), thereby improving public health outcomes.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS RIO GRANDE VALLEY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The University of Texas Rio Grande Valley seeks to establish a Diversity Center for Genome Research that will build genomics research capacity by 1) expanding genomic research capabilities and discoveries in two innovative research projects; and 2) enhancing the size and quality of the available genomics workforce. The Center will leverage the exciting activities and resources available in two highly innovative research projects, one focused on non-alcoholic fatty liver disease and one focused on major depressive disorder. The Center’s structure and approach are designed to expand the pool of diverse genomic scientists, clinician scientists, and researchers at both the doctoral and technical staff levels who can perform cutting-edge multidisciplinary genomics research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Native Hawaiian/Pacific Islander (NPI) young adults endure heavy alcohol-related disparities including high rates of hazardous drinking and alcohol use disorders that cause 40% of NPI young adults to suffer alcohol- related harms. Building on our intervention model of evidence-based alcohol prevention strategies selected and shaped in a prior NIAAA R21, this resubmitted R01 study will refine and then randomized controlled test SPEAR: a culturally grounded alcohol use disorder prevention intervention for NPI young adults. Using innovative community engaged research methods, this project will produce a first-of-its-kind culturally and community informed intervention to reduce alcohol use and prevent alcohol use disorders and harms in NPI young adults.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite decades of efforts to reduce racial pain disparities, the pain of Black patients is still undertreated, indicating that this decades-old inequity must be addressed by taking an innovative approach. This work will develop and test a comprehensive framework establishing behavioral coordination (the dyadic and dynamic processes underlying patient-provider communication) as the key mechanism through which patient and provider factors contribute to racial disparities in both patient-centered and clinical pain outcomes. Findings from this work will lay the foundation for developing interventions that target modifiable factors (i.e., patient-provider communication) that can be addressed by leveraging existing infrastructure (i.e., medical training).

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Down syndrome (DS), the genetic condition caused by triplication of chromosome 21 (T21), is the most common chromosomal abnormality and a leading cause of intellectual and developmental disability. Although it is accepted that T21 causes genome-wide dysregulation of gene expression programs, little is known about how T21 affects gene expression across different tissues and organs, and how these effects contribute to the developmental and clinical hallmarks of DS. To address this knowledge gap, this proposal aims to generate a comprehensive atlas of tissue-specific gene expression changes caused by T21, matched to detailed metrics of organ development and architecture.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE Most patients with alcohol use disorder (AUD) do not receive treatment, including medications for AUD. The proposed pragmatic trial tests population-based primary care interventions designed to increase treatment engagement and decrease alcohol use among non-treatment seeking patients with AUD. Specifically, the trial tests two interventions to implement a patient-centered decision aid and shared decision-making in a primary care sample of 1,500 patients who have 4 or more AUD symptoms documented in their electronic health records, consistent with moderate to severe AUD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vascular contributors to cognitive impairment and dementia (including Alzheimer’s disease) have a profound societal impact and despite the importance treatment remains limited. Vascular disturbances lead to disconnection and damage of the brains white matter connectivity associated with cognitive impairment. Our evidence suggests that these harmful effects to white matter are mediated by vascular- immune cell alterations and we will aim to study these in detail to provide new information to enable the development of treatments.

PHR: Project Narrative Cancer-promoting changes in chromosome structure can occur when replication forks are arrested at sites of DNA damage. I discovered that two proteins that act at the stalled fork, FANCM and BRCA1, prevent chromosome rearrangements from forming at stalled forks, and that combined loss of BRCA1 and FANCM is lethal to cells. My goals in this proposal are to identify how this lethal interaction operates in cancer cells, with a view to targeting FANCM as a new therapy in BRCA1 mutant breast or ovarian cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic pain is a debilitating consequence of spinal cord injury that is refractive to current treatments. This proposal aims to examine how the macrophage activation state can modulate nociceptor excitability, and if altering macrophage phenotype reduce the development of spinal cord injury-induced pain. Understanding these interactions will give us a better understanding of the underlying neuropathology that occurs early after a spinal cord injury in the dorsal root ganglia that leads to pain development or prevention.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sleep problems affect up to 93% of individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). These sleep problems can precede an ASD diagnosis and worsen core ASD symptoms. This project will investigate the relationship between early life sleep loss and ASD in a genetic mouse model of ASD to better understand the molecular consequences of sleep loss in order to allow for targeted intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO RIO PIEDRAS
PHR: The main goal of the NeuroID program is to increase diversity in the Neurosciences by establishing a cohort of interested students that will receive academic and professional training in neuroscience- related research and developmental activities. Specifically, the NeuroID program will be primarily training dedicated Hispanic undergraduate students, which at the end the program will pursue a research career in Neuroscience. The core of the program is a comprehensive research experience for undergraduate students based on an established research-with-purpose training philosophy that integrates research and community outreach activities, to enhance empathy, social responsibility and self-motivation skills. At the end, students will have the necessary research, academic and professional skills to succeed in a research career in neuroscience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This SBIR research will demonstrate a superior method of respiratory monitoring that will be first to enable continuous predictive respiratory monitoring (CPRM) at the patient bedside and in the future at the patient’s home. This research (phase 1 and 2) and innovative product research & development (phase 2) will enable commercialization of the Linshom CPRM that will move the entire field of respiratory monitoring from responsive (too late) to predictive, where patient respiratory decline is identified when health care providers can take action and pre-empt patient decline. This will reduce morbidity, mortality and healthcare expense. The engineering research (phase 2) will re-design and miniaturize the sensor technology allowing these developments to be embedded in multiple additional, smaller form factors (i.e. nasal cannula, home use) to reach more patients in need of continuous, predictive respiratory monitoring.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative FTD, the second most common form of dementia after Alzheimer's disease, is an incurable illness which leads to inevitable cognitive and behavioral decline. FTD-Tau is characterized by accumulation of toxic aggregates of Tau protein in the brain. Our poor understanding of the molecular mechanisms mediating Tau toxicity onto neurons, and synapses, stands as a critical barrier to identifying effective treatments for FTD. This project will seek to address this gap in knowledge by examining how SUMOylation, a post-translational modification that our labs found to be impaired in FTD, controls tau aggregation and pathological action of Tau on mitochondrial and synaptic functions in animal models as well as patient-derived neurons carrying Tau mutations.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposal will introduce new statistical approaches for quantifying and reducing biases in genome-wide association studies using family health history as proxy phenotypes. The projects will leverage the rich family health history survey data with matched genomic information in the AllofUs research program to interrogate methodological flaws in current GWAS-by-proxy approaches. The findings may fundamentally change how family health history information will be used in future complex disease genetic studies.

PHR: Project Narrative Polygenic scores offer the promise of empowering precision medicine by assessing individual-level risk of heritable diseases based on a personal genome. This proposal aims to develop and apply methods that increase accuracy of genetic risk models by analyzing whole-genome sequencing data from population biobank data sets. The methods to be developed will incorporate structural variants and blood-derived somatic mutations not currently considered by existing approaches and will allow analyses of genome-wide SNP and indel variants to scale to hundreds of thousands of sequenced individuals.

PHR: Project Narrative This proposal promotes intergenerational cardiovascular health (CVH) of women and children in the high burden St. Louis, Missouri, metro region, by rigorously testing HEALTH (Healthy Eating Active Living Taught at Home). This intervention is delivered through the Parents as Teachers (PAT) evidence-based home visiting model in partnership with the study team at Washington University in St. Louis (WUStL), and will further benefit from the ENRICH Collaborative. We will apply expertise in implementation science to ensure the intervention has equitable application and impact across PAT and the ENRICH Collaborative.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Endoplasmic reticulum (ER)-associated degradation (ERAD) is a principal ER quality-control mechanism; however, its (patho-)physiological role in vivo remains largely unclear. Excitingly, in a recent proteomics screen, we identified ceruloplasmin, a ferroxidase secreted by hepatocytes and a key player in iron metabolism, to be highly accumulated in the ER of ERAD-deficient liver. Hence, we will test the hypothesis that hepatic ERAD plays an essential role in systemic iron metabolism, at least in part, by controlling the turnover of ceruloplasmin protein in the liver.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Obesity is a major public health concern, as it increases the risk for diabetes, heart disease and certain forms of cancer. Obesity, particularly in its most severe form, has an extremely strong genetic basis. Unfortunately, most of the genes that predispose people to obesity, as well as the molecular and cellular pathways those genes participate in, remain unknown. This project builds on the expertise and established collaborative work of two investigators to illuminate how dysfunction of neuronal primary cilium, a specific sub-cellular compartment that functions as an intercellular antenna, causes obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative - Human milk oligosaccharides (HMOs), abundant components of human milk, hold extraordinary potential as biomedical and therapeutic agents to treat inflammatory, autoimmune, and allergic diseases, but the unavailability of methods to produce them in large quantities and affordable cost has hindered their systematic study and efforts to leverage their biomedical potential. To significantly improve HMO production efficiency, Zymtronix is applying its proprietary multienzyme immobilization and cell-free biocatalytic manufacturing systems to produce most HMO milk constituents and demonstrated successful production of multiple complex HMOs in Phase I. In this Phase II project, the company will focus on a single syalilated HMO that is more complex than any other previously synthesized using these methods which has been demonstrated to be highly protective against necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) – a devastating inflammatory gastrointestinal disorder with a 10-50% mortality rate in premature infants and total annual cost burdens upwards of $1B.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The bacterial cell envelope is composed of sugary layers that impede antimicrobials and the immune system. The building blocks that produce these layers are assembled on a lipid carrier that transports them from the inside of the cell to the outside. This proposal describes a program to exploit this lipid carrier to enhance vaccine production strategies while at the same time defining new mechanisms required for cell envelope assembly.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Maternal obesity and consumption of high calorie diets continue to be public health concerns as the perinatal environment provides support that is critical to the proper development and health of offspring. Preliminary data suggests that maternal high fat (HF) diet during development is associated with changes in meal patterning suggesting impaired post-ingestive feedback along the gut-brain axis that may be a result of with microbiota dysbiosis. The current proposal will investigate how perinatal HF diet and dysbiosis alters gut-brain axis development and vagally- mediated controls of feeding in HF offspring and leads to increased susceptibility to obesity and other metabolic disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE β-cells derived from human stem cells represent a transformative, unlimited source of insulin-producing cells for the treatment of type 1 diabetes, but translation of these cells is hindered by the lack long-term engraftment and function without chronic immunosuppression and use of encapsulation devices that limit engraftment. The objective of this project is to engineer advanced biomaterial delivery technologies to (i) enhance vascularization, survival, and engraftment of SC-β cells and (ii) protect them from rejection by the immune system without the need for encapsulation or chronic immunosuppression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The rapidly increasing prevalence and serious complications of type 2 diabetes (T2D) underscore its importance as a public health issue. Despite advances in therapeutic options, optimizing glycemic control still remains an elusive goal. Since excessive glucose production is the main source of increased glucose levels in T2D, understanding mechanisms that regulate glucose production would have important therapeutic implications. Our recent data suggest that the brain exerts important restraining effects on the liver’s glucose production, but that elevated fatty acid levels in T2D impair this regulation. Using studies in both humans and rats, we hope to clearly elucidate the impact of fatty acids on the cells in the brain that control glucose production. These studies could therefore lead to new therapeutic target(s) for the treatment of T2D.

PHR: Obesity has dramatically increased the burden of cardiovascular disease, and a major goal of the NIH/NIDDK is to reduce this burden. The goal of this application is to discover how to target liver estrogen pathways to improve glucose and lipid abnormalities in obesity and diabetes, which is expected to help reverse the impact of obesity on cardiovascular risk. Our project identifies pathways that mediate sex differences in cardiovascular disease, which is also an NIH priority area.

PHR: Project Narrative Insulin resistance is a risk factor for metabolic syndrome and is often observed in patients suffering from obesity, a major risk factor for cardiovascular disease. Endothelin-1 is increased in patients with obesity and may contribute to insulin resistance. The current proposal will elucidate mechanism by which ET-1 contributes to insulin resistance and will provide preclinical evidence to determine if ET-1 antagonists improve insulin sensitivity and cardiovascular outcomes associated with insulin resistance.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mustard gas keratopathy (MGK) is a sight-threatening, potentially blinding, chronic corneal disease after mustard exposure. Clinically characterized as persistent corneal epithelial erosions, ocular dryness and pain, and limbal stem cell deficiency, MGK still lacks definitive treatment with the underlying pathogenic mechanisms leading to the chronicity of ocular manifestations after exposure largely unknown. Existing evidence shows chronic inflammation as an important component of MGK, and thus this project, grounded on an established pre-clinical model in our lab, proposes to investigate the precise immune mechanisms that drive the development of MGK after acute mustard exposure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project aims to evaluate the role of two key affective skills – emotional granularity and interoceptive accuracy – that support coping with stress and uncertainty in adolescence, their relation to childhood adversity, and their role in contributing to resilience or vulnerability to the mental health impacts of daily stressors. A better understanding of the sources of individual differences in emotional granularity and interoceptive accuracy will allow for improvement of existing effective interventions targeting these skills and application of those interventions to improve outcomes among youth exposed to childhood adversity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Understanding how the immune system impacts the onset and progression of Alzheimer’s disease is critical to identifying new treatments for this devastating disease. Emerging allergic diseases that can drive systemic inflammation may be critical to understanding the pathogenesis of Alzheimer’s disease. This project aims to establish a relationship between tick-induced allergy to mammalian meat and neuroinflammatory molecular and T-cell signatures, thereby establishing a new paradigm for the immunopathogenesis of Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of this project is to induce localized immune tolerance to transplanted human beta cells derived from renewable stem cell sources as a treatment for type 1 diabetes. This project presents a significant step forward in the development of alternative, renewable, and off-the-shelf sources of insulin producing cells for current cell replacement therapy efforts. This project addresses the key technical challenge of systemic administration of immunosuppressive drugs to protect beta cell grafts through introduction of a highly localized immunomodulation and as such, represents the highest level of translational innovation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The incidence of type 1 diabetes (T1D), an autoimmune disease which affects millions of people worldwide, has been rising for the past half century. While both genetic and environmental factors contribute to the risk of developing T1D, recent studies indicate that early-life microbial interactions with the developing immune system offer a critical window of opportunity to influence the immune system’s development to prevent disease. Our study uses an innovative approach that leverages a community of early life microbes to identify microbial products and immune system pathways that may lead to therapies to prevent the development of T1D.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Non-invasive recordings of human brain activity cannot identify whether the parts of the brain that generate them are undergoing excitation (increased neuronal firing) or inhibition (decreased neuronal firing). We aim to develop a novel non-invasive measure of this moment-to-moment physiological excitability of the human cortex by using the TMS-evoked potential (TEP) – an amplitude deflection in EEG recordings of human cortex that can be elicited by TMS stimulation. We will systematically elicit excitation or inhibition of the same brain area using cognitive processes known to differentially increase or decrease that area’s neuronal firing. We will then test whether these changes are reflected in amplitude changes of the TEP.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Adolescents and young adults with T1D, as a subgroup of the population with T1D, have the poorest glycemic control of all, reaching a peak mean A1c >9% around age 19; they, too, often experience diabetes distress. Diabetes distress is common in persons with type 1 diabetes (T1D) and contributes to suboptimal self-care behaviors and outcomes, especially for the high risk group of adolescents and young adults with T1D. In the proposed 2-year randomized clinical trial, we will implement and assess the impact of a behavioral/psycho- educational intervention to reduce diabetes distress, increase acceptance of self-care behaviors (with or without diabetes technologies), and improve glycemic outcomes in adolescents and young adults, aged 14-25 years, with T1D in order to optimize their short-term and long-term health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is highly relevant to public health because the identification of efficacious interventions that integrate mental health-exercise training to improve insulin resistance in adolescents with obesity and depression offers the prospect of mitigating type 2 diabetes (T2D) risk. Adolescent females from historically disadvantaged racial/ethnic and socioeconomic backgrounds disproportionately experience elevated depression symptoms, physical inactivity, poor cardiorespiratory fitness, obesity, insulin resistance, and youth-onset T2D. By rigorously studying the efficacy of cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), exercise training, and their combinations to increase physical activity/fitness and ameliorate insulin resistance in adolescent females at-risk for T2D with elevated depression symptoms, the proposed research is poised to contribute to the NIDDK's mission to combat T2D and improve people's health and quality of life.

PHR: Obesity is associated with “metabolic inflexibility”, which is involved in the pathophysiology of obesity-induced metabolic abnormalities, such as type 2 diabetes and insulin resistance. PHR: NARRATIVE Loss of mitochondria and oxidative capacity have been implicated in the development or progression of many diseases, from type 2 diabetes to cardiovascular diseases and skeletal muscle diseases. PHR: Dysfunction to insulin secreting cells causes diabetes. Insulin-secreting cells show extensive electrical communication to regulate insulin secretion, and this communication is disrupted during diabetes. Understanding how this electrical communication is disrupted in diabetes will identify targets for retaining normal electrical communication and insulin secretion, thus providing potential drug targets for diabetes prevention.

PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project will determine the mechanisms that control pancreatic -cell endoplasmic reticulum (ER) Ca2+ (Ca2+ER) handling and their importance regulating islet hormone secretion. Results from this project are expected to provide significant insights into how glucose-stimulated-cell Ca2+ER handling becomes disrupted in T2D and perturbs islet hormone secretion. Thus, the proposed research project will generate fundamental knowledge about human islet -cells that will help reduce the burden of human illness in the context of diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Dysfunction and death of the insulin-producing β-cell underlies virtually all forms of diabetes, and the protection of β-cells represents an approach to the treatment of diabetes that has yet to be exploited. The 12-LOX pathway represents an attractive target for protection of β-cells, since inhibitors of this pathway have been developed. This proposal will provide a better understanding of how the 12-LOX pathway can be manipulated to protect β-cells.

PHR: Chronic Kidney Disease is predominantly a result of initial injury to the glomerulus, the filtration system in the kidney. Dysregulated signaling between injured visceral and parietal epithelial cells is a major contributor to glomerular dysfunction and eventual kidney failure. In this research proposal, we aim to investigate the mechanisms mediating this cellular crosstalk in glomerular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is a prototypic systemic autoimmune disease which causes significant morbidity and early mortality, especially in young minority women. SLE patients are at risk for ongoing heightened clinical disease activity and disease flares that often result in end-organ damage, and are only identified after clinical signs and symptoms have occurred. We propose to validate and prepare advanced marketing/clinical adoption and reimbursement strategies for a select panel of blood proteins that are known to activate or regulate the immune system and feed the results into innovative mathematical algorithms that assign a single, immune system-informed and clinically actionable disease activity or flare prediction scores to provide proactive information as to which SLE patients are likely to have heightened clinical disease activity or who are at risk of imminent disease flare (positive score) for early intervention, organ damage prevention, and reduced need for treatments that carry damaging side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately one third of patients with temporal lobe epilepsy do not respond to currently available antiseizure drugs, and many are not candidates for surgical resection. Inhibition of activity of a specific cell type in the hippocampus effectively arrests seizures in a rodent model of temporal lobe epilepsy, but translation of this approach is being hampered by the inability to specifically target these cells in human patients as it is impossible to modify genes as in model animals. In this project we will develop a viral vector to specifically deliver a transgene to the hippocampus in non-genetically modified mice with the goal of developing a novel and translatable gene therapy to stop seizures in patients with drug-resistant temporal lobe epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Identifying Needs and Building Research Capacity at an Historically-Black University Public Health Relevance  Building research capacity at Historically-Black institutions such as Delaware State University is a strategic investment that not only benefits these institutions, but also contributes to the advancement of scientific knowledge, the reduction of health disparities, and the promotion of diversity and inclusion in research. Building research capacity at HBCUs enables them to conduct research that addresses the unique health needs of their communities, contributing to the reduction of health disparities.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS RIO GRANDE VALLEY
PHR: Project Narrative Health research is vital to improving community health and is most effective when conducted synergistically between medical and health professionals (allied health, nursing, social work, clinical psychology) who represent more than 80% of the healthcare workforce. Closing the significant gap in the level of research skills and engagement between medical and health professions is critical to accelerating progress in addressing the most complex challenges on the public health agenda. The successful implementation of the proposed research needs assessment and corresponding action plan will result in an effective model that will support a robust multidisciplinary, interprofessional research capacity to advance health and health disparities research at minority-serving, resource-limited institutions.

This is a capacity-building project that will grow research excellence at our university.

PHR: The MapHabit System (MHS), our neuroscience-based, innovative assistive technology and interactive care management platform is focused on people living with Alzheimer’s disease and Alzheimer’s disease related dementias and helps organize an individual's habits and routines into visual maps i.e., step-by- step pictures/videos to successfully carry out activities of daily living (ADLs) and other activities. This CRP will boost commercialization and marketability of the MHS by implementing the goals of three interconnected Specific Aims (SAs) that will (SA1) strengthen our platform infrastructure and security to enable new predictive analytics components, (SA2) enhance user appeal and user “stickiness” by upgrading our innovative gamification programs and improvements related to the front-end user interface, and (SA3) enhance customer care processes utilizing social determinants of health (SDOH) Z codes. Taken together, these goals provide particularly important developments for successful commercialization because value-based care models to address health equity disparities are increasingly being linked to SDOH, and SDOH codes, and because these goals reflect the nation’s public health goal of further reducing the burden of AD/ADRD on individuals, their families and caregivers, and society at large.

PHR: Project Narrative Cancer is driven by DNA mutations which can increasingly be used to determine the type, likely outcome and best treatment options for individual patients. Establishing the clinical relevance of each mutation requires experts to review and summarize a growing body of evidence. By coordinating the efforts of these disease experts we will build a database of mutations and information that helps doctors guide treatment of cancer patients.

PHR: Proteins containing disordered regions are implicated in devastating human diseases but are challenging to characterize by conventional methods. This research will apply a novel approach to determine the molecular mechanisms by which the structured and disordered regions of the tumor suppressor p53 function synergistically to activate it in response to cellular DNA damage. Activation of p53 is of central importance in the prevention of cancer.

PHR: NARRATIVE Colorectal cancer is one of the most common cancers in both men and women in the United States and accounts for approximately 140,000 new cases annually. Hepatic metastasis, the dominant feature of life- limiting disease, occurs in approximately 20–50% of patients with colorectal cancer. In this study, we propose developing a novel strategy (hyperthermia + ferroptotic agent + TRAIL) to treat colorectal liver metastases.

PHR: Project Narrative Prostate cancer causes death because the cancer cells move throughout the body, forming lethal metastasis. If prostate cell movement could be inhibited just as they begin to move, it would prevent them from spreading throughout the body. We have made a first-of-its-kind drug that stops these cells from moving, and in this proposal we would like to test whether it will stop their initial movement and thereby prevent development of deadly spread.

PHR: Project Narrative Active perceptual processes such as attention and saccadic eye movements are essential for sensory guided behavior and memory formation; however, the cortical circuit mechanisms of active sensory information processing remain poorly understood. The breakdown of active perceptual processes is debilitating and can be observed in various neuropathologies such as attention-deficit disorder, autism, schizophrenia, and in patients with Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI). In this proposal, we will use advanced statistical analyses, in combination with sophisticated computational modeling, of dense neurophysiological data from a non-human primate model of active perception to investigate circuit level principles of information processing in the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Despite improvements in overall access to dental care for children in the U.S., oral health disparities persist, with low-income, publicly insured children bearing a disproportionate burden of dental disease. This study will contribute to the scientific knowledge about the potential spillover effects of adult-targeted Medicaid dental coverage policies on children. This evidence will be instrumental in informing policy and programmatic interventions aimed to improve dental care use among Medicaid-enrolled children and reduce oral health disparities.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Through this F30 training fellowship, I propose to examine the association between adiposity and ovulatory dysfunction among Samoan women. Project findings will shed light on the dual burden of cardiometabolic and reproductive risk among Pacific Islanders, who despite having among the highest obesity prevalence globally, are underrepresented in epidemiologic research. This training proposal integrates new learning experiences in longitudinal data analysis, epidemiological study design and implementation, and reproductive endocrinology which will prepare me for a career as a physician scientist that conducts longitudinal epidemiological research to characterize how obesity affects maternal and child health outcomes in low-resource settings.

PHR: Project Narrative  The insoluble tau aggregates present in multiple neurological disorders such as Alzheimer’s disease are morphologically and molecularly heterogeneous species that emerge from the assembly of tau seeds carrying specific molecular profiles. I aim to illustrate that tau’s molecular modifications in the form of its degree and pattern of hyperphosphorylation vary within tau oligomers and morphologically distinct insoluble tau aggregates in Alzheimer’s. These studies will facilitate the development of therapies that can accurately target various tau aggregates through the identification of the specific molecular signatures of tau seeds and tau aggregates present in human pathology.
