PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is an urgent need for objective biomarkers of disease progression that are sensitive to disease related changes over the duration of clinical trials in ALS. Based on our recent work on multimodal MRI in ALS, demonstrating sensitivity to change over six and twelve months, we propose a multi-site study to further optimize, validate, and demonstrate its clinical trial readiness. We will also correlate the MRI metrics with functional progression and plasma neurofilament light. 1
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Multimodal longitudinal imaging of brain and cervical cord as an ALS disease biomarker using microstructure statistics and morphometry

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over a third of U.S. adults have unhealthy substance use but primary care clinicians rarely routinely screen for and address unhealthy substance use in a whole person approach that would effectively reduce substance use and improve health. Our study engages primary care practice champions and patients in codesigning and implementing a comprehensive, whole person approach to identifying and addressing unhealthy substance use that accounts for the psychological, social and biological contributors to substance use.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Supporting Unhealthy Substance use care Through a whole person Approach and user centered INtegration into primary care (SUSTAIN)

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed Center for Cancer Systems Therapeutics (CaST) will seek to perform systematic, single-cell- level elucidation of stable cell states and state transitions in tumor-related cells and in their tumor microenvironment (TME) to identify and target complementary dependencies leading to mechanism-based combination therapy trials. This will provide a more holistic understanding of the fundamental steps underlying tumor initiation and progression and of the critical mechanisms that can be targeted pharmacologically to transform cancer treatment. Critically, we have shown that the Systems Biology framework developed by CaST Center investigators can effectively generalize to virtually any tumor of interest leading to highly innovative, biomarker-based interventional trials, thus accelerating progression from biological analysis to cures.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As neurodegenerative diseases have substantial heterogeneity in clinical presentation and no effective cures, Natural history studies (NHS) are essential to enhance our understanding of the disease, find external matching controls, identify people living with rare and ultra-rare forms of the diseases, and bring them into clinical research. Current “traditional” models of NHS in ultra-rare diseases try to search for people living with those conditions “under the lamppost” of the participating clinics, while a decentralized model with utilization of a disease-agnostic people-centric platform, NeuroPRO™, with digital biomarkers’ capture and periodic home or nearest clinical hubs visits will be more efficient in ultra-rare diseases like PLS or familial ALS. We propose to pilot NeuroPRO in three diverse settings that will cover majority of decentralized research models:  • A stand-alone patient-centric longitudinal NHS utilizing digital biomarkers and, if required, periodic home  or nearest clinical hubs visits,  • A hybrid NHS, in which patient-facing NeuroPRO and a “traditional” site-based NHS recruit participants  and capture data as equal partners, and  • NeuroPRO serving as a regulatory compliant environment for rapid simultaneous validation of digital  biomarkers against “standard” disease-specific biomarkers and outcomes.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Creating a disease-agnostic scalable platform for decentralized observational and validation of digital biomarkers studies and piloting it for people with familial ALS and ultra-rare MNDs

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Improving Diagnostic Equity in Ambulatory care Settings (I.D.E.A.S.): Research to Practice study is designed to evaluate diagnostic errors in the context of diagnostic equity and diagnostic uncertainty through the application of decision-modeling and human factors methodologies. IDEAS: Research to Practice will produce data to understand the extent to which diagnostic inequities occur in the ambulatory setting and their root causes. Our anticipated findings serve as the first step in designing interventions to support clinicians and patients in recognizing potential diagnostic errors, connecting risk factors and their interactions to disproportionately experienced diagnostic errors caused by system-level challenges in diagnostic decision-making processes.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Improving Diagnostic Equity in Ambulatory care Settings (I.D.E.A.S.): Research to Practice

PHR: NARRATIVE We propose to test an innovative model connecting clinical settings serving historically marginalized communities with early childhood educational services for preschool-age children with developmental delays and disabilities. In doing so, our study aims to improve access to educational and therapeutic services which foster developmental skills and improve health outcomes for families and their children with developmental delays and disabilities.

PHR: Project Narrative  This proposal will benefit both basic scientists in their understanding of the drug resistant brain cancer – glioblastoma – as well as chemical biologists in deriving new selenium-containing small molecules. This proposal is also directly related to the NCI’s mission statement to “help all people live longer, healthier lives” as the project uses a neuroprotective agent to treat drug resistant glioblastoma which should both extend lifespan while also decreasing toxic side effects. In this way, I believe this project will both increase our knowledge and ability to target drug resistant brain tumors in a smarter way.

PHR: There is a limiting understanding of the predictive value of metrics of sleep health and circadian rhythms – core to mental and physical health and well-being – for medications for opioid-use disorder (MOUD) outcomes. The proposed project will identify sleep and circadian phenotypes that are predictive of MOUD outcomes and can point to potential intervention targets. The proposed research is relevant to the NIH HEAL initiative's mission that pertains to conducting research to improve the treatment for opioid misuse and addiction.

PHR: Project Narrative Cervical cancer is one of the most preventable and treatable forms of cancer, yet nearly 90% of cases in low- to middle-income countries result in death. To address this crisis, we recently developed a portable, low-cost, simple-to-use, telemedicine- and patient-friendly innovative imaging system that can help advance toward the screen-and-treat strategy for cervical cancer prevention advocated by the World Health Organization. In this phase II study, we will establish the feasibility of our screening protocols through a multisite international study and advance the overall technology.

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCY STATEMENT) Chinese immigrants suffer a disproportionately high type 2 diabetes (T2D) burden and have poor health outcomes. They face numerous social determinants barriers to accessing evidence-based diabetes programs, including high rates of poverty and limited English proficiency (LEP), and lack of insurance. This project will provide important evidence on scalable strategies to disseminate and implement evidence-based diabetes interventions in LEP Chinese immigrants with T2D.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Implementing an effective Diabetes intervEntion Among Low-income immigrants (IDEAL Study)

PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Dementia is predicted to affect more than 50 million people by the year 2050 and is a leading cause of death. However, there is no cure and more than 400 clinical trials have not proven successful. We believe that immune signaling molecules in the brain causes chronic brain inflammation; therefore, we believe that by being able to monitor the signaling proteins involved would be a viable strategy to stage and grade dementia using a unique set of human-relevant mouse models we have created in preparation for testing in human clinical trials.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hepatic steatosis is a common radiographic “incidental finding” that is overlooked and underreported to patients. We developed a clinical decision support system using machine learning and natural language processing that will prompt reporting to patients and provide ED clinicians risk stratified follow-up care recommendations. Data on both the implementation and effectiveness of our intervention resulting from this trial will inform future use with a goal of ultimately improving diagnostic safety and outcomes for patients with hepatic steatosis.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Improving Diagnostic Safety through STeatosis Identification, Risk stratification, and Referral in the ED (STIRRED)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Resistance to conventional chemo-radiation and immunotherapy in glioblastoma (GBM) results in uniform lethality by 12-18 months in the majority of patients. Here we propose to demonstrate novel therapeutic potential of drugs termed CDIMs that target NR4A1 and NR4A2 nuclear orphan receptors which drive interacting mesenchymal and immune suppressive tumor microenvironments that promote resistance to standard chemo- radiation and immune checkpoint therapy, respectively. By disrupting NR4A1/2 effects on the tumor microenvironment, CDIMs are expected to have robust anti-tumor activity and potentiate current chemo-radiation or immune based therapies in GBM.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Narrative To improve oral health and reduce health inequities, it is essential to address structural barriers that impede access and use of dental services; on July 1, 2021, the Virginia Medicaid program expanded dental benefits, enabling 800,000+ adults to access comprehensive dental services. The research plan of this career development award aims to evaluate the multi-level impact of this large-scale dental policy change on access and use of dental care among adults and children and isolate the role of dental policy in addressing oral health disparities using advanced data science approaches. The resulting findings from this work will fill critical research gaps, generate actionable evidence to strengthen existing and new policies, inform programmatic decisions to improve oral health equity and support NIDCR's strategic goal of advancing oral health for all.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative This study, entitled “BEATS: Binge drinking Ecological Antecedents with Transdermal alcohol monitoring Study,” will enroll 100 sexually-active adults who binge drink alcohol and assess real-time antecedents for binge-drinking and binge-drinking associated sexual behaviors using real-time assessments during a 30-day follow-up. Participants will also wear a wrist monitor that will track alcohol consumption continuously for 30 days. Data from the assessments and monitor will be analyzed using machine learning approaches to develop algorithms that predicts binge drinking (aim 1) and binge-drinking associated sexual behaviors (aim 2), while data on the feasibility and acceptability of these procedures will be examined for this population (aim 3).

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project seeks to establish clinical outcome assessments (COAs) to capture the capacity, efficacy, impacts, and perceptions of communication brain computer interfaces (cBCIs) as tools to improve the healthcare and quality of life of those with ALS and their caregivers. To better develop and apply such COAs, we will develop a deep and wide-ranging understanding of (1) the current clinical and scientific landscape surrounding cBCIs, (2) the assessment of their impacts and efficacy, (3) the strengths and weaknesses of current COAs, (4) patient needs and their perceptions of cBCIs, and (5) to evaluate areas for future COA development. By including historical, scientific, and stakeholder-based information in a landscape assessment of COAs for cBCIs in ALS, we can establish a clear pathway toward identification, development, and validation of a precise, accurate, and meaningful measure that will facilitate regulatory approval, reimbursement, and patient access to these transformative technologies.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Metrics for Brain Controlled Communication: A comprehensive review of clinical outcome assessments for communication brain computer interfaces in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis

PHR: Project Narrative  Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is a leading cause of cancer-related mortality worldwide. HMG-CoA reductase (HMGCR) inhibitors, statins, show high potential in the prevention and treatment of cancer including HCC. We hypothesize that the MYC pathway is suppressed by statins and this is a mechanism by which statins can prevent and treat HCC, both through direct anti-oncogene effects as well as by restoring immune surveillance. We will determine the mechanisms by which statins protect against HCC as well as identify biomarkers that can predict when these agents are most likely to be useful in preventing HC.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Methamphetamine (MA) is a highly addictive drug that has both rewarding and aversive effects. We recently discovered that a receptor called the trace-amine associated receptor 1 (TAAR1) mediates MA aversion and protects against MA intake. By using genetic tools and electrophysiology, this project will identify how MA activation of TAAR1 produces aversion and reduces MA intake, which could lead to the identification of a new class of therapeutics for MA addiction.

ORG_NAME: HENRY FORD HEALTH + MICHIGAN STATE UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative It became well known that the immune suppressive niche inside the tumor microenvironment (TME) accounts for tumor immune escape and progression, in which the regulatory T cells (Tregs) play an important role. Vacuolar protein sorting 72 homolog (VPS72), a histone chaperone that recognizes and exchanges histone H2A.Z for standard histone H2A. In the proposed studies, we will use gene deletion mouse models to determine the role of VPS72 and H2AZ in Treg cell maintenance, stability, and function in the tumor. Results from the proposed study will not only enhance our understanding of Treg biology but will also facilitate the development of more efficient Treg-based intervention strategies for cancer treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will improve our understanding of how the brain’s motor system interacts with its sensory systems via the cerebellum as we plan and produce speech. It will employ state-of-the-art non-invasive, ultra-high field functional magnetic resonance imaging to provide maps of brain activity during speaking tasks in unprecedented detail. The foundational knowledge gained through this project is expected to lead to new insights about the mechanisms underlying speech disorders.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The US is facing a “twin epidemic” with dual crises of chronic pain and opioid overdoses, and despite national efforts to reduce opioid prescribing and improve non-opioid pain management, opioid overdoses are increasing, including from prescription opioids, and uptake of evidence- based nonpharmacological pain treatment approaches remains low. More effectively treating pain with non-opioid strategies is key, but low motivation and logistical barriers have interfered with many patients transitioning from long term opioid therapy to other evidence-based treatments. The proposed study will aim to address both of these barriers by developing and evaluating a Motivational Interviewing (MI) and Contingency Management (CM) intervention aimed at increasing readiness to reduce opioid use and utilize non-opioid, evidence-based CP interventions among individuals displaying risk on LTOT.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Narrative African American children engage in low amounts of activity, placing them at risk for health disparities as they age. African American fathers may be instrumental in helping to promote physical activity in their children. The current proposal is designed to use community-engaged research methods to develop a physical activity intervention for children in which their fathers are the agents of change, and to determine the feasibility of implementing this intervention.

PHR: Cancer cells reprogram signaling, metabolism, and other functions in response to changing environmental conditions. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients and health care professionals are now able to use genetic information to help prevent, diagnose and select treatments for diseases. Health policies can improve or reduce access to genomic tests; therefore, monitoring the outcomes of policies is an important public health issue. This project will advance the field of genomic medicine by developing and validating analytical methods for efficient, rigorous evaluation of policies that impact access to genomic tests and associated outcomes to inform healthcare and policy decisions.

PROJECT_TITLE: Surveillance for outcomes of genomic medicine policies

PHR: CENTER OVERALL: PROGRAM NARRATIVE Breast and cervical cancer kill many millions of women around the world, particularly in Sub-Saharan Africa, despite the fact that deaths and disability related to these cancers can be prevented by early detection and treatment. There are major gaps in the screening for and coordination of care to prevent women’s cancers in countries like Kenya; a profound inequity that threatens the health and well-being of women, their families, and communities. We propose to establish the Enhanced BReast and cErvical cAncer screening in Kenya THROUGH implementation science research and training (BREAKTHROUGH) Center, a partnership between institutions in Kenya, the US, and Canada to: 1/ promote research on how to improve women’s cancer control; 2/ to build the base of future researchers in Kenya that can continue and expand this work; and 3/ to inform policy makers on the best ways to engage women in breast and cervical cancer screenings and link them with appropriate care.

PHR: Project Narrative We propose to establish a SPORE program leveraging Hawai`i's multiethnic population and the University of Hawaii Cancer Center's community-facing translational research infrastructure to conduct minority health research among Asian Americans, Native Hawaiians and Pacific Islanders (AANHPI). We will test innovative approaches to address ethnic/racial disparities in non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) (a liver condition that may lead to chronic liver disease and liver cancer), lung cancer and breast cancer, and develop additional innovative translational research that will benefit Hawai`i, the Pacific region and the rest of the US.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Native Hawaiian smokers experience one of the highest risk of lung cancer, which is not fully explained by their smoking history. This multilevel translational study aims to identify barriers to lung cancer screening in Native Hawaiians, construct a population-specific risk prediction model to enhance screening guidelines, and molecularly profile lung tumors from Native Hawaiian patients to characterize the biological mechanisms that contribute to their high risk and poor survival. Study findings will help design a culturally informed health education campaign to improve lung cancer screening utilization and provide information towards more tailored precision-based treatment strategies for this high risk underserved population.

PHR: Cancer metastases to the leptomeninges (LM) are difficult to treat, create significant morbidity, and portend extremely poor survival. Our proposed work will define how malignant cells hijack developmental neuronal pathfinding mechanisms to enter the central nervous system and study how the innate and adaptive immune systems impact this metastatic pathway. Our studies will provide new mechanistic insight into a poorly understood biologic phenomenon and a therapeutic approach to an area of high unmet clinical need.

PHR: Project Narrative A quality gap exists in the performance of computed tomography (CT) as radiation doses are higher than needed for diagnosis and vary depending on where a patient goes for care. Alara Imaging has developed patient safety measures that are focused on the radiation dose and image quality for CT and are being considered for use in the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services (CMS) quality payment programs; the use of these measures has the potential to reduce the doses used for CT to make CT safer. Alara Imaging is seeking funding to support the development of commercially built software that hospitals and physicians can use to report on these measures as well as seeking funding to build software to help guide physicians to lower the doses they use for CT.

PHR: NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT The proposed studies are highly significant because they seek to understand breast cancer risk and survival differences in Asian American, Native Hawaiian and Pacific Islander (AANHPI) ethnic minority women. We will calibrate established radiomic risk features in mammogram images for AANHPI, assess markers of tissue microenvironment in breast tumors, and use already collected measures of fatness, including fat around the internal organs of the abdomen (visceral fat) and determine how they influence breast cancer risk and prognosis in AANHPI women. Thus, this advance is expected to have a high impact on health and well-being by improving risk and prognosis prediction and better identifying high risk women for further assessment or tailored therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Very little is known regarding the cell morphology and synaptic connectivity within the newly discovered rostromedial tegmental nucleus (RMTg) – a region implicated in the neural mechanisms underlying alcohol use disorder. Recent work from our laboratory reveals a dense projection from the mPFC to the RMTg but little is known about how functionally distinct subregions of the mPFC regulate RMTg signaling. The proposed project will combine circuit-specific labeling with state-of-the-art connectomics approaches to determine the effect of chronic ethanol exposure on cell morphology within the RMTg and the synaptic organization of cortical input to the region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE While there are already some established methods for antibody validation, there are still issues with the specificity, cross-reactivity, reproducibility, sensitivity, and accuracy of them. This is especially true for antibodies directed against post-translationally modified proteins. The proposed Phase II effort aims to address these issues by investigating the effects of post-translational modifications, comparing our MILKSHAKE method with other established methods for quantifying specificity and sensitivity, using our Sundae method for evaluating the importance of paratope specificity, and our Epivolve method for the discovery and validation of glycosylation-specific antibodies. The proposal also includes a means for the dissemination and commercialization of this Phase II project, which will increase the impact of this effort. Overall, the proposed research has the potential to contribute to the development of more reliable and accurate antibody validation methods and improve the reproducibility of biomedical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  Lyme disease is a tick-borne disease caused by bacterial spirochetes, the most prevalent vector-borne disease in the United States, and an ever-worsening public health problem. In this proposal, we will develop novel PET radiopharmaceuticals that target the bacteria responsible for Lyme disease — Borrelia burgdoferi sensu lato (Bbsl) ¾ and thus facilitate the non-invasive imaging of Bbsl infection. These probes could have a paradigm-shifting impact on both the basic science and clinical management of Lyme disease, with applications ranging from preclinical research to clinical imaging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative “Improve HIV-related health outcomes of people with HIV” is one of the 4 goals identified in the recently published US National HIV/AIDS Strategy (2022-2025), which involves addressing HIV-associated comorbidities. HIV-associated sensory neuropathy (HIV-SN) is one of the most common neurological complications associated with HIV infection, often painful, and clinically hard to manage. Studies investigating the underlying mechanisms of HIV-SN, and help identify affordable treatment strategies are critical for achieving the national vison for HIV/AIDS “… every person with HIV has high-quality care and treatment,…and can achieve their full potential for health and well-being across the lifespan”.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Nearly 10% of infants are born prematurely, with outcomes including behavioral and cognitive problems, severe disability, and death. There are currently no targeted neuroprotective interventions for preterm infants, and mounting evidence suggests that multiple therapies will need to be applied in order to see robust global neuroprotection. In this proposal we describe complementary in vitro and in vivo techniques in the early preterm ferret to determine combinatorial therapies with the greatest likelihood of benefit – we provide a preclinical platform that can create a pipeline for translation to clinical neuroprotection trials in premature infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Clinical evidence suggests survivors of cardiac arrest experience emotional disorders in addition to well-defined cognitive dysfunction. I have identified a sex and circuit specific amygdala dysfunction in a translational mouse model of cardiac arrest. To further understand the mechanism of this dysfunction and provide molecular targets for translatable therapies, I have proposed the hypothesis that GCI induces dysfunction of LTCC's within the BLA of male mice, thereby contributing to the deficits in amygdala-dependent behavior and LTP.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE In our prior work, we have identified multiple novel congenital anomaly-cancer associations by linking data from population-based birth-defects and cancer registries from four states. Here, we propose to expand this study to seven additional states to analyze a cohort representing >25 million live births and approximately 35% of the US population. We will also search for genetic mechanisms driving these associations through the analysis of whole-genome sequencing data in 20,000 children with congenital anomalies or pediatric cancer, including 2000 sequenced tumors.

PHR: Project Narrative Neuropsychiatric symptoms (NPS) affect up to 97% of patients during the course of AD and may accelerate cognitive declines and institutionalization. In this project, we will assess neural circuits and subtypes underlying dimensions of NPS by leveraging sophisticated machine learning tools. Successful outcomes of the project will lead to an improved understanding of the neurobiological mechanism underlying NPS and its clinical relevance, form a promising new avenue to potentially guide the intervention of NPS and better the management of AD progression, and hence pave the way towards precision medicine of AD dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative This research will validate measures that can be used in the clinic to assess different features of speech that may be affected in children with cerebral palsy. Results will help speech therapists determine if specific aspects of a child’s speech (e.g. voice quality, nasality, breath support, intonation) are disordered or fall within age-expected ranges. Results will also help us understand what problems are responsible for reduced speech intelligibility and will point to directions for speech therapy.

PHR: This K01 International Research Scientist Development Award seeks to provide the applicant experience in primary data collection in Bangladesh, knowledge, and skills in the measurement of sleep health and executive function, advanced statistical methods to examine socio-ecologic determinants of sleep, and community-based participatory research approaches for intervention adaptation to support the applicant's transition to research independence. Through the training embedded in this award, the applicant will develop the skills and expertise necessary to study sleep health of preschool children as a modifiable behavior to improve executive function and reduce the risk of childhood obesity. A feasible and culturally appropriate sleep health promotion intervention adapted during this training has the potential to improve long-term physical and developmental outcomes for millions of children in low- and middle-income countries.

PHR: Metastasis, the spread of cancer throughout the body, is one of the primary causes of cancer death, yet there are no therapeutic strategies to inhibit metastatic invasion. Cancer cells are known to undergo metabolic reprogramming to promote tumor growth, but the metabolic drivers of metastasis are unknown. This research will define the how lipid storage and catabolism fuel metastatic invasion in pancreatic cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol use disorder and alcohol-associated liver disease are associated with changes in the gut microbiome, but the mechanisms by which the gut microbiome increases individuals’ risk for these disorders is not well understood. Our research investigates how ethanol production by gut microbes may increase alcohol use in the host and exacerbate liver disease. These studies will enhance our understanding of how gut microbial metabolites contribute to alcohol use disorder and alcohol-associated liver disease and lead to discovery of improved therapeutic interventions.

ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cigarette smoking remains the leading preventable cause of morbidity and mortality in the United States. SBP-9330 is a positive allosteric modulator of metabotropic glutamate receptor subtype 2 (mGlu2) that modulates glutamatergic neurotransmission in brain circuits involved in nicotine and other substance use disorders that has shown promise in a Phase 1 clinical study. We propose to continue clinical development of SBP-9330 as a novel therapeutic agent for nicotine addiction.

PHR: NARRATIVE Project Narrative: Mobile methadone is a service delivery model that allows vehicles to dispense methadone as an extension of a community opioid treatment program. This project will evaluate the early implementation of the mobile methadone grant program in New York, where the state has invested in creating new units. The aims include interviews with pilot sites and their community partners, surveys with people who are current or potential mobile unit patients, and the use of geospatial methods to identify communities where there is likely to be high need for mobile services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative: Mechanical stimulation of the auditory and vestibular sensory organelle, the hair bundle, generates an electrical current by regulating the opening of mechanically gated ion channels. The mechanical properties of hair bundles shape receptor currents and are postulated to provide filtering to the input. The goal of this proposal is to characterize how, and which hair bundle mechanical properties are important for tuning receptor currents.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Unintended pregnancies are associated with risks to maternal and child health and Latina immigrants face a variety of contraceptive access barriers. This proposal aims to design and test a stakeholder-informed intervention for integrating maternal contraceptive care coordination in pediatric settings serving Latinx families. This award will help me achieve my long-term career goal of leading pediatric primary care interventions that support contraceptive access equity among parents with limited health care access.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE While prostate cancer is strongly influenced by inherited genetic factors, most genetic studies of prostate cancer have been limited to men of European ancestry, limiting our knowledge of genetic risk of prostate cancer in other populations. In this study, we will investigate genetic risk of prostate cancer in the All of Us Research Program across diverse populations, combining findings with previous large-scale prostate cancer genetic studies to strengthen our ability to identify novel genetic risk factors, and we will investigate whether genetic risk of prostate cancer can be modified by lifestyle and socioeconomic factors. We anticipate that findings from this investigation will improve our ability to identify men with increased risk of prostate cancer and aggressive disease, which could have important implications for screening and early detection of prostate cancer.

PHR: Project Narrative Cervical cancer incidence has increased among Puerto Rican women in recent years. This study will evaluate the impact of patient reminders, patient navigators, and self-collection on cervical cancer screening and follow- up care among Puerto Rican women. To inform the future broad-scale implementation of the effective approaches, we will also identify factors influencing the use of these strategies and determine their cost- effectiveness and budget impact.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE People who inject drugs are susceptible to being hospitalized with severe bacterial and fungal infections but may not receive evidence-based treatment for substance use disorder in the hospital. Using national Medicaid data and qualitative methods, we will study how addiction treatments are delivered to people hospitalized with injection-related infections, how those treatments are related to clinical outcomes, and how to improve the addiction-related healthcare for this population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Narrative As a society, we have long recognized the significant risk for language delays facing children born into poverty. Research efforts to understand this risk have appropriately focused on social determinants such as parental interaction styles, parental stress, and parental knowledge of child development, but those factors have never been able to fully account for the problem. This project expands our search for explanatory factors by proposing that poverty-related healthcare inequities put children at risk for premature birth and more-frequent otitis media with effusion, and these biological factors, in turn, delay development of essential auditory skills needed to acquire language on a typical timetable.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Allostatic load (AL) is a complex clinical construct that offers a unique window into the cumulative toll of stress and how it manifests as physiological and psychological dysfunctions. This proposed study will leverage the Asian American (AA) subsample from the All of Us Research Program to understand the cumulative toll of chronic stress through the concept of AL, its behavioral and social-contextual correlates, and how AL manifests as chronic diseases among AAs, in aggregate and by four regional/ethnic subgroups (East Asian, Southeast Asian, South Asian, and Filipino Americans). Through dissemination activities jointly led by the researchers and community/clinical stakeholders, we expect the findings of this study will guide future lifestyle and behavioral interventions to improve resilience and provide clinical implications for personalized medicine to mitigate stress and prevent chronic diseases in understudied AAs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Ischemic stroke is a leading cause of human death and long term disability. We propose to investigate a novel strategy to direct reprogramming endogenous non-neuronal cells into neurons that can gain a balanced microenvironment for cell survival and regeneration in the post-ischemic brain. Comprehensive approaches including cellular, molecular, optogenetics, electrophysiological techniques will be tested in aged male, female mice to promote and verify regenerative repair and functionalities after ischemic stroke.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE T-cell directed therapies are the most exciting recent advances in treatment of patients, but after the initial response patients inevitably relapse to this disease and myeloma remains incurable. We will credential a mouse model for developing novel combinations of drugs with T-cell directed treatments which will allow for their rapid clinical development. These studies will likely inform clinical practice on how combine standard of care agents with immunotherapy.

PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the proposed project is to identify how sex-hormones, inflammation, and obstructive sleep apnea impact the relationship between brain tissue oxygen use and functional impairment in middle-aged underrepresented women with Type 2 Diabetes (DM). Underrepresented women experience the most severe long-term consequences of DM, including development of vascular dementia; however, we have limited insight into the complex causes of poor brain health in this population. This project will advance understanding of brain health as a combined effect of sex-hormone changes, inflammation, and obstructive sleep apnea in underrepresented women with DM prior to development of vascular dementia.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Contact PI (Last, First, Middle): Musiimenta, Angella PROJECT NARRATIVE TB is a serious public health concern which kills more people annually than HIV and malaria combined, and poor treatment adherence limits the success of TB treatment and increases TB transmission. SMS texts and real-time adherence monitoring may provide low-cost and acceptable alternative approaches to supporting TB medication especially in settings where DOT is difficult to implement, while incentives may overcome financial and motivational issues that currently constrain medication adherence. My Mobile Wallet is a novel intervention that utilizes SMS texts to remind medication adherence, and utilize mobile money-based approaches to provide transport to the clinic, and motivate medication adherence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) frequently co-occurs with harmful alcohol use and alcohol use disorder, conferring unique etiological risks for drinking and challenges to successful alcohol treatment. The proposed research will identify affectively-linked cognitions that lead to problem drinking in-the-moment as drinkers experience PTSD symptoms in their real-world settings. Such acute cognitive mechanisms represent key, proximal clinical targets that could be modified through future just-in-time adaptive interventions in an effort to reduce the harms of PTSD-related drinking.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Due to the lack of access to human embryonic and post-natal tissue, we know very little about how our gonads (testes and ovaries) develop and function. Within our proposal, we describe novel methods to develop human male and female gonad organoids “in a dish” that mimic testis and ovary developmental patterns and functions. These gonad organoids can be used for many applications including toxicology analysis, preclinical drug side- effect assessment, patient-specific diagnosis, disease modeling, and development of new reproductive and contraception technologies.

PHR: Project Narrative Multi-omics integration analysis is needed to better understand the underlying biological mechanisms, and hetero- geneity in complex diseases. We will develop and apply integrative and nonlinear Bayesian methods that leverage the rich information in data from multiple omics types to identify biological predictive pathways, important driver biomarkers and clinically molecular disease subtypes. The application of our methods to diverse complex disease datasets will likely provide new data that enable assessment of diagnosis and personalized treatment strategies.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Overall The underserved vulnerable African American, Asian-Pacific American and Hispanic American populations in the PA-NJ-NYC region experience significant cancer-related health disparities across the cancer continuum, from a higher prevalence of cancer risk factors to delayed screening and diagnoses, experiencing more advanced disease, and poorer outcomes. SPEECH has made significant strides toward transforming cancer health disparities research and education; research infrastructure and platforms that enabled investigators to advance cancer health equity in these underrepresented and underserved populations. In the next five years, our Partnership aims to advance cancer health disparities research, training/workforce development, and community-informed interventions by breaking structural, systemic barriers and promoting inclusive excellence across disciplines among basic, clinical and population science researchers, trainees and diverse underserved communities

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Primary muscle tension dysphonia (pMTD) is a functional voice disorder that impacts communication, occupation, and quality of life. Although muscle tension and hyperfunction in the laryngeal system is the prevalent theory underlying patient symptoms of vocal effort, fatigue, and discomfort, previous studies comparing well-vetted physiological laryngeal muscle metrics and self-reported symptoms from our lab suggests pMTD may have more to do with an altered sensory system than aberrant motor patterns. The goal of this proposal is to elucidate the role of sensory mechanisms in pMTD and their relationship to pMTD symptomology.

PHR: NARRATIVE We propose to leverage our successful network and proven operational expertise to develop an optimized, evidence-based approach to early HCC detection in patients with indeterminate liver nodules (ILNs) – a commonly encountered, high-risk group in need of accurate risk stratification and surveillance strategies. Our Translation Research Cancer will leverage our Clinical Validation Center for HCC to efficiently recruit patients with ILNs to (1) validate the effectiveness of our novel biomarker-based risk stratification model, (2) evaluate the effectiveness of surveillance abbreviated MRI and contrast enhanced ultrasound for detecting early-stage HCC, and (3) compare the cost effectiveness, using micro-simulation modeling, of surveillance strategies including a precision screening model for patients with ILNs. Overall, our proposal will transform our approach to early HCC detection in patients with ILNs by validating evidence-based and cost-effective strategies to optimize HCC risk stratification and HCC surveillance.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Lineage plasticity is a developmental process of cell reprogramming employed by cancer cells as a mechanism of therapy resistance. Dr. Linares’s application for the R50 Research Specialist Award will support Dr. Diaz-Meco’s research program focused on elucidating the molecular mechanisms that regulate lineage plasticity in prostate tumors. Unveiling the mechanisms that control this process is crucial to find new targets for castration-resistant prostate cancer.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A major challenge in thwarting the alarming increase in methamphetamine use, especially in men who have sex with other men (MSM), is the high relapse rate, which is often precipitated due to the enhanced emotional reactivity to drug-related cues, a comprehensive examination of which is non-existent in MSM with methamphetamine use disorder. This study aims to objectively quantify reactivity to methamphetamine cues in MSM and test the effectiveness of cognitive reappraisal, a neuroscientifically well-characterized self-regulation technique, in decreasing such reactivity and evaluate its clinical outcomes. Successful completion of this project will advance mechanistic research into the psychophysiological assessment of reactivity to methamphetamine cues in an understudied population, which will aid in the development of evidence-based interventions for relapse prevention in methamphetamine use disorders.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE To address the challenge of how to effectively target neomorphic driver aberrations, where the functional consequences of the gene on tumor cell-intrinsic or tumor microenvironment processes are altered through changes in regulatory processes, binding partners, or cellular location, we propose a CTD2 Center that will employ characterize,  state-of-the-art, high-throughput computational and experimental approaches to identify,  validate, and target novel neomorphic drivers. Focusing on glioma, sarcoma, and endometrial cancers that represent high unmet need where we have identified multiple candidate neomorphic drivers, our application pathways few markers, specific immune  will address three key areas listed in PAR-21-274: (i) improve understanding of gene functions in and cellular wiring important in cancer initiation, progression, and metastasis within the context of a  human tumors; ( ii) identify and confirm biological candidate targets, and possibly associated predictive involved in ancer etiolog y which are amenable to modulation; and (iii) determine how these context-  neomorphic pathways can be harnessed in combination with established strategies that target the  system, and identify mechanisms of resistance. Our collaborative, interdisciplinary team, comprising c Drs. Mills (tumor biology/clinical trials), Deneen (molecular genetics/electroporation tumor models), Liang (computational biology), and Chen (innovative algorithms) will address this challenge through three Specific Aims: (i) to develop computational algorithms for predicting neomorphic driver aberrations; (ii) to identify and elucidate mechanisms underlying potential neomorphic driver aberrations; and (iii) to elucidate therapeutic liabilities engendered by neomorphic driver aberrations.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to enhance the effectiveness of adoptive cellular therapy in three ways: 1) increasing the memory properties of T cells, 2) engineering T cells to resist TGF-β , a T cell suppressive factor found in many cancers, and 3) identifying T cell targets for solid tumors. We will plan to treat patients with stomach and esophageal cancers whose tumors have high levels of TGF-β in a clinical trial using T cells that target a novel antigen found among stomach and esophageal cancers. We believe that this approach, if successful, can be applied to T cells targeting other solid tumors so that we may treat greater numbers of patients who have an unmet need in advanced stages of their disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: NARRATIVE The goal of this project is to develop a highly advanced, commercially viable, bimodal walking-running prosthetic foot that is optimized in two modes (a walking mode and a running mode) and can be reimbursed under the existing L-code reimbursement structure. This novel device would provide individuals with lower limb loss who don’t currently have access to running feet due to the lack of insurance coverage, the opportunity to participate in running, sports, and other social activities with a foot optimized for high-impact activities and the practicality of not having to switch sockets. Since it is optimized for walking and running, the unique design of the Caesar foot provides a substantial increase in functional benefit over the currently available hybrid feet, which although allow for walking and running do so by compromising the foot characteristics for each.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative Loud or extended noise can permanently damage the connections between hair cells—the sensory receptors of hearing—and auditory nerves. The goal of this proposal is to understand how damaged connections between hair cells and auditory nerves are repaired following noise. The results of these studies will identify strategies to stimulate repair in noise exposed ears to prevent subsequent nerve degeneration and hearing loss.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE - NARRATIVE Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension is a debilitating often fatal disease without a cure, a serious unmet need. The inflammatory protein, eNAMPT (extracellular nicotinamide phosphoribosyltransferase), is a key driver of unchecked inflammation and a highly novel therapeutic target and candidate gene in PAH. Our Phase I/II goals are to validate and optimize the eNAMPT- neutralizing humanized mAb, ALT-100, as a therapeutic strategy for PAH, and to complete IND-enabling studies that will facilitate ALT-100 development in human PAH trials.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Irreversible electroporation (IRE) is a surgical ablation technique that is currently being used clinically to treat locally advanced pancreatic cancer. CD40 is an immune receptor that helps to stimulate anti-tumor immune responses. We hypothesize that combining IRE with local delivery of an antibody that stimulates CD40 will enhance the immune effects of IRE. We propose a phase I study to evaluate the safety and preliminary efficacy of this approach. In parallel, we will perform correlative studies to demonstrate that this combination generates specific anti-tumor immune responses.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Randomized controlled trials have shown that screening reduces the incidence of and mortality from colorectal cancer (CRC), the second leading cause of cancer deaths in the United States. However, screening has resulted in a growing cohort of patients with precancerous polyps and little is known about effectively managing their post-polypectomy surveillance. Thus in this proposal, we will develop and validate a comprehensive risk prediction model using polyp characteristics, and clinical and genetic risk factors to tailor surveillance; and determine the optimal strategy for CRC surveillance given an individual’s risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: 8. Project Narrative We will perform a double-blind placebo randomized clinical trial (RCT) in male and female youths 13 to 17 years of age with biopsy-documented hepatic steatosis and clinically diagnosed NAFLD. Eight weeks of treatment with AMS2392 will be compared to placebo. The primary endpoint will be liver fat content as measured by magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) at the outset and after the eight-week intervention.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF VERMONT & ST AGRIC COLLEGE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many women undergoing breast cancer screening and diagnostic imaging are diagnosed with high-risk benign breast lesions, but there is clinical uncertainty as to how aggressively to manage these cases with surgical excision, chemoprevention, and surveillance imaging. We will develop and validate new risk models for short- and long-term breast cancer risk among women with high-risk lesions, which will inform clinical practice and national guidelines for identifying cases that require aggressive interventions while sparing others from unnecessary side effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Chronic sleep disruption causes metabolic changes including increases in polyamines that promote sleep, suggesting that these polyamines act as a homeostatic `equalizer' attempting to fulfill the drive to sleep. This project seeks to improve our understanding of how and why sleep loss and polyamines are linked, which may give long-term insight into regulating sleep need and treating sleep disorders in humans. In many ways the polyamine phenomenon I have noted also reflects changes seen in Alzheimer's disease, which has long been known to occur more often in people with sleep disorders; my study also aims to determine whether polyamine increases are the mechanism that couple sleep disorders to Alzheimer's, which has implications for both prevention and treatment in the long run.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Aggregation of the RNA binding protein TDP-43 has been reported in Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and AD-like dementia in the oldest of the elderly named LATE. We seek to identify how TDP-43 prion-like aggregation regulates the P-body function in neurons, which could provide a mechanism of TDP-43 aggregation-induced neurotoxicity. We will also determine whether P-body components can serve as new neuropathological markers for AD-related dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE : We are developing implantable, miniature, packaged accelerometers designed to sense incoming sound by transducing the motion of the middle ear bones. An implantable sensor is a necessary component of totally implantable auditory prostheses (e.g., hearing aids and cochlear implants), and these assistive hearing devices hold significant promise over existing systems including providing safety-enhancing continuous use, improving usability and cosmetic appearance, and allowing for a more naturalistic sound input using external ear directional cues and gain. We seek to create devices that are on the critical path to a fully implantable auditory prosthesis system, meeting the stringent performance requirements for hearing as well as enabling less invasive surgical approaches.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Current dietary assessment tools available for self-administration in children are limited and rely mostly on caregiver-report for children younger than 14 years. The proposed project will address the outstanding need for a technologically advanced dietary assessment tool specific to the U.S. pediatric population by creating the Pediatric Food Intake System (P-FITS). P-FITS will integrate Viocare’s VioScreen technology with targeted 24- hour food group screeners to improve estimation of usual dietary intakes in U.S. children ages 8-13 years.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) affects ~11% of the population worldwide, significantly impacts patients’ quality of life and imposes a tremendous economic burden due to loss of productivity and high healthcare costs due ot its relapsing-remitting nature. Abdominal (visceral) pain is the defining IBS symptom and is also the hardest to treat. Changes in small intestinal bacteria are associated with abdominal pain, but the mechanism by which they cause visceral pain remains unclear; this is a significant roadblock for developing effective treatments. Our proposal will uncover how specific small intestinal bacterial products can cause abdominal pain and allow development of effective probiotic and other therapies to treat abdominal pain in patients with IBS.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) is a lethal disease with relatively limited therapeutic options, leading to high patient mortality. The overall goal of this project is to identify novel therapeutic regimens that more effectively target heterogeneous malignant stem cell populations that give rise to MDS. These studies stand to substantially improve the efficacy and safety of current therapeutic regimens targeting MDS stem cells, and overall improve outcomes for patients with MDS.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cocaine use is an important topic and is one of the most commonly used drugs in the US, especially in the south, and promotes both initiation and elongation phase of HIV-1 transcription and may affect HIV reservoir activation. Cocaine use is associated with increased inflammation and mortality in antiretroviral treated HIV. This proposal will investigate the mechanisms of host gene isoform expression on functional cure of HIV in cocaine users, which may reveal a novel mechanism on controlling of HIV persistence and help the development of therapeutic strategy for ART-free HIV cure in cocaine users and non-drug users.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Although bariatric surgery procedures provide the most successful long-term treatments for obesity and are associated with numerous health benefits, there is increasing concern about the development of alcohol problems with the two most-used procedures (i.e., sleeve gastrectomy and gastric bypass). The results from our study will lay the foundation for understanding how sleeve gastrectomy, the most performed bariatric surgery, affects how alcohol is processed by the body and how alcohol affects mood and blood sugar in both men and women. These evidence-based data will support patient counseling and monitoring and may help prevent alcohol misuse after bariatric surgery.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A two component sprayable hydrogel barrier that has been previously demonstrated to reduce abdominal adhesion formation will be investigated for the prevention of uterine adhesions following cesarean delivery. The implications of this study are significant as the rate of cesarean delivery now accounts for more than one third of live births, with a particularly high rate observed within minority communities. This Direct Phase II effort will target the demonstration of product safety and efficacy to support uterine healing while mitigating adverse scar or adhesion formation, improving postoperative outcomes for women at higher risk of maternal morbidity or mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: The goal of this project is to characterize the mechanism by which excess heme exposure alters the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle activity to affect the ferroptosis stress, while Nrf2 renders protective effects against this heme-induced metabolic stress to regulate the pathophysiology of sickle cell disease. We will determine the hemin/Nrf2 mediated metabolic, epigenetic and ferroptotic stress response in controlling the cellular fate of erythroid cells under hypoxia and the findings will implicate Nrf2 activation and metabolic regulation as novel treatment options for sickle cell disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Failure of donor islet engraftment in patients living with type 1 diabetes (T1D) occurs due to challenges in the transplant niche including inflammatory stress that follows an immune assault to the allogeneic cell graft. Developing technologies that could identify such adverse events non-invasively and in real time at the site of graft could enable surgical teams to design interventional therapies to halt or reverse damage to the transplanted material, changing the landscape of allogeneic cell therapy. Our proposal describes a novel strategy to monitor intracellular responses to inflammation in insulin-producing cells that will have direct implications for long-term survival and proper function of islet grafts, leading to sustained insulin independence for patients with T1D.

PHR: Label-Free Optical Redox Imaging for Pretreatment Prognosis of Early-Stage Triple Negative Breast Cancer Narrative Abnormal metabolism and redox status have been demonstrated in high-risk breast cancer. Using clinical specimens, mouse xenografts, and cell models, we will validate an optical redox imaging method to predict the risk of progression in triple negative breast cancer (TNBC). The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will identify clinically translatable novel biomarkers to stratify the progression risk in untreated TNBC patients, supporting the NIH’s mission to improve cancer diagnosis and personalized treatment planning.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Unintended nerve damage during surgical procedures is a significant and costly public healthcare delivery problem and current methods for injury prevention via intraoperative nerve monitoring leave substantial room for improvement. The ramifications of increased healthcare costs due to associated medical-liability issues and the significant reductions in quality-of-life issues, including the burgeoning chronic pain management related opioid- related drug overdose epidemic, make addressing this very impactful to society. The proposed development will yield an effective, commercially viable, non-contact multimodality imager that provides realtime intraoperative identification of nerves within the surgical field-of-view to facilitate the prevention of unintended nerve damage during surgical procedures.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project narrative Despite the success of cochlear implants, devices surgically placed in the inner ears of patients with severe hearing loss, the overall speech perception outcomes vary substantially among the individuals who receive them. The main goals of this project are: i) to produce 3-D maps of cochlear histopathology at the electrode- neuron interface in temporal bones from cochlear implant recipients and relate them to clinical measures and outcomes, ii) to apply that knowledge to develop and validate a computational model of the electrode-neuron interface using histopathology, research and clinical measures, and iii) finally, to improve speech perception scores for cochlear implant listeners by focusing and/or deactivating a subset of channels based on electrode- neuron interface estimates. The results will improve our understanding of the effects of hearing loss and cochlear implantation on the histopathology of the auditory nerve, and the relation of those details to clinical measures, ultimately leading to advances in clinical practice and improving hearing outcomes in cochlear implant listeners.

PHR: We have been studying the mechanism by which Canakinumab (an IL-1β blocking antibody) stimulates the immune response to cancer in treated patients. We have discovered that this occurs by blocking the production of immunosuppressive factors by myeloid cells that skew the tumor microenvironment in favor of tumor growth, but also unexpectedly by permitting the immunostimulatory effect of IL-1α on CD8 T cells,. In this proposal, we explore the detailed mechanism of this pathway further, and utilize novel therapeutic compounds to selectively stimulate or block cytokine activity on specific cells, towards the end of designing a definitive immunotherapeutic treatment for cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: OVERALL COMPONENT: PROJECT NARRATIVE Falls and cognitive impairments are disabling and currently untreatable features of Parkinson disease. University of Michigan scientists developed evidence that falls and cognitive impairments arise from degeneration of brain cells using the chemical messenger acetylcholine. By integrating neuroimaging, behavioral, and physiological studies in patients with Parkinson’s disease and in animal models, we aim to further dissect the relationships between falls, cognitive impairments, and abnormalities of these brain cells.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Perinatal depression is the most common complication of pregnancy, leading to impaired health for the individual, family, and community. While the collaborative care model (CCM) has demonstrated efficacy for treatment of depression in primary care, it is rarely utilized in obstetric care due to gaps in effectiveness and implementation outcomes. This rigorous stepped-wedge randomized trial 1) enhances the CCM by embedding a multi-level approach to achieving equity in mental health care, 2) evaluates the effectiveness of the CCM on mental health outcomes, 3) analyzes the impact of the CCM on racial and ethnic health disparities, and 4) optimizes an implementation strategy package via a hybrid type 2 implementation-effectiveness design with the ultimate goal of achieving broad-scale implementation of equity-centered perinatal CCMs within obstetric care sites nationally.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research will test several novel hypotheses regarding the interactions between synaptic zinc, glutamate, GABA, NMDA receptors (NMDARs), AMPARs and GABARs. These interactions are fundamental to our understanding of synaptic transmission and synaptic plasticity, as well as sound processing in health and hearing loss. Because these processes are found in many brain areas and are associated with several disorders, such as epilepsy, hyperekplexia, autism, schizophrenia, Alzheimer’s disease, hearing loss, tinnitus and pain processing, this research is relevant to those aspects of the NIH mission aimed at improving health through understanding pathophysiological mechanisms in disorders causing disability.

PHR: NARRATIVE We propose to translate a novel liquid biopsy platform for early cancer detection. Specifically, we will apply a forward-thinking nano-plasmonic platform for comprehensive, high-throughput molecular analyses of extracellular vesicles (EVs). We will rigorously address EVs' clinical utility to detect high- grade serous ovarian cancer in high-risk patient cohorts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Pacific-Stanford PRIMED Program –Project Narrative The Pacific-Stanford PRIMED Program will foster a culture where oral health clinicians and students view practice-based research as a routine component of their regular daily clinical practice, and train the next generation of clinical oral health researchers to effectively translate biomedical research findings into their clinical practice to ensure optimal oral health outcomes. The program will provide clinical research skills development for dental students and clinicians, through formal training as well as mentorship. The University of the Pacific and Stanford University have a longstanding history of collaboration and are ideal partners to engage research faculty, clinical faculty, students, and residents to conduct practice-based research in three areas: sleep medicine, oral cancer and developing the Pacific-Stanford biobank.

PHR: Narrative: The 5-year survival rate for children with metastatic osteosarcoma (OSA) is extremely low, hovering around 20%-30%, a rate that has not improved in over 30 years. Novel therapies are in critically needed, specifically molecules capable of inhibiting the process of OSA metastasis. This SBIR Phase 2 application will support IND enablement of an immunomodulating peptide with unique anti-tumor and anti-fibrotic properties that PharmaIN is developing for the treatment of osteosarcoma and other cancer types.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative The applicant group led by the Principal Investigator (PI) has conducted a series of Early Detection Research Network (EDRN) defined Phase 1-3 biomarker studies that have led to the identification and development of a panel of circulating proteins as well as autoantibodies directed against tumor proteins (including TP53 and novel citrullinated antigens) for detection of breast and ovarian cancers. The primary translational objective of this project is to advance candidate biomarkers for detection of breast and ovarian cancers via testing in pre- diagnostic plasmas from the Prostate Lung Colorectal and Ovarian (PLCO) cohort and to develop a multi-analyte blood-based biomarker panel based on protein and autoantibody biomarkers for risk assessment of breast and ovarian cancers. The resulting biomarker test would then be integrated with other risk models based on individual subject characteristics, such as the Gail Model for breast cancer, to deliver personalized cancer risk assessment and inform on a need for further pertinent tests that enable earlier diagnosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF PUERTO RICO MED SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the leading cause of dementia worldwide in older individuals, while HIV associated neurocognitive disorder (HAND) is prevalent in 20-50% of people with HIV, who live longer due to successful antiviral therapy, being the leading cause of dementia in younger individuals. The crosstalk between the signaling pathways of AD and HAND warrant studies to better understand the neuropathologic mechanisms and identify novel candidates for therapies. Studying the altered interferon type 1 immune response in monocytes will yield novel information on how interactions between immunologic signaling and the CNS contribute to cognitive impairment.

PHR: Project Narrative We will determine 1) how tumors and the tumor microenvironment accumulate fatty acids and use them to induce lipid peroxidation in tumor-infiltrating CD8+ TTE or TEM cells; 2) how lipid peroxidation induces CD8+ TTE or TEM cell ferroptosis and dysfunction in tumor beds, and 3) explore new methods to counteract fatty acid effects and to restore T cell function in cancer patients. We hypothesize that inhibiting T cell ferroptosis will effectively enhance the therapeutic efficacy of immunotherapy in cancer patients. Completing this project will allow us and others to identify novel therapeutic targets and develop new methods to improve the efficacy of current cancer immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE Parkinson’s Disease is an age-associated neurodegenerative disorder affecting nearly 1 million Americans, and present treatments provide only symptomatic benefit, with disease progression resulting in diminished efficacy and often intolerable motor complications. Mitochondrial dysfunction is tightly involved in the loss of dopaminergic neurons central to the disease, raising the possibility clearance of damaged mitochondria via increased mitophagy may hold disease modifying benefit. We developed potent and selective USP30 inhibitors that promote mitophagy in cells, which we now propose to evaluate in vivo for their potential as first-in-class therapeutics to stop or slow progression of Parkinson’s Disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The patient perspective is essential for managing unilateral vocal fold paralysis, which affects 16 million persons in the US who have significant difficulty communicating, eating, and breathing. Patients with acute paralysis have profound mental and physical health effects that limit everyday activities and demonstrate variable responses to treatment due to unique patient characteristics and baseline disability. We therefore address the need to individualize how we assess treatment effectiveness using patient-reported outcome measures (PROM) at the point of care by using an innovative statistical machine-learning approach that accounts for the value the individual patient puts on outcomes related to voice, psychosocial, and swallowing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Alcohol addiction is a chronic brain condition that severely damages the lives of affected patients and their families, exerting a tremendous burden on society at large with currently available treatments not showing efficacy in most patients. An emerging research field for treatment of alcohol addiction is the interface of metabolic and epigenetic regulation in brain function; in this proposal, we seek to clarify whether alcohol consumption engages a novel epigenetic-metabolic pathway, via acetate signaling from liver alcohol breakdown directly to neuronal gene regulation. This work will help to discover new targets for novel treatment strategies and therapeutic interventions for alcohol use disorders.

PHR: Project Narrative Clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC) is the most common form of kidney cancer and exhibits multiple nearly universal metabolic alterations compared to adjacent healthy tissue. The proposed research herein builds on prior studies involving the gluconeogenic enzyme Fructose-1,6- bisphosphate 1 (FBP1), urea cycle enzymes, and lipid accumulation as defining hallmarks of this disease. Characterization of consistent and dramatic metabolic changes, and their downstream outputs, has revealed novel strategies for ccRCC treatment that can be extended to other cancers with similar metabolic features, such as hepatocellular carcinoma and soft tissue sarcoma.

PHR: Project Narrative Pediatric cancer, the number one cause of disease-related death in school age children, is still largely treated with old approaches such as cytotoxic chemotherapy, radiation, and surgery. These childhood malignancies typically express cancer-promoting proteins that make for challenging drug targets and generally have been less responsive to immunotherapy approaches that have revolutionized the care of subsets of adults with cancer. We will apply innovative, transformative approaches in functional genomics and chemical biology to overcome these challenges toward new, paradigm-shifting therapies for children with cancer.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Genetic defects in the cohesin complex member Stag2 are recurrently mutated in various human cancers and lead to disruption of tissue-specific gene expression through DNA looping. Using cutting-edge epigenomic techniques, primary patient samples, and a reversible in vivo Stag2 mouse, we will map Stag2-specific chromatin looping in transcriptional regulation of hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells and functionally assess their contribution to the lineage fate and self-renewal. Using these techniques in combination with sequential mutagenesis of the AML driver mutation FLT3ITD, we will determine the effects of altered chromatin structure on leukemogenesis, the requirement of Stag2 for leukemia maintenance, and the effects on therapeutic response.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Placental dysfunction results from abnormal development of this organ early in gestation, and is the underlying cause of adverse pregnancy outcomes, including miscarriage, preeclampsia, and fetal growth restriction. Pregnancies affected by Trisomy 21 are at high risk of miscarriage and fetal growth restriction, at least partly due to abnormalities of placental development. This project will use placental cells, derived directly from normal and Trisomy 21-affected placentas or pluripotent stem cells in order to identify cellular defects underlying placental dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative About 40% of the human genome consists of viral DNA sequences derived from ancient retroviruses, and functions of these retroviral sequences in vascular dementia are not well understood. The TREX1 protein regulates these retroelements in our genome, and patients with inherited mutations in TREX1 develop retinal vasculopathy with cerebral leukoencephalopathy (RVCL), a vascular dementia that causes disability and premature death in 100% of affected individuals. We propose to determine how TREX1 mutants regulate genomic DNA and retroelements to cause this devastating, inherited small vessel disease of the brain.

PHR: Project Narrative Cryogenic electron microscopy has transformed the field of structural biology in the last few years. Despite the tremendous progress in determining structures by cryo-EM, substantial challenges remain in data processing and specimen preparation for proteins that form tubular arrays. New tools will be developed that facilitate structure determination of medically relevant tubular samples such as Drp1, dynamin, and Opa1, as well as other samples that prove resistant to cryogenic preparation.

PHR: Project Narrative. Despite the potential toxicity of liquid nicotine, there is currently no treatment for acute nicotine poisoning. A first-in-class enzyme therapeutic for acute nicotine toxicity is proposed. The enzyme will sequester nicotine and catabolize it to a non-toxic component, thereby reducing its effective concentration at sites of action, the nicotinic-type acetylcholine (cholinergic) receptors (nAChRs), which in turn is anticipated to alter the nicotine’s toxic effects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Approximately 45,000 people sustain partial hand amputations in the United States every year, and amputation of full fingers can cause physical, psychosocial, and economic damage to an individual. There is currently only one powered prosthetic finger available to people with partial hand amputations in the United States, and fragility of these devices is often reported. In this project, Point Designs proposes to develop and commercialize a robust, powered prosthetic finger utilizing an electromechanical design that appropriates anatomy, produces user- defined forces and speeds, and withstands the rigors of everyday life.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Overall The underserved vulnerable African American, Asian-Pacific American and Hispanic American populations in the PA-NJ-NYC region experience significant cancer-related health disparities across the cancer continuum, from a higher prevalence of cancer risk factors to delayed screening and diagnoses, experiencing more advanced disease, and poorer outcomes. SPEECH has made significant strides toward transforming cancer health disparities research and education; research infrastructure and platforms that enabled investigators to advance cancer health equity in these underrepresented and underserved populations. In the next five years, our Partnership aims to advance cancer health disparities research, training/workforce development, and community-informed interventions by breaking structural, systemic barriers and promoting inclusive excellence across disciplines among basic, clinical and population science researchers, trainees and diverse underserved communities
