IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Autism contains a puzzling conundrum: Although 70% of autistic individuals demonstrate age-appropriate language and cognitive abilities on standardized tests, they nonetheless experience significant communication breakdowns during everyday interactions that negatively affect their social, educational, and occupational outcomes. This proposal advances research and clinical practice by defining clinically meaningful markers of conversational success in 560 autistic and neurotypical adolescents participating in (1) neurotype-concordant (autistic-autistic or neurotypical-neurotypical) and (2) neurotype-discordant (autistic-neurotypical) dyads. By combining traditional standardized language tests with innovative psycholinguistic measures derived from spontaneous natural conversations, a key output of this project will be clinically useful and ecologically valid profiles of communication strengths and weaknesses that can be used to inform personalized interventions focused on improving autistic adolescents’ conversational success.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Nigeria has a substantial burden of cancer that could be prevented through enhancing vaccination services. C3-RISE is a comprehensive implementation science partnership between the Nigerian Institute of Medical Research, Saint Louis University, and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill that open new horizons in equitable cancer control and builds sustainable capacity for high-quality implementation science to control cancer using vaccines. This project will increase equity, expand uptake and sustainment of evidence-based vaccination services, and develop a pipeline of Nigerian implementation science researchers for continued success.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Liver disease is the second leading cause of non-AIDS related death in persons living with HIV (PLWH). Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is by far the leading form of chronic liver disease in the U.S., afflicting approximately 30% of adults. However, the incidence of NAFLD is even higher among PLWH with rates as high as 53% and there is a disproportionate burden of progressive fibrosis compared with HIV(-) NAFLD. The studies in this proposal will clarify the mechanistic link between HIV, NAFLD, the YAP/TAZ pathway, and fibrosis, and in so doing uncover novel targets for inhibitors of hepatic fibrosis and liver damage.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative Motor vehicle crashes are a leading cause of unintentional morbidity and mortality among children in the United States and a leading cause of brain injury. A total of 3,355 children ages 0 to 8 died as an occupant in a motor vehicle crash from 2016 to 2020 and hundreds of thousands more had injuries that required treatment. We aim to develop a significantly easier to use intuitive harness tensioning system that improves child safety seats and better protects children riding in motor vehicles.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Central sleep apnea, a condition where people stop breathing in their sleep, can be caused by medications used to treat opioid use disorder. This project will evaluate whether central sleep apnea, by worsening sleep and causing low blood oxygen levels, may lead to nighttime arousal and emotional distress, which in turn may increase risk of drug relapse in patients receiving treatment for opioid use disorder.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Human papillomavirus (HPV)-associated cervical cancer remains one of the leading causes of cancer mortality in People Living with Human Immunodeficiency Virus ([HIV] PLWH) in underserved, low- and middle-income countries. PLWH have evidence of premature aging, which could contribute to cervical cancer progression and responses to chemoradiation therapy (CRT). To identify potential biological biomarkers of aging, the proposed project will focus on measuring differences in epigenetic changes between HIV-positive vs HIV-negative cervical cancer patients before and after CRT and correlating these changes with immunological phenotype for use in future clinical studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Predicting epilepsy outcomes over time for a given patient is a significant challenge due to the large variability in the patient-specific course of disease. We propose to leverage our access to data from the Human Epilepsy Project, a large observational study of 450 patients with focal epilepsy, to develop novel prediction models for seizure trajectories that address substantial variability and clumping in seizure frequency. This work will assistant patients and clinicians identify optimal treatment earlier; for instance, this could help limit the amount of time patients are receiving ineffective medication and improve time to epilepsy surgical evaluation when indicated.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Membrane transporters in the blood vessels of the brain serve as gatekeepers to allow access of essential nutrients into the brain and to facilitate elimination of potentially toxic compounds. In this research, we will systematically identify psychoactive drugs, nutrients and constituents of dietary supplements that are transported by membrane transporters in brain capillaries. This research will lead to a new understanding of transporters in human brain capillaries as well as sharable data and resources that will be available to the scientific community.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: While chronic visceral pain afflicts about 10% of the population globally, including in the U.S., and produces life-long physical and psychiatric burdens on patients and their families, this syndrome has no known causes and is without satisfactory therapeutic options. This proposal will explore the novel disease mechanism that there is a previously unrecognized link between hormones secreted by the intestine and the development of hypersensitivity of nerves in the gut. The working hypothesis suggests that those hormones can be used as oral drugs to eliminate the hypersensitivity of nerves in the gut, to treat and prevent chronic visceral pain.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This application aims to investigate the impact of HIV brain infection and amyloidopathy on ischemic microinfarcts, a major comorbidity in people living with HIV (PLWH), in the context of aging. The central hypothesis is that a procoagulant environment driven by elevated Serpine-1 levels contributes to increased risk of ischemic events, delayed post-ischemic recovery, and enhanced amyloidopathy in HIV-infected brain. The obtained results will have a potential to generate new therapeutic targets and strategies in aging and HIV-1 infection, especially in prevention and treatment of cerebrovascular comorbidities, including ischemic events.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The objective of this project is to determine the genes regulating tumor composition and facilitating tumor growth and resistance to immunity & immunotherapy, with the goal of identifying factors that can be targeted to enhance tumor immunity and improve cancer treatment. We will focus on four highly prevalent and deadly cancers - non small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC), high grade serous ovarian cancer (HGSOC), and oral squamous cell carcinomas (OSCC), and utilize large-scale genomic and transcriptomic data from patient tumors, spatial functional genomics, and computational analysis, to reach our goal.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  It is imperative to develop new noninvasive tools for the detection of curable hepatocellular carcinoma, as this improves survival in these patients. We propose a rigorous and systematic evaluation of liquid biopsy (detection of tumor components released to the bloodstream) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)-based radiomics in a large multiracial multi-institutional cohort of early-stage HCC and controls at high risk for HCC development. Our project is very timely and uniquely positioned to improve early HCC detection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Stress plays a key role in the development and maintenance of alcohol use disorder (AUD) and can trigger relapse. The stress response is regulated by the corticotrophin-releasing factor (CRF) system, and we have developed in vitro chemical probes that inhibit the CRFBP-CRF2 complex. We propose to develop systemically active, small molecule CRFBP-CRF2 probes to validate CRFBP-CRF2 as a target in vivo and to facilitate the development of effective drug treatments targeting CRFBP for AUD.

PHR: Narrative Rapid initiation of enteral feeding via enteral feeding tubes (FTs) is essential to high-risk critically ill elderly patients, however, ensuring accurate FT location requires increased personnel time, increased healthcare costs and potentially detrimental delays in enteral nutrition. Through Phase I and Phase II development, our device offers real-time, accurate mapping of FT location and was granted 510k clearance by the FDA. In this Commercialization Readiness Pilot (CRP) project, we propose to verify automated early detection of airway insertion, refine our second-generation FT with reduced cost of goods to enable commercial launch, and submit a 510(k) application to the FDA.

PHR: Narrative Brain aging is the main risk factor for age-related neurodegeneration; however, this process is not well- understood in human cells which impedes our understanding of how to treat neurodegeneration. Here we will use innovative artificial intelligence analysis of multi-omic brain data sets to identify candidate drivers of brain aging. We will modulate these drivers in hiPSC-derived brain cells and assay for cellular aging phenotypes that are also relevant to neurodegeneration.

PHR: Cystinosis is a genetic disease characterized by accumulation of cystine crystals in multiple organs including cornea. The current treatment regimen is 8 drops of cysteamine every day, which is effective, but tedious and could lead to poor compliance. Our goal is to replace the 8xdaily drop treatment with a daily disposable contact lens which will provide similar delivery to the drops but improve compliance and address other deficiencies of the current formulation including side effects due to preservatives and acidic pH of the formulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The role of maternal care in offspring health is widely accepted, but recent research has shown that paternal care contributes unique advantages to offspring, including significant impacts on survival and psychological development. Our research will fill a critical gap in the literature by providing novel insight into the genetic and neural basis of evolved variation in paternal care behavior in natural populations. This work will contribute to our understanding of the biology of paternal care in a vertebrate system and may reveal insights into the mechanistic basis of variation in this complex behavioral trait in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The nuclear envelope (NE) and the nuclear pore complex (NPC) embedded within the NE are vital structures for eukaryotic cells, and mutations in genes encoding NE and NPC components are intimately linked with a series of human diseases that are collectively known as nuclear envelopathies. However, our knowledge of the category and diverse functions of NE proteins in eukaryotic kingdoms, especially beyond humans and yeasts, remains limited. This research aims to comprehensively unravel the NE protein inventory in the eukaryotic life domain and explore novel, yet critical and conserved, roles of the NPC in facilitating rapid mitotic progression in undifferentiated cells and regulating gene expression via gene gating mechanism, which may offer key insights into fundamental cell biology and potential therapeutic avenues and impact fields ranging from genetics to medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative: Alcohol addiction is a major public health burden. DREADDs (designer receptors exclusively activated by designer drugs) are chemogenetic tools primarily used for neuroscience research, but recently appreciated for their potential as therapeutics for neurological disorders, including addictive behaviors like alcohol addiction. A complication of the implementation of chemogenetic tools is that the viral vectors used to deliver them, such as an adeno-associated virus (AAV), must be reliably and accurately placed within target brain structures for precise viral expression and resultant clinical effect from the DREADDs. This project develops a system that leverages oscillation of a thin injection cannula for reduced insertion and friction forces relative to larger standard cannulas, improving the targeting and reliability of precise injections to deep brain locations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative. The proposed project aims to develop a commercially available image recognition platform for operational larval surveillance of medically relevant mosquito species, initially capable of identification of 10 key species to Placer County, CA as initial proof of concept. The project will involve validating optics for larval species identification and modifying an existing imaging device to achieve these requirements, building a high-quality image dataset with the device, and training a computer vision system to identify mosquito larvae species. This tool will enable mosquito control organizations to make same-day control decisions based on larval surveillance data targeted to species of concern, leapfrogging conventional larval surveillance practices, and providing accurate and timely data on mosquito populations and potential disease transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Metalloenzymes have been identified as drug targets in virtually every therapeutic area, including anti-inflammatory, antibiotics, antivirals, and anticancer, but the complicated nature of metal interactions with potential drug molecules makes the already difficult drug development process even harder for this class of targets. This project aims to develop a software tool that can accurately predict the binding affinities of metalloenzymes and potential drug molecules, and therefore help research scientists more quickly discover drug candidates suitable for preclinical testing and beyond. Currently available molecular modeling methods are unable to make accurate enough predictions to help scientists with the design of metalloenzyme-targeting drugs; therefore, the proposed project will provide a new capability with significant impact on the development of treatments for human disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The aggressive and unpredictable nature of metastatic clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC) is reflected by high rates of morbidity and mortality. While drastic improvements to post-surgical surveillance protocols have been made over recent years, early identification of progression from primary tumor to a disseminated metastatic disease state remains a difficult challenge for physicians and frequently results in detrimental delays of therapeutic intervention. LAGRANGE SCIENTIFIC is developing an innovative technology that accurately and specifically identifies which patients at the time of primary tumor resection will experience a disseminated ccRCC metastasis, and with Phase II support, will mature this highly accurate prognostic test for later progression to metastasis into a regulatory-approved laboratory testing service.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Proposal Narrative As a strategy combining health protection with health promotion to prevent worker injury and advance well- being, the broadened scope of Total Worker Health (TWH®) makes it a promising holistic approach to address the sign production, situation, and individual factors associated with sign language interpreter injury development. The overall objective of this study will employ implementation strategies to adapt and evaluate an integrated TWH® program and pilot test its efficacy on interpreter well-being. These project aims align with objective six of the National Occupational Research Agenda, Healthy Work Design and Well-Being Cross- Sector Program, “improve the safety, health, and well-being of workers through healthier work design and better organizational practices.”

PHR: Project Narrative: The study aims to develop an image-based platform to manage and improve the outcomes of Diabetic Foot Ulcers (DFUs) by performing an automated image analysis of complications associated with impaired healing. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the demonstrated effectiveness of family-centered preventive interventions (FCPI) to prevent cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors during childhood, implementation barriers have led to their limited adoption in pediatric primary care. Two randomized effectiveness-implementation trials of the Family Check-Up 4 Health program conducted in several primary care systems have demonstrated significant positive effects on child and family health behaviors associated with CVD risk and have identified barriers to multiple implementation outcomes limiting scale-up and public health impact. Multiple implementation strategies developed in partnership with a standing Community Advisory Board will be integrated and tested in the proposed biphasic study to assess their effects on identified implementation barriers, with the goal of promoting widespread adoption and sustained implementation of family-based CVD prevention in primary care.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The causal role of aging on Alzheimer's disease (AD) risk variants in neuronal or glial cells is unresolved. We propose a team science approach to integrate computational and experimental models of aging, towards deconvolving the gene x environment impact of aging on gene expression, cellular aging phenotypes, and genetic risk for AD. We hope to find insights into the mechanism of disease initiation and progression in AD, in order to one day reverse the disrupted molecular pathways that contribute to this debilitating disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Many kidney failure patients receiving hemodialysis rely on vascular access via an implanted prosthetic arteriovenous shunt graft. These grafts typically suffer from flow blockages and infections, requiring frequent interventions to restore function. The severity of these issues can be reduced through improved graft integration with the surrounding tissue by applying an outer layer of our novel porous biomaterial scaffold onto conventional grafts. Effectiveness has been demonstrated in preclinical and clinical studies and this project now aims at obtaining FDA clearance for market introduction. v0.9

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A method for isolating cells with interesting spatiotemporal properties from three-dimensional cultures can be a powerful technique to understand how genes determine cellular functions, identify novel drug targets, and engineer effective cellular therapeutics. However, existing cell isolation techniques cannot retrieve cells from three-dimensional cultures with single-cell precision. The authors plan to address this unmet need by developing a platform/workflow that can isolate individual cells from 3D cultures based on their spatial and temporal characteristics.

PHR: Gonorrhea is the second most common bacterial STI and affects over 87 million people annually, globally. The emergence of multidrug-resistant gonococcal strains worldwide has severely limited treatment options. Safe and effective therapeutics against gonorrhea are urgently needed. Here, we will develop and evaluate complement-based therapeutics that provides broad protection against both PorB1A and PorB1B strains using a combination of our lead Fc3/FH* with FH6-7/Fc or C4BP/Fc.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: The architecture of the retina is established during development by the generation and maintenance of a balanced complement of retinal cell types, which can be disrupted in pathological situations, including retinal neurodegeneration. The role of immune cells, such as resident microglia, in the development and function of the retina is poorly understood. This study will investigate the molecular pathways governing the properties of developing retinal microglia, and how this influences development of the retina itself. PHR: Project Narrative There are currently no FDA-approved treatments for methamphetamine addiction. Our previous studies show that treatment with MHC Class II constructs can improve cognitive function, decrease drug-seeking behavior, and reduce inflammation following methamphetamine use in animal models. This proposal aims to move our current generation construct, DRhQ, from the lead optimization stage to the preclinical development stage by evaluating treatment efficacy and relevant biomarkers, which are critical steps in advancing the drug into the clinic.

PHR: Project Narrative  Intermittent exotropia, a periodic outwards deviation of the eyes, is a condition that affects millions of Americans. Treatment has been hindered by a lack of knowledge about its prognosis, inability to quantify its severity, and limited understanding of its neural mechanism. This research project will validate the use of ambulatory eye tracking glasses for measurement of exotropia occurrence rate and uncover the contribution of retinal ganglion cells projecting to a midbrain center controlling eye movements.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Features of employment precarity are associated with adverse behavioral health outcomes; however, most studies have not examined employment precarity comprehensively, nor have they explored increasing employment precarity and risk of poor behavioral health over time. The proposed project will provide a mechanism to measure employment precarity comprehensively while accounting for its dynamic nature over time and will elucidate the relationships between employment precarity, employment variability, and behavioral health longitudinally. Determining the relationships between these phenomena across the life course can help to identify opportunities for more targeted research to pinpoint possible interventions to prevent or reduce adverse behavioral health outcomes in the US workforce.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Employment Precarity and Adverse Behavioral Health Outcomes in the NLSY79 and 97 Cohorts
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project investigates the impacts of drone-induced distractions on construction workers (i.e., material handling laborers and roofers) at heights. The relationships between the distraction impacts and the drone operations are quantified. The project will help to prevent fatal and non-fatal injuries related to falls, slips, and trips due to the distractions induced by emerging aerial robotics and automation technologies in construction.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Impacts of Drone Distractions on Working Safety at Heights in Construction
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The provision of nursing care often involves risk taking procedures that can result in injury to the provider. Yet, little is known about the unit-level prevalence of these injuries, the contributing factors and the associated costs. Understanding the mechanism of workplace injuries among acute care nurse can improve care delivery and nurse and patient outcomes.

PROJECT_TITLE: Workplace Injuries among Acute Care Nurses: Implications for the Healthcare System

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative This pilot study will be the first thorough approach to consider the comprehensive ecosystem leading to highway struck-by hazards. The proposed approach makes use of combination of objective and subjective methods, to measure workers’ cognitive load relative to hazard recognition performance under various conditions and provide practical guideline for designing interventions that address a practical need, instead of fitting a technology to an issue. As such, this project is expected to provide important and impactful new knowledge that can help guide and facilitate industry implementation (e.g., when, how, and which emerging technologies to use “safely”).
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Pilot Study to Investigate and evaluate Factors impacting Highway Construction Workers' Hazard Recognition Performance
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project addresses a critical research gap specific to the U.S., wherein there have been no large, nationally representative, cohort studies of the association between long working hours and CVD mortality by applying a Research to Practice (r2p) approach in reducing the occupational mortality burden of CVD. The short- and long- term outputs and outcomes would be to create an active database of evidence on this association. This project has national and global relevance, and addresses goals set by the National Occupational Research Agenda (NORA) Health Work Design and Well-being sector and the NORA Cancer, Reproductive, Cardiovascular, and Other Chronic Disease Prevention cross-sectors.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Do long working hours increase the risk of cardiovascular disease mortality? Evidence from the U.S. National Health Interview Survey 1997-2015
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
PHR: Narrative Although workers in the drying cleaning and laundry industry are exposed to synthetic fibers (containing microplastics) by handling clothing and linens every day, these workers’ exposure to microplastics is mainly unknown. Further, the effects of work-related factors (workforce, workplace, and work hazards) on exposure to microplastics among these workers are not investigated. This proposed R21 study, in response to the National Occupational Research Agenda: the Services Sector and the Cross-sector of Healthy Work Design, will provide helpful information for workers, industry, local, state, and national agencies, and policymakers to develop a mitigation strategy for reducing workers’ exposure to microplastics in this business sector.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Inhalation exposure assessment to microplastics for workers in the laundry and dry cleaning industry
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Safety and Occupational Health Study Section[SOH]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol abuse causes or exacerbates many diseases including neurological disease, and is a leading cause of preventable death in the United States. Much of the toxicity associated with ethanol, including metabolic dysfunction, is due to the production of its reactive metabolite acetaldehyde, which in the brain is produced primarily by the enzymes catalase and CYP2E1. In this proposal, we seek to understand how chronic binge drinking changes acetaldehyde production by CYP2E1 inside brain regions, and the consequences on cellular metabolism and stress.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Membrane proteins regulate cellular processes through conformational changes across the plasma membrane, yet such transmembrane processes are often inaccessible with current tools. We will advance spectroscopic and biochemical methods and, through these advances, probe the membrane proteins relevant to treatments for cancer and antibiotic resistant infection. The proposed studies will introduce an approach to uncover the biophysical mechanisms of this important class of biomolecules.

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative This grant will design and measure a novel stakeholder- and technology-based framework aimed at improving dementia screening and diagnosis, secondary cardiovascular preventive measures, and utilization of anticholinergics, in primary care settings, and among disadvantaged and racial and ethnic minority populations at risk for dementia. The study will be in the context of a pilot Embedded Pragmatic Clinical Trial (ePCT) that is optimized with/for the stakeholders (patients, caregivers, primary care providers) and leverages validated methods based on electronic health records, artificial intelligence, and modern clinical workflow integration. This pilot ePCT will pave way for larger ePCTs that address disparities in timely diagnosis, access to specialists, and evidence-based care delivery.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gene expression plays a central role in immune regulation and is often affected in immune diseases and during viral infections. The goal of the proposed research is to determine the rules governing the regulation of immune genes and to determine the mechanisms by which viruses hijack immune expression programs to favor viral replication. The findings and principles uncovered by these studies will lay a foundation for the design of novel therapeutic strategies.

PHR: Project Narrative The Children’s Oncology Group (COG) brings together more than 10,000 experts to refine front-line therapy for childhood cancer, study novel approaches to patients with recurrent disease, advance understanding of cancer biology, and improve supportive care and quality of life for cancer survivors. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anxiety symptoms are very common among people with neurodegenerative movement disorders, including Huntington’s disease (HD) and Parkinson’s disease (PD). These symptoms cause significant burden for patients and caregivers, and evidence-based treatments are lacking. This project includes development and preliminary evaluation of a novel, easily accessible, web-based psychological intervention (MindTrails- Movement) for treating anxiety in HD and PD.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We propose to develop a set of DNA-nanostructure-based tools for controlling membrane shape, tension and dynamics in a programmable way with high precision. PHR: NARRATIVE Hispanic cancer patients and survivors face social and structural inequalities perpetuating mental health disparities while no interventions exist to address these health inequities perpetrated by structural, social, and social-environmental adverse events. This project is innovative because it disrupts traditional psycho-oncology mental health care to address upstream structural (limited access to psycho-oncology mental health care and psychological distress screening), social (mental health stigma), and biological (psychological stress and inflammation biomarkers) determinants of mental health among Hispanic cancer patients and survivors. The team anticipates this project will push a transformative population-level impact through a multilevel approach that empowers communities to understand and address mental health among individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Colorado Clinical and Translational Sciences Institute’s (CCTSI) T32 Pre-Doctoral Training Program aligns and supports the goals of NCATS to ensure that a diverse pool of highly trained scientists is available in adequate numbers and in appropriate research areas to carry out the nation’s clinical and translational science research agenda. Our proposed Team Oriented Training across the Translational Sciences Spectrum (TOTTS) program will support pre-doctoral trainees’ (biomedical/bioengineering PhD students, population health/health outcomes PhD students, clinician doctoral students) competency development and foster characteristic development for translational research scientists. Evaluation will focus on our ability to achieve program objectives and goals of attracting and supporting the training and persistence in the field of individuals from diverse (especially underrepresented) backgrounds that have the potential to infuse clinical translational science and research with new perspectives and approaches that are efficient and effective.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Undernutrition is a critical TB comorbidity and drives the TB epidemic in India. The NUTRIENT-India study will help quantify the long-term impact of nutritional interventions on TB incidence and mortality among persons with and without TB in India and define the most cost-effective nutritional interventions in the Indian context. Estimating cost-effectiveness of nutritional supplementation to mitigate the TB epidemic in India may incentivize Indian policymakers to wield nutritional policy effectively to attain their TB elimination goals.

PHR: Veterans are at increased risk for hematopoietic system diseases like leukemia. The only cure for many patients with these diseases is hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HCT). However, the new immune system from the transplant (graft) often launches a multisystem attack against the patient (host), termed chronic graft-versus-host-disease (cGVHD). Treatment options are inadequate, and cGVHD will kill most long- term HCT survivors who overcome their original cancer. Clinical trials of promising new treatments as well as the ability to make optimal patient care decisions are thwarted by the absence of assessments to determine whether patients are responding to treatment or progressing. The proposed research will study the ability to objectively and reliably measure cGVHD in skin by a combination of innovative handheld, noninvasive tools: 3D photography, artificial intelligence, and the Myoton device. This may enable evidence-based, personalized cGVHD therapies and guide treatment decisions for improved outcomes in Veteran and other HCT survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative The complex sensory and structural defects of craniofacial disorders can be traced to an early period in embryogenesis, with the emergence of four multipotent cell lineages at the neural plate border. Of these four, the neural crest and pre-placodal lineages are most closely-related, respectively forming all facial bones and cartilage, as well as cranial sensory organs and nerves, in parallel. The goal of this project is to expand our knowledge of the distinct molecular mechanisms that govern placodal and neural crest progenitor fates by examining novel roles for the Foxi3 transcription factor and extracellular BMP signaling during border cell specification.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: In the United States, more than 100,000 carotid endarterectomy or stent procedures are performed annually on patients with narrowing of a carotid artery due to atherosclerosis who have not yet experienced symptoms of a stroke. Recent advances in medical management of atherosclerotic disease have raised questions regarding the net benefit of these procedures to prevent stroke. We are requesting support to complete two parallel multicenter randomized clinical trials, one comparing intensive medical management (IMM) vs. endarterectomy plus IMM (n=1240), the other comparing IMM vs. stenting plus IMM (n=1240).

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE DNA repair abnormalities occur frequently across human cancer types, presenting the potential for targeted tumor treatment via synthetic lethal approaches. We recently discovered a novel DNA modifying agent which generates DNA interstrand crosslinks specifically in tumor cells lacking the DNA direct repair enzyme O6- methylguanine-DNA methyltransferase (MGMT) and is effective in temozolomide (TMZ)-resistant glioma models. This proposal seeks to understand the therapeutic potential of this compound in a broader array of MGMT-deficient cancers, specifically by targeting additional defects in interstrand crosslink repair and by circumventing TMZ resistance.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dual Eligible Special Needs Plans (D-SNPs) have emerged as the largest category of managed care plans intended to integrate Medicare and Medicaid coverage for the nation’s 12.2 million dual eligibles and have evolved to attain different levels of integration. This project will use national Medicare and Medicaid administrative data, nursing facility assessment data, and patient experience surveys to identify attributes of D- SNPs and state Medicaid policies associated with higher quality, efficient, and equitable care, and it will use a difference-in-differences design to identify effects of integrating coverage, leveraging variation in default enrollment into integrated plans. Findings from this project will provide evidence to guide how policymakers improve D-SNPs to address the health care needs of their medically and socially vulnerable enrollees.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Integrating Medicare and Medicaid coverage in managed care: effects on quality, utilization, and disparities

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: In this K12 proposal we wish to establish a training and mentoring program for junior faculty in oncology specialties including hematology-medical oncology, radiation, surgical, gynecologic, neurosurgical and urologic oncology that will provide comprehensive education, training and mentoring for scholars interested in a clinical research career. We will expand existing programs at the Laura and Isaac Perlmutter Cancer Center (PCC) and leverage ongoing training efforts within the NYU Clinical and Translational Science Institute (CTSI) to create an integrated, full-thickness training, mentoring and follow-up program. Our long-term objective is to recruit the next class of scholars in oncology clinical research that will launch careers in clinical investigation and promote their ability to assume leadership roles at PCC and elsewhere.

PHR: Project Narrative In the US, patients presenting to the Emergency Department with an unknown Cardiac Implanted Electronic Device represent a unique problem. Often correct treatment requires the reprogramming of the device by the manufacturer, but it is impossible to quickly determine the manufacturer of each device in the Emergency Department. The MDI a portable, hand-held device that can identify Cardiac Implanted Electronic Devices from any manufacturer either in the Emergency Department, or in transit to the Emergency Department, eliminating the need for a time-consuming and unnecessary x-ray, and enabling first-line medical personnel. The proposed device identifier works by mimicking the “wakeup call” communication of the five major CIED programmers in sequence, and would identify each device by analyzing the response from the CIED.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The renewal of the University of Kentucky Markey Cancer Center’s Appalachian Career Training In ONcology (ACTION) Program will continue a culturally centered cancer education and training opportunity for students from rural, disease-burdened, low socioeconomic, and low education-attainment Appalachian Kentucky communities. The program will enhance the diversity of the biomedical workforce by preparing underrepresented Appalachian Kentucky high school and undergraduate students for biomedical careers. ACTION will also increase the community’s understanding of cancer, thereby addressing the cancer and education disparities in Appalachian Kentucky and beyond.

PHR: Narrative We have identified a subgroup of colorectal cancer (CRC) patients as having “Outlier Methylation Phenotype” (OMP) using normal tissue methylome and OMPs are significantly associated with CRC patients over healthy controls and African American CRC patients are more than twice as likely to have OMP than Caucasians. In our current grant application, we propose to develop OMP as a less- invasive CRC screening and prognostic tool by evaluating the consistency of OMP status in a less-invasive (whole blood) tissue with an invasive tissue (normal colorectal mucosa). We will test whether OMPs identified in colorectal tissues can also be identified in whole blood samples using epigenome-wide data from >850K CpGs and analyze the association of OMP in CRC patients with known CRC molecular subtypes and with future clinical outcomes in controls; and study the association of genetic (single nucleotide polymorphisms including ancestry informative markers) and environmental (diet and social determinants of health) factors with OMPs.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite the scaling up of evidence-based interventions to End the HIV Epidemic (EHE) in the U.S., several communities most affected by HIV – including Black/African American (AA) communities – lag behind the EHE goal of reducing HIV Infections by 90% by 2030. The proposed study aims to characterize ART adherence trajectories among AA people with HIV (PWH), and to examine the influence of psychosocial determinants of health on ART adherence and healthcare utilization. Understanding the influence of psychosocial determinants of health on ART adherence and healthcare utilization will aid in 1) identifying individuals most likely to benefit from the scaling out of evidence-based interventions, and 2) adapting interventions to better target modifiable determinants of ART adherence, which ultimately will support the health and longevity of AA PWH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance statement: Development of shock marks a critical event in sepsis and is linked to a dramatic increase in morbidity and mortality. Our preliminary data supports that mast cells, which are best known for their ability to launch powerful inflammatory responses in allergy, are shaping key features of vascular pathology in septic shock. By defining platelets as the circulating source of mast cell activation and by examining the relevance of mast cell activation in septic patients, we will develop a comprehensive picture of the events that shape development of shock in sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
PHR: Narrative The study of complex traits is fundamental to understanding the nature and behavior of living systems. Most diseases, like Alzheimer or cancer have complex traits whose genetic characterization in model systems have been essential to finding effective therapies. Similarly, venom is a complex trait that has evolved throughout the tree of life, and studying its evolution has broad applications to understanding the development of homologous tissues, the origins of novel genes, and the molecular mechanisms behind the regulation and expression of bioactive compounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: Project Narrative Heart disease is the leading cause of death in the US (even in 2020), while the Center for Disease Control estimates that 6.1 million suffer from abnormal heart rhythms. Adenylyl cyclase produces the small molecule cyclic AMP that is a crucial regulator of cardiac function, including heart rate, in addition to many additional physiological processes. Our studies provide a better understanding of the mechanisms that regulate the local production of cyclic AMP and ultimately heart rate and will uncover new strategies for therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Strategies to safely and effectively prevent ovarian cancer can have important public health impact since ovarian cancer causes more deaths than any other diseases of the female reproductive system. New scientific evidence shows that most ovarian cancers originate from the fallopian tubes rather than from the ovaries, and therefore removing fallopian tubes can effectively reduce ovarian cancer risk while allowing patients to preserve the ovaries that are beneficial for cardiovascular, bone, and cognitive health. The proposed project seeks to identify physician- and patient-related factors that influence the adoption of this new approach to ovarian cancer prevention and inform ways to improve utilization and informed decision-making.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Salpingectomy for Ovarian Cancer Risk Reduction: Improving Utilization and Informed Decision-Making

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The mechanistic basis of many biological processes, such as development, aging, homeostasis, and response to stimuli can be revealed from understanding of metabolism, and there is an urgent need for the imaging platform to visualize 3D volumetric metabolic dynamics and heterogeneity in live cells and tissues. Our proposed study is to develop and optimize a state-of-the-art 3D imaging platform that combining a new generation of deuterated glucose- probed stimulated Raman scattering microscopy with upgraded tissue clearing recipes and custom designed spectral linear unmixing algorithm, for visualizing large volumetric distribution of more than 20 newly synthesized molecules in animal models for studying metabolic pathways.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity currently affects 42% of U.S. adults, costing 173 billion dollars in health care costs annually. Human genetics links obesity to defects in an organelle called the primary cilium, where G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) transmit extracellular information across the cell membrane to direct cell signaling events. This project will decipher how the primary cilium membrane controls GPCR activity and how it responds to dietary lipid consumption with the long-term goal of finding better strategies to treat metabolic disease.

PHR: Project Narrative Damaging more than just the skin, burn injuries can lead to excessive inflammation, often stemming from a breach in the intestinal epithelial barrier, which can allow translocation of bacteria and bacterial products into the circulation. Advanced age is an independent risk factor for mortality after burn injury, especially in patients with severe burns, and aged patients experience greater levels of neurological impairment after burn injury. By investigating age-related mechanisms responsible for early damage to the gut and blood brain barriers after burn injury, we hope to identify novel strategies to reduce the impact of this post-injury neuroinflammation and mental decline seen in elderly burn patients.

PHR: Principal Investigator: FM Fernández – Triboelectric Ambient Mass Spectrometry Imaging of Renal Cell Carcinomas  Mass spectrometry imaging (MSI) is a powerful tool used in cancer research to study biomarkers in tumors and to develop new cancer treatment drugs. Current MSI techniques are powerful but still suffer from some drawbacks such as not having sufficient sensitivity and not being able to ionize all compounds in a tissue sample. We propose a new generation of MSI technology that uses triboelectric nanogenerators coupled to laser ablation to improve on existing MSI techniques; this technology will have higher sensitivity and higher coverage than existing tools, improving our understanding of cancer biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intercellular adhesive junctions formed by cadherins are fundamental to development and organization of tissues in all multicellular animals, and their dysfunction in human disease has severe consequences including fatal developmental errors, cancer progression, and skin blistering. At these junctions, cadherin proteins assemble into intricate and highly ordered structures that bridge between the membranes of contacting cells. We propose to investigate the molecular mechanism of how these large and poorly understood superstructures form at critical cell-cell junctions and how they may be changed in disease by using a multi-pronged approach comprising structural, biophysical and functional methods, including direct visualization in cells and native tissues.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Vestibulodynia (VBD) is the most common cause of sexual pain and may last over 3 months at a time, compromising psychological functioning, interpersonal relations, and daily activities in women with VBD, indicating a desperate need for efficacious treatments. AnelleO has developed a unique flexible, mucoadhesive biodissolvable film for delivery of local anesthetic to the vestibule. The design of the film allows for easy self- administration of treatment, precise dosing, and blocks drug leakage which will increase patient compliance and satisfaction, offering the first vestibule-specific treatment for VBD.

PHR: In the eREACH study we will evaluate a theoretically and stake-holder informed eHealth delivery alternative to traditional genetic counseling, recruiting a nationally representative population of patients who are candidates for genetic testing for cancer susceptibility. We expect this research to significantly inform how best to deliver and communicate results of genetic testing in a way that provides access for all patients across the US, while maintaining adequate understanding and clinical use of genetic test results.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The research in my lab is focused on development of mass spectrometry-based structural methods to study the higher order structure of proteins. We are particularly interested in studying protein structure in complex model systems that mimic the in vivo environment. We are developing these methods for discrete applications including protein aggregation and misfolding as well as further expanding them to other model systems.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Women with advanced hormone receptor (HR)+ breast cancer being treated with endocrine therapy in combination with an inhibitor of cyclin dependent kinase 4/6 (CDK4/6) inhibitor are at risk for debilitating fatigue which can lead to poor quality of life and reductions or even discontinuation of the medication. Lifestyle interventions, particularly exercise and intermittent fasting, are well-tolerated and favorably impact fatigue, biomarkers of inflammation, physical function, patient reported outcomes and body composition in women with early-stage breast cancer, however, there have been few studies in women with advanced breast cancer. To address this gap, we propose a 2 x 2 trial in 260 women with advanced HR+ breast cancer initiating treatment with hormonal therapy in combination with a CDK4/6 inhibitor, to evaluate the impact of either prolonged overnight fasting intervention alone, moderate-intensity exercise alone, or in combination on fatigue and associated inflammatory biomarkers.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Public Health Relevance Statement) Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic, debilitating, inflammatory disease that disproportionally affects older adults, and those with late-onset RA (LORA) have more severe disease and disability. However, older adults are less likely to receive RA treatment that aligns with current clinical practice guidelines suggesting we may be accepting worse outcomes than what may be achievable. This study will inform future optimization of safe and effective medication use in this vulnerable population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Microbes such as Bacteria influence the healthiness of their host in many different ways. To understand how the microbes interact with their host, we need tools to characterize the microbes spatial distribution and also their cellular status. This project aims to build a widely applicable spatial RNA and protein sequencing platform to understand microbe status, spatial organization and their interactions with their host.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Antibiotic-resistant bacteria are of critical concern to human health. MRSA is the leading cause of nosocomial infection in the USA. A vaccine that protects against MRSA infection is highly sought after; however, the development of S. aureus immunobiotics and vaccines is stymied due to antigenic variation and failure of protection. In this Phase I SBIR, we propose to use information learned from our previous studies with inactivated, whole-cell immunogens to test existing and modified candidates and derive a finalized vaccine candidate for future development.

IC_NAME: OFFICE OF THE DIRECTOR, NATIONAL INSTITUTES OF HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Microglia, the immune cells of the brain and spinal cord, are the next frontier for treating neurological diseases. This proposal will investigate how microglia provide protection against viral infection and aims to overcome that protection to enable gene and cell therapies. Completion of this project will identify methods to deliver genes to microglia to make “living drugs” and identify targets to defend the brain against infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NEW MEXICO HEALTH SCIS CTR
PHR: Project Narrative Pregnant women in many countries continue to consume moderate levels of alcohol, which might not result in neurobehavioral problems in their children but may still program the fetus for adulthood diseases. The proposed research is relevant to public health as it begins to address the health risks in adults exposed to moderate levels of alcohol in utero. The project is relevant to the mission of the National Institute of Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism as it advances our fundamental knowledge about the mechanisms involved in increasing the severity of neurological disorders in adults exposed to moderate levels of alcohol in utero and apply that knowledge to reduce the related health consequences.

PHR: PROGRAM NARRATIVE Esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC) is a rapidly rising public health problem and its prognosis remains poor. Barrett's esophagus (BE) is the precursor to esophageal adenocarcinoma but it often goes undetected. The Program Project focuses on genetic and molecular studies that will develop better understanding of how reflux injury and repair result in development of BE and its progression to EAC in susceptible individuals. The ultimate goal is to develop improved methods for detecting BE, predicting its progression to EAC, and preventing BE from progressing to EAC.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Barrett's esophagus is a complex disorder and patients with Barrett's esophagus are at an increased risk of developing esophageal adenocarcinoma, a lethal and most common esophageal malignancy in the United States. To date, the mechanisms contributing to the onset and malignant progression of Barrett's esophagus remain poorly understood. Our proposed studies are accordingly designed to unravel the molecular underpinnings of Barrett's esophagus and associated esophageal malignancy, with an overarching goal of developing evidence-based biomarkers and rational chemopreventive/therapeutic strategies for this increasingly prevalent and complex disease.

PHR: Thousands of children are born blind in around the world, often due to genetic hereditary abnormalities or environmental factors. In this proposal, we will examine the functional and neuroanatomical changes to the posterior parietal cortex that emerge with early loss of vision, and determine if these changes confer compensatory behaviors on congenitally blind individuals. We will investigate these changes at two important developmental stages. These data can influence therapeutic interventions and allow predictions for behavioral outcomes following such therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Artificial Intelligence assisted echocardiography to facilitate optimal image  extraction for congenital heart defects diagnosis in Sub-Saharan Africa Narrative Congenital heart defects (CHD) is a major contributor to under-5 deaths in Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA), owing to the lack of paediatric cardiologist experts who can perform an echocardiography scan for early diagnosis. The current project seeks to develop an artificial intelligence assisted model that will allow local non-experts such as nurses who work in birthing centres, to conduct an echocardiography scan and extract optimal images which can sent to a remote expert for interpretation and diagnosis confirmation. This will remove the burden and risk of travelling hundreds of kilometers to expert centres mainly located in cities, increase early diagnosis and initiation of care remotely, and reduce the workload on the few available experts.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Esophageal and gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinomas remain cancers associated with poor survival, and current preventive strategies have been limited in reducing this high mortality. Improvements in screening and preventive approaches may emerge from more complete understanding of how esophageal adenocarcinomas arise in the context of chronic injury and abnormal wound healing. We focus on esophageal submucosal glands as a potential source of progenitor cells in the esophagus where we have observed inflammation and we now propose experiments to understand this microenvironment and how it may influence wound healing with the goal of identifying more effective preventive strategies to reduce cancer risk and improving current strategies for esophageal cancer interception.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The ILERA study aims to build integrated models for early risk prediction to address the rising burden of non- communicable diseases (focusing on cardiometabolic diseases and associated traits) in many African countries, taking into consideration the predictive power of genetic risk scores when combined with predicted gene expression data and non-genetic (environmental and lifestyle) information. The models will be developed using data from South African participants and evaluated in independent cohorts from south, west and east Africa, as well as examining age-related effects in longitudinal data. The methods and models that best predict the cardiometabolic disease outcomes will be used to stratify populations according to risk categories and their potential translation into early warning systems will be investigated.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will examine existing quality measures that define avoidable hospital care among adults with cancer and compare their performance to in-depth clinician reviews of medical records. We will recategorize hospital visits into actionable clinical scenarios to help cancer providers identify avoidable hospital visits and create a new quality measure to identify conditions that could be treated in oncology urgent care clinics. We will validate findings with patients and emergency clinicians, then survey cancer care providers nationwide to ensure that these categories and quality measure are accurate and useful.

To date, the mechanisms contributing to the onset and malignant progression of Barrett's esophagus remain poorly understood. Our proposed studies are accordingly designed to unravel the molecular underpinnings of Barrett's esophagus and associated esophageal malignancy, with an overarching goal of developing evidence-based biomarkers and rational chemopreventive/therapeutic strategies for this increasingly prevalent and complex disease.

PHR: NARRATIVE – PROJECT 1 Gastric cancer is a leading cause of cancer morbidity and mortality worldwide and is associated with poor clinical outcomes and limited therapeutic options. Early detection of precancerous lesions, particularly gastric intestinal metaplasia, has the potential to identify patients at highest risk for neoplastic progression, enable novel prevention strategies, and ultimately enhance health outcomes and reduce mortality for individuals with gastric cancer. Project 1 aims to characterize the precise molecular and cellular landscape of high-risk gastric intestinal metaplasia, and leverage this information to improve gastric cancer detection, prevention, and treatment.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed CURE for Cancer program will develop and implement a multifaceted, culturally relevant cancer- focused research experience for American Indian and Hispanic high school and undergraduate students. By cultivating student interests in college to graduate and professional schools, boosting their self-efficacy in science, and helping them attain skills needed to apply and ultimately succeed in higher education programs, we expect CURE for Cancer trainees will productively contribute to tackling the significant education and health needs of underserved communities locally and nationally. Moreover, the emphasis on American Indian and Hispanic students from under-resourced communities will address national priorities for their recruitment and retention in STEM-H careers, especially biomedical science and cancer-related health careers that address the health disparities experienced by these populations.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Novus Vision Inc. is developing a novel eye drop drug delivery technology, OcuGel, that has promise for providing longer-lasting and more effective drug delivery to the anterior and posterior segments to treat a variety of ophthalmic diseases. Here, we describe preclinical development work to reformulate a brimonidine OcuGel eye drop as a pharmaceutically appropriate, shelf stable, repeat use formulation for once daily dosing to treat glaucoma. At the end of the project period, we will have an appropriate data package for an IND submission to continue development.

PHR: Project Narrative Clathrin-mediated endocytosis is the primary route of internalization from the plasma membrane and is required for cell viability and the proper response to extracellular cues like growth factor signaling. Mutations in the endocytic machinery, or the proteins that regulate this process, lead to a variety of diseases like cancer and neurodegeneration. This research will take an interdisciplinary approach to understand the mechanisms of endocytic initiation and cargo selection to understand CME in normal cells and how it is subverted in human disease.

PHR: Project narrative The main objective of this project is to implement a complementary set of capacity building actions, at global level and in a number of selected countries focusing on risk-based practices and overall comprehensive assessments of food control systems to improve national food control frameworks. Risk-based approaches to food control and identification of the weaknesses in the food control system help minimizing exposure to food hazards, while making more efficient use of the available resources, that may be scarce for many developing or transition countries. In the development and delivery of this project, high importance is placed on coherence with other activities, both in FAO and beyond, to support an optimal and a sustainable outcome, while linkages will be ensured between the technical and the political frameworks to facilitate policy changes based on the improved understanding about where the risks lie.

PROJECT_TITLE: Strengthening global food safety through improved capacities for food control at regional and country levels

PHR: Narrative Over the course of human evolution, a complex process of genetic inheritance across diverse human populations has given rise to intricate patterns of statistical association between genetic variants and common complex diseases. Population-based studies that assess the genomes of large samples of unrelated cases and controls offer a powerful approach for identifying common disease risk variants, primarily those for which risk is conferred by possessing a single copy of a risk allele. Our project will leverage models from human population genetics to provide methods and software that will accelerate the discovery and characterization of rare, recessive genetic factors—for which risk is conferred by possession of two copies of the risk variant— addressing challenges arising from large data sets, complex genome sequencing projects, and the effort to find disease variants in underrepresented populations.

PHR: Project Narrative The function of macromolecules involves dynamic interactions with other molecules, so studying their structural variability is often key to understanding their functioning mechanism. In this proposal, we will develop novel computational methods that analyze the structural heterogeneity of proteins imaged by CryoEM and CryoET. Using the Gaussian mixture model for protein structure representation and deep neural network for constructing the conformation space, the software tools will provide a more comprehensive view of the dynamic of macromolecular systems.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATVE Aggressive variant prostate cancers (AVPC) respond to carboplatin+cabazitaxel but remain with a poor prognosis. We propose a tissue-rich clinical trial, and co-clinical studies in mice, combining ADI-PEG20 (which depletes serum arginine levels) with carboplatin+cabazitaxel to evaluate the safety, efficacy and effects of this combination on intratumoral metabolites, signaling pathways, and immune profiles of the AVPC tumor microenvironment. The results of these studies will serve to inform further rational combinations for the treatment of the AVPC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study will test of the influence of two individual difference factors, motivation for alcohol and cognitive control, on alcohol use and problems in young adults making the transition to legal drinking (i.e., the 21st birthday). The study will examine how these processes contribute to the increase in alcohol problems, especially alcohol-impaired driving, that is known to occur in the year after the 21st birthday. Knowledge gained from this research will inform efforts to reduce alcohol-related problems in young adult drinkers.

PHR: NARRATIVE Blepharospasm is a neurological disorder characterized by over-activity of the muscles around the eyes, leading to excessive blinking, eye spasms, impaired eyelid opening, and sometimes involvement of the lower face and jaw. In the current studies, we describe a multifaceted approach for the detection, discrimination, and measurement of these different problems, so that they can be better studied.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE After learning, new memories are consolidated, which relies on transferring information from the hippocampus to the cortex. This project aims to understand how hippocampal inputs and local circuit dynamics in the prefrontal cortex interact to support memory consolidation. Thus, this proposal will lead to a critical understanding of the mechanisms of memory processing that will provide insight into how memories are consolidated in the cortex for long-term storage.

PHR: Project Narrative In this study, the DISCOVER (Digital Innovation, Simulation, and Collaboration using Virtual Environment Realities) for Pediatric Diagnostic Excellence Learning Lab we will build a patient safety learning lab combining the expertise of LiveWell, a design collaborative with user-centered design and human factors expertise, with the clinical knowledge, implementation science expertise, and world-renowned virtual simulation program of Cincinnati Children’s Hospital Medical Center. This learning lab will use systems engineering methodology to envision, develop, prototype and test design-informed clinical decision support approaches to improving diagnosis in an existing highly immersive virtual clinical world.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The gene regulation processes by which an olfactory sensory neuronal progenitor goes from co-expressing multiple olfactory receptor genes to monogenic, monoallelic choice of olfactory receptor genes in mature olfactory sensory neurons needs to be further elucidated. Tex15 is transiently expressed during the critical gene regulation window in olfactory sensory neuronal progenitors, and we hypothesize that Tex15 is regulating monoallelic olfactory receptor gene choice through either methylation patterns or through its effect on chromatin state of developing olfactory sensory neurons. Through this study, I will be trained on cutting-edge molecular, cellular and computational neuroscience approaches to answer some of the broader questions of the field of olfactory sensory neuron gene expression and gene regulation patterns.

PHR: Project Narrative In this project, we will conduct exome-wide discovery efforts to identify rare variants and genes that contribute to risk of prostate cancer and aggressive disease in men of European, African, Asian and Latino ancestry. We expect findings from this study will make a major contribution to our understanding of genetic susceptibility to prostate cancer and will have widespread applicability and significance, leading to better risk models to more accurately predict a man's risk of developing prostate cancer and aggressive disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute seizures may evolve into status epilepticus (SE) which can result in irreversible brain injury or death and costs ~$4 billion per year to the US healthcare system. The QuITT-SE effectiveness-implementation hybrid trial utilizes quality improvement interventions and methods derived from a single-center project that improved outcomes in children and mitigated over $2 million in charges. By studying the effects of these interventions and their implementation across an established research consortium, we will develop and refine a standardized toolkit and implementation framework to improve the safety and value of SE treatment across diverse hospital settings.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myriel, Inc., is a pharmaceutical start-up company founded in 2022 whose goal is to find cures for tauopathies by developing small-molecule caspase-2 inhibitors that repair synapses by preventing the cleavage of the tau protein and increasing the number of functional AMPA receptors in dendritic spines. The goal of this Phase 1 STTR application is provide Myriel with a brain-penetrant analogue of our lead caspase-2 inhibitor, GPHR ‘739, by preparing prodrugs and validating the improvements in brain-penetration through pharmacokinetic studies.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The recent explosion in biobanking, more routine collection of data on gender identity, and rapid expansion of research in transgender and gender diverse (TGD) populations has afforded both an opportunity to study whether gender identity has genetic underpinnings, and a time sensitive need to inform how such research is used to benefit and not harm TGD populations. In partnership with and guided by an Executive Stakeholder Board of diverse TGD community members, advocates, clinicians, and ethics, legal, and genomics and health equity scholars, we will explore potential risks and benefits of studying genomic associations with gender identity, host a summit to develop guidelines and recommendations for such research, and widely disseminate our findings. Our team will continue to serve as a national network to provide consultation and leadership in the expanding field of genomic research related to gender diverse populations.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As rates of depression in adolescent girls continue to rise, causing worsening disability and illness in this population worldwide, it is critical to investigate how social media use may amplify certain behaviors in ways that exacerbate vulnerability to depression. The overarching objective of the proposed project is to advance our knowledge of a potentially modifiable social media use behavior, intimate self-disclosure, and whether it represents a unique risk factor for depression in girls, especially those with high levels of social media use. Completion of the proposed aims is an important step towards identifying potentially modifiable behaviors that confer risk for depression-related outcomes in the context of social media use, and informing future prevention and intervention for depression in adolescent girls.

Completion of this project may provide new molecular targets for potential therapeutic intervention of alcohol use disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative Alcoholic hepatitis (AH) is an acute form of alcoholic liver disease (ALD) with high short-term mortality, with over 450,000 hospital admissions per year and a 40–50% mortality rate (for severe AH) at 1 month from presentation. Chronic liver injury from excessive alcohol consumption leads to telomere shortening in the liver, and there is strong evidence that telomere extension may improve AH patient survival. This project will advance Rejuvenation Technologies’ breakthrough treatment for AH, comprised of telomerase mRNA that extends telomeres transiently, the same mechanism used by stem cells, and a lipid nanoparticle vehicle that delivers the telomerase mRNA to the liver with high efficiency and low toxicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic alcohol exposure causes cognitive deficits, which are associated with increased relapse probability and continued misuse. I hypothesize that chronic alcohol exposure produces cognitive deficits through altering activity and function of the nucleus reuniens of the thalamus and that normalizing its activity will attenuate cognitive dysfunction. Using a multimodal experimental approach, I will characterize the impact of chronic ethanol exposure on nucleus reuniens physiology and demonstrate how it impacts cognitive function.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Conceptual models of childhood adversity propose that specific features of adversity significantly increase risk for mental health problems throughout the lifespan likely through mechanisms such as changes in biological development. This project aims to leverage multivariate approaches with a longitudinal sample to identify the respective benefits of each conceptual model in relation to adolescent neural development and mental health trajectories, and will explore how positive childhood experiences influence such relationships. The knowledge gained from this project will contribute to scientific understanding of linkages between exogenous exposures and development, and will advance methodological approaches to be coextensive with the complexity inherent to measuring and operationalizing childhood experiences.

ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative The escalating rates of alcohol use among vulnerable youth populations necessitate a thorough understanding of how environmental factors shape risky decision-making, especially regarding alcohol use. This study proposes a novel multivariate approach that uses longitudinal data from the ABCD Study to calculate a polyexposure risk score and determine the role of inhibitory control in the risk for alcohol use onset in youth ages 10-14. The findings are expected to provide critical insights into the complex multidimensional features of youth at greater risk for early onset of alcohol use, and inform effective risk-mitigating strategies to reduce the prevalence of alcohol use among vulnerable youth populations.

ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hyperadrenergic autonomic crises are episodes of drastic and acute increases in blood pressure and heart rate, accompanied by unremitting vomiting, retching, and are the most frequent and severe manifestations of a rare genetic disease - familial dysautonomia (FD). Hyperadrenergic autonomic crises result from improper develop- ment and function of the autonomic nervous system and are treated primarily using non-pharmacologic measures and at-home medications that carry severe side effects and don’t prevent secondary complications. In this study, we will test a new approach to resolving the autonomic crises in patients with FD that combines an easily deliverable and effective medication, sublingual dexmedetomidine film, along with non-pharmacological assistance through telemedicine and a wearable device that continuously records vital signs, to provide data to be applied towards the development of effective, at-home strategies for autonomic crises resolution and preven- tion.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Dexmedetomidine Sublingual Film for the Ambulatory Treatment of Hyperadrenergic Autonomic Crisis in Patients with Familial Dysautonomia

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer is the second leading cause of death in the United States. Many cancers show a difference in incidence or outcomes between males and females. This proposal explores how rearrangements involving the X- chromosome can lead sex-specific differences in cancer pathogenesis and unveil sex-specific vulnerabilities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Healthy tongue function is vital for human chewing, swallowing and speaking, and loss of tongue function due to stroke, degenerative diseases and surgery results in significant health problems, including, malnutrition, pneumonia, and difficulty swallowing and speaking. This project will use natural feeding behaviors in nonhuman primates to elicit a wide range of tongue movements and associated muscle and brain activity during chewing and swallowing, develop and test biomechanical models of how tongue movements are produced and how the brain controls those movements. These data will inform strategies for rehabilitation of chewing and swallowing in patients through exercise, non-invasive brain stimulation, lingual prostheses and brain machine interfaces.
